Mancuso would come back to record a "Billy Commentary" on the film, which is on the recent Scream Factory! release.Warner Brother studio executives hated the ending and demanding that Clark change the final scene to have Chris appear before Jess and say, "Agnes, don't tell them what we did" before murdering her. However, Clark stuck to his guns and kept the ending that he believed in. The studio further tinkered with the film, calling it Silent Night, Evil Night in its original release.When NBC aired the film as Stranger in the House on the January 28, 1978 edition of Saturday Night at the Movies, it gave stations the option of airing Doc Savage, as the Ted Bundy murders had just occurred two weeks earlier.There's an urban legend that this was Elvis' favorite horror movie. It definitely made an impression on Steve Martin, who told Olivia Hussey "Oh my God, Olivia, you were in one of my all-time favorite films" when she was being considered for Roxanne. She thought he meant Romeo and Juliet, but he told her that he meant Black Christmas, claiming that he had seen the film 27 times.There's another urban legend - how many can one film have - that says that Halloween was originally intended as a sequel to this movie.Clark would go on to direct Porky's and a film that failed at first before becoming a holiday tradition, 1983's A Christmas Story. Yep - he pretty much made both the happiest and darkest films about the Yuletide, which is pretty awesome.I love this movie. It's a true classic that's unafraid to go against conventions even as it creates them. Nearly every actor and actress in this movie went on to do more and play their roles perfectly here.

I can't believe I didn't know that this movie is so amazing! I had never seen it, and I thought it was just one of those subpar horror movies from the 70s. It's so, so good! The characters are so well-written, and their relationships and interactions are all believable. It's perfectly plotted and paced. Also, it's cozy and terrifying at the same time. I love this movie sooooo much!!! Also, I was shocked to find that it was written and directed by two men. That's no knock on men. The commentary about reproductive issues and how police often don't take women's concerns seriously when they feel threatened was just so spot on. This is an instant favorite. :)

I was really looking forward to seeing this movie, in the main because I have read from several sources that this was massively influential on Halloween, the John Carpenter slasher classic. I have to say, though, (and I'm not proud of this) that I found this to be very boring throughout. There's some good POV work, which I guess is the inspiration behind many of the similar scenes in Halloween, but overall it's all a little too soap opera, with endless scenes of Sorority dullards wittering senseless prattle. I must confess that the film has one of the finest taglines I've ever read: "If this film doesn't make your skin crawl...it's on too tight." Pure quality.I don't know, maybe I was expecting too much, but this just left me a little cold.

OK, you've probably heard that Bob Clark's (RIP) "Black Christmas" is basically the original slasher movie, the inspiration for John Carpenter's "Halloween". Well, let me just say that - in response to the tag-line - my skin did actually crawl a little bit during some of the phone calls! Of course, that doesn't even begin to identify what makes this such a scary movie. Aside from not knowing the killer's identity, some of the scenes towards the end really catch you.But that's only one cool aspect. The cast includes Olivia Hussey (Juliet in "Romeo and Juliet"), Keir Dullea (Dave in "2001: A Space Odyssey"), Margot Kidder (Lois in "Superman") and John Saxon (Roper in "Enter the Dragon"); no doubt when Olivia Hussey and Keir Dullea appeared in their most famous roles in 1968, they never imagined that they would co-star in this sort of movie. Director Bob Clark is most famous for "A Christmas Story" and the "Porky's" movies; seriously, what kind of person can lay claim to directing movies as different as these, plus "Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things"? But the main point is that this is the mother of all slasher movies. Like "The Jazz Singer" to sound, like "I Haven't Got a Hat" to the Looney Tunes, like "I Love Lucy" to sitcoms, everything started here. No matter how you look at it, "Black Christmas", for lack of a better word, is DA BOMB! Not only do the cast members truly have something about which to proud, but it goes to show what we lost when Bob Clark got killed in a car wreck earlier this year.PS: the special edition DVD includes an interview with Olivia Hussey (and she still looks quite good after all these years). She didn't see the completed film until many years later, as horror flicks scare her. Well, I think that it's practically a guarantee that at least one scene in this movie will scare you. Because as Olivia Hussey notes, the idea of there being something creepy out there is scarier than knowing what's there.

The girls at a sorority are getting terrifying obscene phone calls during the Christmas season and, when one of them goes missing, they come to the conclusion that perhaps this harmless prank caller could be a murderer.Bob Clark's holiday horror film predates John Carpenter's Halloween by a few years, but has many of the same tropes from the killer's P. O. V. Shots to the likable group of young women friends to the holiday setting and the chilling open ending. Unlike Halloween, Black Christmas has the added bonus of its power not being diluted by sequels over the years trying to overexplain its mysterious killer.

This is a real let down, the movie goes on and on. But it really doesn't say much. It does have a good cast and that helps. But it makes you wonder what the hell were they think when they agreed to star in this snooze. It's long, it's boring, we never learn the identity of the killer of his motive. Near the end of the movie, the guy who was nothing but a Saint is killed and takes the fall for the killings, but the real killer is still lurking about the house and they never found the one girl who was killed with the plastic bag who still sits in the attic. Good thing the Police did such a intense search of the house. This is a stupid bad ending, I just pray the remake fixes the stupid ending of this crapper and I hope the stars remove it from their resume. I give it the LUMP OF COAL.

reviews.review_title: Filled with Christmas melancholy and cheer, for a horror film this movie is really quite good.
reviews.content: "It's him again...the moaner!""No, Claire. That's the Mormon Tabernacle choir doing their annual team phone call."-Barb"I don't think you should provoke someone like that"-ClaireThis film was a complete surprise to me. A horror film set in a sorority during Christmas break at the college, it is filled with equal parts Christmas cheer, Christmas melancholy and Halloween style horror!"It's me Billy"...I loved the horror film House on Sorority Row, which I saw at a young and impressionable age during a Halloween party sleepover. That will probably remain my favorite sorority horror film, but this is a very close second and I can't help but wonder if one didn't influence the other.The story takes place on a college campus (filmed on the Toronto campus in 1974 this is almost like a time capsule of the times) at the start of their Christmas break. A group of sorority girls have a small party with the girls with those still left in the house before they head off on their separate Christmas adventures. There is Barb, played by Margot Kidder, who has a potty mouth, likes to shock people, drinks heavily and is unnaturally fascinated with fornication particularly that of zoo animals! There is Jess (played by Olivia Hussey), who is dating a concert pianist Peter studying at the local conservatory and who is pregnant but wants to abort the baby. There is Claire who is dating a hockey player and all around good guy...she is to meet her father to be taken home the next day, but ends up being the first to go missing. Then there is good girl Phyl and their house mother Mrs. Mac...who seems to have a bottle of booze stashed everywhere in the house for her enjoyment...(tank of the toilet, encyclopedia "B for Booze"). (Personally, I would need a lot of alcohol to deal with those sorority girls as well!). The girls have been getting persistent obscene phone calls...including during the party. When Claire doesn't meet her father for their rendezvous, he goes to the sorority looking for her. Eventually he and her fellow sorority sisters go to the police to report her missing. The police station is busy as there is a missing girl from town and desk sergeant Nash, doesn't take them too seriously as he says, "I don't know if it's any consolation but 90 percent of the time when girls are reported missing from the college they are at a cabin somewhere with a boyfriend."It's not until Claire's boyfriend a well liked hockey player shows up that it gets the attention of Lt. Ken Fuller (Jon Saxon) and the police start to take them seriously...including the prank phone calls.This film has all the elements of a great horror film, it builds suspense, delivers on the horror and leaves you with that haunting unfinished feeling perfect for a Halloween night!"Just tell her to put down the phone and walk straight out of the house."-Lt. FullerThe haunting ending as the wind roars and the phone rings...no music, just the end credits! It leaves you with that great tingly, butterflies in your stomach feeling.This is a great must watch for any horror night like a Halloween sleepover!

It's easy to see and understand why Black Christmas has such a large cult following, not only is it an influential film (see 'Halloween') for the many slasher films to come, but it's also an exercise in minimalism, one of my favorite things about this film is the killer never gets a reveal, it could be anybody, anywhere, how long has it been since you've check the upstairs? It's a spine tingling thriller from a confident director at the top of his game, along side a great cast of scream queens, although they may not all be able to fully save the convienence laden script, there's just a few too many plot holes to make this a true stand out contender, but as a whole Black Christmas will satisfy those slasher cravings in an otherwise slasher-free holiday season.

reviews.review_title: Much ahead of its time but found it to b dull.
reviews.content: I first saw this on a VHS in the late 80s. Revisited it recently on a DVD. Plot - A group of sorority sisters are receiving threatening phone calls, they r stalked and murdered during the holiday season by a deranged murderer. Black Christmas was a bit ahead of its time by using the subject of abortion as one of the main stories in the film. Also a lot of the killers movements are filmed in a point of view style. It was also a first horror film to have its villain use phone calls as a way to terrorize its victims. This movie also has an open ending without revealing or pondering much bah the killer. Also it is notable for "the calls r coming from the house" revelation. Now coming to the flaws, the movie is very slow paced. The editing n cinematography is  not upto the mark. The kills r minimum n most of it r lousy n not at all scary. The tension was lacking. On the contrary the remake had some brutal death scenes.

When the remake of When A Stranger Calls was out, obviously I was interested in watching the original. Then when I read about the original (which I recall had my sisters totally freaked out back in the day) I saw that the real money is on Black Christmas, which apparently beat everyone to the "the caller is in the house" punch. So I Netflix that, and it sits at the top of my list for months due to its "very long wait." All this time I am getting more and more eager to see it! Then one day, out of the blue, it finally arrives! ...And it's a total snore.Sure, maybe I had elevated expectations, but I don't think it would have gained more had I seen it fresh. The thing is it's Christmas in some Canadian college town, and there's this sorority having a party. We see some killer-POV shots as he climbs this trellis and sneaks into the attic. So we KNOW he's in the house. Then we're introduced to our characters-Olivia Hussey as the mousy, whiny, Canadian-accented Jess. Margot Kidder as the annoying, overtly aggressive alcoholic Barb. She's so annoying even her mother dis-invites her for her Christmas festivities. There's also this irritating Janis Ian clone ("Phil") and this alcoholic den mother Mrs. Mac, seen taking nips from the various bottles of booze she has stashed all over the house. We also meet Jess's highly-strung boyfriend Peter, played by Keir Dullea of 2001 and Bunny Lake is Missing fame, though halfway through the film I was still asking myself "Which one's Keir Dullea?"So it seems that the house has been receiving obscene phone calls, but this was before email, so they couldn't ask him to send a photo. Then-well, you know how they say those plastic dry-cleaning bags are not a toy? One of the sisters finds that out the hard way. Don't worry if you don't catch the first 14 shots of the plastic-encased corpse face as it reposes in the attic-there'll be 28 more interspersed throughout the film, obviously there to make you say "Oh my God! There's a corpse in the attic!" Though after the first hour that changes to: "How come the dumb police haven't found the rather prominently-placed plastic-encased corpse in the attic?" Especially as it is made abundantly clear that it is clearly visible from outside the house. Really, any time before CSI came on the air must have been such a golden age of crime; the cops are so dumb. Fortunately some of them look like John Saxon.Anyway, after a lot more darn boring human drama, the house mother fears that her precious kitty has ascended a vertical ladder and has pushed open a heavy-looking trap door that rests atop it (those wily cats!), for she sticks her head in there and ends up with a hook pulley in her neck for the trouble. Now we have two corpses up in the attic-hey, why don't we have 75 more shots trying to chill us by the fact that there are now TWO corpses in the attic?So by now the police have begun to take the situation seriously, and tap the houses' phone and station a cop outside. They inform Jess and her pal Janis Ian that if the obscene caller calls back, they need to keep him on the phone. Jessica, who has grown even more whiny, mousy and annoying keeps asking the caller "Who is this? What do you want? Who are you?" after like the first 89 calls, when it is clear that he is not going to answer her. Isn't that like a sign a developmental disability? The inability to learn from unsuccessful attempts at something? And what's he going to do, suddenly say "Oh yeah, hi, it's Bob from the Laundromat?" Dumb Jess.Spoilers! Anyway, soon Janis Ian and Lois Lane (Kidder) are piled in bed with ketchup splashed on their faces (this film's idea of gore), and idiot Jess realizes that not a single door or window in the house is locked. Hello? Are you being stalked or what? Then the cops realize that the killer is in the house, and call Jess and tell her "don't ask questions, just do as I say walk to the front door and get out." So what does moron Jess do? Starts screaming "Phil? Barb? Phil? Barb?" Hey, great idea sister. Now why don't you go right upstairs where you know a psychotic killer is lurking? Of course she does, and sees her former friends, all splashed with ketchup, prompting this viewer to scream at the screen: "Have a clue now?!"Now, obviously one needs to be understanding and realize that this movie was made before the classic slasher movie tropes were solidly in place, and that it doesn't move to the same pace we're used to, and seeing a plastic-covered corpse in the attic like 206 times probably WAS scary back in the day, and people weren't used to being stalked by psychopaths, so they wouldn't think to, you know, lock the doors or windows. And they might be tempted to wander upstairs when they have just been told that a rabid killer is up there. You see, people were stupid back in the 70s. We have to understand that. One of the big shocks is that we don't even see our proto-Final Girl kill the psycho. But believe me, that fact is more interesting being read in this review than sitting through the movie for. Spoilers end! ------ Hey, check out Cinema de Merde, my website on bad and cheesy movies (with a few good movies thrown in). You can find the URL in my email address above.

This is one of the best horror films I've, seen and I love it. I feel that this film is slightly underrated and overlooked and some people don't realise how good it actually is. I have seen This Film a few times now and it still holds up really well. This film has everything, great acting, likable characters a nice location, and a story that works very well. Since this is such an old film i'm sure that a lot of people have seen it so i don't have to explain much of the story. Its about a crazed killer stalking a bunch of girls at their sorority house on campus and the killer starts killing people one by one. This may sound like your typical horror movie but believe me its not. This movie works well because of its atmosphere and its creepiness. I found this to be a very dark and chilling film, it was also suspenseful and had some mystery behind it, and I quite liked the mystery, it makes a nice change because most horror films just have a bunch of kills. But there seemed to be more to this film than just killings. I guess I just thought this film had more of a story to it than most horror films do.There are a lot of chilling and creepy scenes in this film that will make your skin crawl and my personal favourite were the weird phone calls. I thought they were done well, and the killer spoke in a way that made your skin crawl. He was creepy and his voice was creepy. The actor that played the killer did a good job and I thought this film had some good idea's like the killer hiding in the attic of the girls sorority house, I thought that was a great idea and I found it creepy that he was up there watching people out the window and nobody knew he was up there and, the heavy breathing from the killer is also very creepy especially when we don't see him. I liked him as a villain and I liked the lead girl Olivia Hussey, she looked great in this film and I found her character likable and she played her role well and the rest of the cast were good too. I also liked how things were sometimes filmed from the killers point of view as he quietly crept around the house, this added to the creepiness in my opinion. I liked the whodunit aspect of the film and I thought the twist was clever and the ending was effectively Creepy. This is a classic film and deserves a watch, its highly recommended. This excellent film deserves a 10/10.

The sound of winds, random other sounds and disturbing nature of everything is wide and glorious! So effective and nerve wracking vibes of suspenseful mastery. There's so much madness about destruction whether it's death or objects, excitingly awesome and fun. I think I enjoy Black Christmas more than most horror in the last 50 years.

Sorority house sisters are being terrorized by mysterious and obscene phone calls as Christmas comes closer. The unknown caller then escalates things to murder, and seems determined to kill everyone in the house, which, unknown to them, he is secretly inhabiting in the attic...Good cast(Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, John Saxon, Keir Dullea) cannot salvage this bizarre yet strangely flat horror film, which did come before "Halloween", but has none of that film's skill and scares that made it so memorable. Some eeriness with the deranged voice of the killer, but leads nowhere because it doesn't pay off at all. (No background or explanation of the killer is most annoying.) The ending is especially maddening in this regard!

For those movie lovers who appreciate the subversive take of the horror genre on the Yuletide season, "Black Christmas" is one of the all time great Christmas themed chillers. Producer / director Bob Clark had already done the cult favourites "Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things" and "Dead of Night" (a.k.a. "Deathdream"). He'd move away from the genre after this, but certainly ended this string of titles with one of the best and most memorable on his resume. Of course, he would return to Christmas fare almost a decade later with the much more upbeat "A Christmas Story"."Black Christmas", written by Roy Moore, tells the story of a sorority house being menaced during the holidays by a stealthy and supremely creepy psycho, identified as "Billy". We never really learn much about him, and he's kept off screen or in shadow most of the time; the only part of him we ever clearly see is his eye. It remains to be seen if the few girls remaining in the house (most have left for their vacations) can survive the ordeal.It has naturally been mentioned many times how certain elements in this story would be popularized in subsequent movies like "Halloween" and "When a Stranger Calls". If one is already familiar with slasher movies before viewing this movie for the first time, they can hardly fail to notice that it won't play out in a way they're used to. The final girl in this case is nice enough but hardly "innocent". The atmosphere both in and outside the house is excellent (Carl Zittrer's music is a big help in this regard). Clark goes for a largely subtle approach, emphasizing the atmosphere and creepiness, utilizing a little bit of gore, but mostly going for a classic "old dark house" type of feeling.The sense of humour is a great asset, as well, with scene stealing Margot Kidder, as the vulgar sorority sister Barb (who also displays a touching vulnerability at one point) supplying much of it. Douglas McGrath as dim bulb police officer Sargeant Nash and Marian Waldman as secret drinking house mother Mrs. Mac are both a hoot. Lovely Olivia Hussey of "Romeo & Juliet" fame is leading character Jess, who already has her own problems to deal with, including her boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea of "2001: A Space Odyssey"), a temperamental musician. Andrea Martin is wonderfully appealing in a very straight-laced performance as her friend Phyl. And John Saxon has a great presence here as the compassionate and dedicated Lt. Fuller. Fans will also recognize actors such as Art Hindle ("Invasion of the Body Snatchers" '78, "The Brood"), Les Carlson ("Deranged", "Videodrome"), and Lynne Griffin ("Curtains", "Strange Brew") in supporting roles.The movie builds slowly to a scary climax, which actually isn't quite as scary as the ultimate reveal right at the end, that plays out behind the closing credits. This helps to cement this movies' status as a horror classic. While it was a hit here in Canada in its time, it did take a while for its reputation to grow elsewhere. It's one of the movies I would easily recommend to new fans of the horror genre. 42 years later, it still works extremely well.Nine out of 10.

Considered in Some Circles to be the First "Slasher" Movie.But this Type of Declaration is Fraught with Opinionated Opportunism.It is the One-Film that Created the "Holiday" Horror Movie.No Holiday is more Sacrosanct then "Christmas" and is why Bob Clark Changed the Original Title from "Stranger in the House".The Movie is quite Accomplished Artistically Apart from the Usually Uninspired Creation from Low-Budget "Band Wagon", Bottom-Line Imitators.The Atmosphere and Look of the Movie has a Colorful Quality and Takes Advantage of Holiday Trappings and Festivity.Alcohol Plays a Prominent Influence On-Screen and even has Margot Kidder (who insisted of drinking real alcohol during filming) Dispensing Drinks to a Minor.The Film also Includes Lewd and Profane Dialog.The Contemporaneous "Real Life" Serial Killings had Authorities and Other Overly Pius People Loudly Voicing Protests.Overall, the Movie does Deserve Accolades for Delivering its Low-Budget (around $600,000) Horror-Show with Style and Cutting-Edge Cinematic Ingredients that would be Imitated Ad-Nausea for Decades.With an Attention to Detail, for the Artistic Flourishes and its Trend-Setting the Movie is Essential for Horror Buffs. For Others its...Worth a Watch.

reviews.review_title: I appreciate it for what it was
reviews.content: Black Christmas was just boring and not atmospheric enough for my taste. I did not like the killer at all, I did not find him scary, and him acting like a child on the phone calls was not scary at all and very annoying. They also put way too much effort into trying to make us believe that her boyfriend was the killer. I had a hard time taking this movie seriously and couldn't wait until it was over. I will not watch it again. I respect what it was, and how it inspired Halloween, which is my favorite horror movie of all time, but that doesn't mean I have to like it

reviews.review_title: It was getting good but the ending was a flop.........
reviews.content: I've seen this on Christmas Eve and I honestly thought it was gonna be a good movie. However, I felt disappointed when we still didn't get to see the killer caught and yet, the audience like myself knew who done it. If they ever thought about a Christmas horror film, at least give it a proper ending and not be messing it up like as if we'll leave it at that! Hello, I was getting interested in seeing one of the girls boyfriend get caught. I wish I had something more to say about this film, its just it left a bad question mark for me and thats why Im giving this a 6/10 rating instead of 8/10.........

A sorority house is being terrorized by obscene and disturbing phone calls. Little do they know the phone calls are only the tip of the iceberg. A mysterious and unknown killer is lurking in and around their house killing them one-by-one.This horror/thriller gets more intense as it goes and it gets bonus points for addressing contemporary issues. You have to wonder if this movie was attacking conservative Christian values or just trying to elicit shock and awe.It's Christmas time and folks are being murdered. The main setting is a sorority house where there is drinking, cussing, and an open assault upon the idea of virginity (Barb (Margot Kidder) labeled one of the girls a "professional virgin" LOL). Then there is the main character.Jess (Olivia Hussey, who reminds me of Kelly Macdonald (Margaret Thompson in Boardwalk Empire)), is in a committed relationship and she reveals to her boyfriend that she's pregnant and she doesn't want to keep the baby. That is a touchy topic in 2019 so I can only imagine how sensitive and risqué this must have been in 1974.Furthermore, when her beau insists that they get married and keep the baby, she stiff arms him saying that she doesn't want to marry him and she still doesn't want the baby. She doesn't do any of this in an aggressive feminazi way. She is very rational about the whole matter and not the least bit condescending.For such a delicate matter they covered it well. The dichotomy was on full display as she was never seen without a cross pendant around her neck and she was the only one seen enjoying the Christmas carol "O Come All Ye Faithful." In other words, her Christianity was not to be doubted yet marriage was a no and abortion was a yes. But the implication wasn't that marriage would always be a no and abortion would always be a yes. Just at that time in her life it was.As deep and even complicated as this was, this was a side story however while the main story was a maniac killing sorority girls. The main plot thickened and thickened as the police got involved and tried to tighten the dragnet around the killer.I think the movie was well done overall. It clearly wasn't a big budget film, yet they had very good actors and a good screenplay. I was pleasantly surprised by this movie, how it unfolded and how it played out.

This film begins on a college campus with several young ladies making plans to enjoy the holiday season at their sorority. Unknown to them, a man has gained entrance into their sorority house and settled upstairs in the attic. Not long afterward, he kills his first victim named "Claire" (Lynne Griffin) by suffocating her and then propping her dead body up on a nearby rocking chair. Naturally, being quite puzzled by her absence, several members of the sorority go to the police to file a missing person's report. Unfortunately, the desk sergeant "Sergeant Nash" (Douglas McGrath) doesn't take it seriously--and this creates all kinds of problems from that point on. Now, rather than reveal any more, I will just say that, while it certainly didn't have the blood and gore associated with the slasher films of today, it managed to maintain the necessary excitement the old-fashioned way--by utilizing mystery and suspense to keep the viewer interested. So much so that it was nominated for the award of "Best Feature Film" in Canada not long afterward and a Saturn award for "Best Horror Film" a year after that. Likewise, from what I understand, it has also been remade twice--once in 2006 and again in 2019. Be that as it may, I thought that this was a pretty good horror movie and I have rated it accordingly. Above average.

Yet another overrated but this time decent little serial killer flick surrounding girls in a sorority. Margot Kidder is great and this production features "Audra" from Stephen King's made For TV movie, "IT." While this is somewhat entertaining, the direction was horrible, and it is easily one of the most clichéd horrors I've seen.It was not scary, and while it tries to build suspense, the liquor-filled sorority house mother relieved any suspense built, by her antics. There are some really creepy (and humorous) elements in this one, making it better than some, but frankly, I don't see why this film is considered to be a benchmark of the horror genre. It really is not anything special. It is just a mediocre thriller, nothing more. I honestly thought Scream was better. *LOL*3.8/10 from...the Fiend :.

Black Christmas (1974): Dir: Bob Clark / Cast: Olivia Hussey, Kier Dullea, Margot Kidder, John Saxon, Marian Waldman: Canadian slasher where evil makes its presence within a time of year known for being joyous. Billy is never seen but his childish screeching voice can be heard through prank calls to the girls in the fraternity house. One victim is suffocated through clear plastic and left rocking in a chair in the attic while her father arrives searching for her. Bob Clark previously directed Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things but here he is backed with chilling atmosphere and better writing. Olivia Hussey is the central focus and Kier Dullea plays her overbearing boyfriend. She is pregnant but decides on having an abortion. Dullea is a failing and frustrated pianist who is against Hussey having an abortion. Dullea is also chief suspect for the murders as well. Other personalities emerge including the lovely Margot Kidder in a drunken spree spewing comedic disrespect to all who will listen. Her murder scene amongst swan and unicorn ornaments is a highlighted stylish scenes. John Saxon plays the police chief whose staff provide comic moments. Marian Waldman also provides comic moments as the house mom at the fraternity house. She is crass and seems to have liquor stashed everywhere. Pointless heartbreak that no one need to live through but viewers will enjoy experiencing. Score: 8 / 10

Move over, Halloween! The scariest holiday is now Christmas. Coming a few years before John Carpenter turned trick 'r treating into a night of horror, Bob Clark told a similar story about an unknown psychopath killing sorority sisters and leaving them terrifying obscene phone calls as the police tries to track him down. It's boasts a likable and strong cast featuring the likes of Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, Andrea Martin, and John Saxon who keep everything grounded and increasing the horror around them.

Whilst I was continuing on anti-Xmas crusade what better movie then to cap of the festive celebration with none other than Black Christmas. I bought the DVD a while back ago assuming that it was the 2006 version but by looking at the trailer thank god I got the original version and not the 2006 teen trashy version! Not much over here that is new but you can that a movie like this was the one that would set the 'rules' for future horror movies and slasher flicks. The movie goes straight into the action and does not waste in any time , although it does tend to drift off in a few places the good part was that we introduced to a tense atmospheric moment which but the tone right again. There also some genuine creepy moments that stand out and the odd funny moment here and there . There are also good uses of camera which helps dramatically to its quality and really make this movie stick out. Olivia Hussey was undoubtedly the star of the show but having said that Margot Kidder was amusing and John Saxon's performance was worthy as well. To conclude although Black Christmas did not exactly make my skin crawl , it did however jump out moments and also the fact that it annoyed some bible thumping Evangelical watching this makes me more happy as I hate Christmas and this movie just feels like a kick in the balls to old Santa, one definitely for horror movie fans who can do with some decent horror during this 'cheerful' holiday.BLACK Christmas: 6.8 OUT 10IF THIS MOVIE DOES NOT MAKE YOUR SKIN CRAWL ... THEN IT IS ON TOO TIGHT.

This movie is great on so many aspects. It sounds like a unoriginal slasher but this movie is unique different than any other slasher, and the movie itself is what started slasher movies. The soundtrack is great, the shots are amazing, the characters are good and likeable and aren't as dumb as a rock like in most horror movies. The deaths are brutal and creative. The movie has some great turns and twists it takes, and left me guessing, and the end reveal and is amazing and the end shot to the credits is one of the greatest movie endings of all time. This is a true masterpiece and is criminally underrated. MASTERPIECE 10/10.

reviews.review_title: The calls are coming from inside the house
reviews.content: I caught some of the movie on a movie channel and then again free on a streaming service with commercials. The film is quite a good horror film without it being too obvious. The ending is ambivalent to viewers. The cast is first rate. The story about an unseen killer adds to the suspense. This film doesn't overdue for the audience. There are a few laughs along the way. Marion Waldman who played the house mother was quite good and should have been utilized more as a character actress. Margot kidder was quite good as drunk Barb. Olivia Hussey was great as Jess. Keir Dullea played Peter. A young Andrea Martin played Phyllis. The film is smarter than most of today's horror movies. We begin to care about the characters as well. John Saxon was also excellent as the policeman leading the investigation. Of horror films, this one is a must see to your collection. It does leave you wanting to know more.

reviews.review_title: Effective and stylish North American giallo: much more than just a proto-slasher!
reviews.content: This movie mixes elements of humour with psychological thriller and Italian giallo to produce a film that is both tense, harrowing and grimly satisfying.The girls at a sorority house preparing for the Christmas holidays become the target of a menacing crank caller (the content of whose calls is genuinely creepy and disturbing). In a shocking moment, one girl is murdered early on and left undiscovered in the house: an enduring and sorrowful image that the film returns to frequently throughout its duration. In a way, this is a comedy of errors - the comedy being extremely black in this case - as parents, friends and police fail to spot the clues right under their noses whilst further murders are carried out.Innovative and impactful use of camera angles, POV shots and editing really heightens the tension and terror as the film reaches its pivotal conclusion and the movie ends on a sickeningly ironic twist that leaves a lingering mood.Go out of your way to see this - especially at Christmas for added chills!

Scary thriller with an emphasis on ugly murders. A killer is hiding up in the attic of a sorority house during the snowy Christmas season. Who is it? Who will be next to die? Bob Clark directed--seemingly taking delight in the film's gruesome details--however, his priority is an atmosphere fraught with tension, and this he accomplishes with tight editing, appropriately grainy photography, realistic locations and a most interesting cast. The memorably stark finale is so straight-forward, it takes almost a few seconds to sink in. Not a fun night at the movies, but not-bad for the genre. ** from ****

reviews.review_title: I'm dreaming of a... well, it's a nightmare, actually.
reviews.content: Considered by many to be the first true 'slasher' (although 'Peeping Tom (1960)', 'Psycho (1960)', 'A Bay Of Blood (1971)' and 'The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)' preceded it), 'Black Christmas (1974)' certainly provided plenty of inspiration for genre filmmakers (including John Carpenter) in the years following its release. For the most part, the movie plays out as a mystery with elements of a psychological thriller. It sees the members of a sorority house harassed with obscene phone calls and picked off one by one by an unseen killer. The film is really good at getting you to engage with its enigma, trying to guess who the killer may be while wondering when he is going to strike again. This is a large part of why the picture is as successful as it is, even if it is relatively slow between its more intense sequences. It's genuinely rather suspenseful at times and its madman's maniacal screaming is actually somewhat upsetting. The protagonist is absolutely iconic and the film's attitude towards sex and abortion is wonderfully ahead of its time. It all builds to a brilliantly ambiguous finale that really does get under your skin, leaving you craving closure and callously refusing to provide even an ounce of it. It's a fantastic way to end the experience. Overall, the movie is suspenseful, unsettling, engaging and entertaining. Its restrained use of violence is surprisingly effective and one of its most shocking images - a manic eye peering out from the shadows - is still burned in my memory. It gets better every time I watch it. It's easily one of the best slasher movies ever made; it's easily one of the best Christmas movies ever made; it's easily one of the best movies ever made. 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Bob Clark's game-changing slasher is also a great Christmas movie!
reviews.content: The second instalment of my (diminishing) 'Shitty Christmas' film selections, not only is the late Bob Clark's Black Christmas a perfectly mean spirited holiday movie, it's a highly influential horror.It's the week before Christmas break at a quaint American college campus. With red wine being sloshed and chestnuts roasting on an open fire, the festivities turn fearsome when a killer is let loose inside a sorority house. With each of the female tenants meeting their timely fate, it's up to damsel in distress Jess (Olivia Hussey) to put her abortion debate with boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea) aside, and catch the killer herself.I love Black Christmas. Even if time hasn't aged it well, it's still the perfect remedy of genuine scares and humorous bravado, without ever being trashy or pastiche. It's great fun to spot the standardised tropes we've all become used to in horror movies. And wow, there are so many here including horny young girls, implausible 'don't go in there!' plot points, seven absurd fatalities, melodrama screams and glimmers of German expressionism, maniacal phone calls, a stoic detective, an Oedipally complex serial killer and, best of all, Carl Zittrer's clamorous score which comines distorted sound of cutlery clanging together and ominous analogue synths.Alongside all this genuinely nuevo scares, horrophiles will relish in spotting the homages Bob Clark fits into the movie, with callbacks' to the POV killings from Michael Powell's Peeping Tom, psychoanalytical paranoia stemming from Hitchcock's handbook, and the same eerie claustrophobia as Robert Siodmak's fantastic 1945 mystery The Spiral Staircase.Far from formulaic, Bob Clark's Black Christmas is the precursor to the Slasher sub-genre it would spawn, and it's still better than most of it's derivations today. Like John Carpenter's Halloween, with added eggnog. Great stuff!Read more and watch it here: http://366movies.com/2012/12/15/349black/

A group of sorority girls are preparing themselves for the holiday season, but there festival spirits are short lived when suddenly they're plagued by a prude caller making obscene comments and later the next morning one of the girls have gone missing. Worried about the girl, her father and her friends go to the police for help and the detective involved discovers that maybe the girls' disappearance, a murder of a child and that of the obscene phone calls share a common interest.I remember when I use to think that Halloween was the begin all and end all of slashers and even to a extend horror films. Though, that was up until I discovered this Canadian little gem. Well, this has got to be one of my favourite horror films I've come across and I finally got around to updating my video copy to that of DVD. It's one of a few horror flicks that still are able to raise goosebumps whenever I watch it.Simply this is an old-fashion horror tale working with atmospheric subtleness and conjuring up such a sombre mood, where it's exhausting in its slow-building suspense. You might think that it all sounds familiar and it sure does, as you could class this as a blueprint for the slasher genre. Yes, before 'Halloween' was even thought up this film was setting up the trend to come, just that 'Halloween' was advertised better than 'Black Christmas' and from that pick up momentum in its popularity. It was one of the first films to cook up these standard clichés and stereotypes you find in these movies. But when compared with most in its field this story will rather deal with atmosphere than violence, and that didn't bother me because director Bob Clark did a sensational job in keeping this slow-burner genuinely gripping with many effectively memorable scenes. The violence is rather timid and implied with little blood, therefore it goes for a psychological imprint by leaving in up to your imagination to picture what happened off screen, although there are two deaths we do see, which stand out in a very stylistic manner. Actually a lot of things are left up in the air, leaving you to use your own insight to come up with the answers and images. Sometimes the uncertainty of the outlook can work against you, but here it seems to fit in neatly. I thought the whole ambiguity of our killer (we don't even see him and there's no motive) and that of the ending goes down well, but it's one of those ones you'll like or be totally disappointed with.The customary plot focus basically that of a few collage students where we learn some elements (the abortion issue) that drive the motivation factor that's formed around its murder-mystery tone. I really wouldn't say it's a straight-forward stalk and slash film, because the mystery of the disappearance, murders and the obscene phone calls seem to level out instead of focusing on one particular aspect. This helped woven a nice dose of reality to the situation and characters. Now what does take front stage, are definitely the blood-curdling phones in a perversely harassing manner. The jittery voice(s) and the lurid context being said over the phone are intensely unnerving. It might build on its high-strung suspense, but the in the script there's a nice amount of amusing dark humour that's worked in with great timing. The character's interactions and perks are believable and the chemistry amongst them was more than sound. The performances were great (there's no bad exceptions) with each one fitting their roles perfectly. I would even go to say that there wasn't a weak character in the main leads, as they all had their own complexities and contain strong personalities. Margot Kidder stands out as alcoholic lout Barbie and you've got the also impressive John Saxon as the more than competent Lieutenant Kenneth Fuller. Olivia Hussey is gorgeous as the concerned, but strong-willed Jessica and Keir Dullea nails down her irrational boyfriend Peter.Director Clark draws tightly such a dreaded mood with the wintry backdrop and within that of the almost empty and bleakly lit sorority house. The dark presence of this house just takes you out of your comfort zone with its hidden layers. There's prominent work in the camera placement that moves well with the sweeping shadows roaming the house and the POV shots are eerily staged to perfection with the constant heavy breathing backing it up. They provide some quite inventive shots, as there's a lot of movement going on in the panning and frame shots. The chilling but underplayed piano score knows when to make the sudden whispers turn into quick rush of terror and the sound effects played a big part by chiming with preciseness to make you feel hellishly uneasy. Even when it's dead silent with only the ruffling winds it still succeeds in stamping a terrifying mark. It's clearly a dynamic catalyst of the genre! A truly stark and quite stylish horror film that gets under your skin by suffocating you with a heavy blanket of menace. Highly recommended!

I'm not sure why people keep saying 'Black Christmas' is the first slasher movie. Clearly, the films 'Bay of Blood' and 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre' we're both released first. Not to mention the fact that all slasher films owe a great deal to Hitchcock's 'Psycho'.That being said, Bob Clark is a skilled director, and this film is one of the better films in the slasher genre. Minimal gore, strong acting, and Andrea Martin help separate this film from the million other slashers that would be released in the late 70s and 80s.

The grandfather of slasher films we know today all started with 1974's Black Christmas. Set during everyone's favourite time of the year, Black Christmas takes a total 180 approach on a usual upbeat holiday and makes it dark and mysterious. This film may have introduced the first person killer camera angle which has since been done better by recent films. The other camera angels are also well done and you can tell a lot of work went into that. The movie also uses a lot of phone calls that come with profound language and suspenseful leads (Sounds like Scream, right?). Lastly, I like how the killer is always kept a mystery. We don't truly know exactly who the killer is and we never visibly see the person.As much as I like the novelty behind this movie, I can say for certain that Black Christmas is INCREDIBLY boring. You will not believe how many scenes drag, how long we focus way too much on the police officers and the investigation of the murders, the killings are slow and unimaginable, and the dialogue will put you asleep standing up. The build-up to the climatic parts of the movie, which is basically the last 15 mins, isnt worth the trouble to sit through.Olivia Hussey eventually becomes the main character after it's not really determined who our main lead is at the beginning. She clearly acted well and did her part and she's absolutely stunning, but I feel her performance was wasted.Black Christmas has seemingly become buried in time. With some cool horror elements that have been copy and pasted into other horror franchises and a bar that was set for future horror movie directors, the unique history and nostalgia behind Black Christmas is undeniably intriguing. But as a movie of its own, Black Christmas mostly flops, and that is why I lead to believe that this film has been lost in time and why, for example, hasn't resonated with a younger crowd, or hasn't had too much of a cult following (not denying there's a cult following, because I do believe there is one but it's minimal in size).If you're a history of horror buff or wanting to learn more about it then take notes from Black Christmas, but be warned, this movie is awfully slow paced and it'll take a lot of patience to sit through the dialogue and suspense.

Black Christmas (1974)
Directed by Bob ClarkYou'll stab your eye out with a random hook in the attic kid. That's right. Bob Clark made two great Christmas films. One the perennial classic A Christmas Story and the other the birth of the modern slasher film, Black Christmas.Forget Jessy. That's no fun. Truly, it makes no sense as well. That being said.Synopsis: a sorority house including Jess (Olivia Hussey), Barb (Margot Kidder), Phil (Andrea Martin), Claire (Lynne Griffin) and the liquor hiding Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) is unwittingly housing a home invader. All the other characters are possible suspects that must be stopped before the last girl is threatened.My first experience with this film was a few years ago after I told a friend that slashers are the lowest rung of the horror ladder. Then I watched this one, and claim it as my favorite slasher film. Truly the film, or my investigation through the journey of the film changes every viewing. Who did it? The only other film that changes each time I view it is The Thing. Bob Clark is a better director than given credit as he has two films aforementioned that are quintessential repeat viewers.Who did it? That's the game. But where did Mrs Mac hide the booze should be a drinking game.

reviews.review_title: Serial killer and a Sorority - before panty shots were the norm
reviews.content: It's Christmas break, but there's a serial killer terrorizing a college sorority. First there are the crank calls. Then he starts killing. This is a horror movie from Bob Clark who would be better known later for 'A Christmas Story', and the Porky's franchise. He's certainly much better in comedies than horror. He doesn't have the touch to juice up the intensity. This movie is far too slow. The kills have limited shock value.The den mother is boozy Mrs Mac. Margot Kidder plays the brash Barb. Olivia Hussey plays the pregnant Jess who's considering abortion. Andrea Martin plays Phyl. When they report a missing girl, the police is unconcerned, busy with a missing 13 year old girl named Janice Quaife. However Lt Fuller (John Saxon) soon realizes that there is something wrong going on.When a modern horror movie of a serial killer in a sorority, it's expected to have hot young co-eds strutting around in their panties. This was before that all started. It does have some modern touches like a killer's POV. But the lack of editing and its slow pace do hold it back. I consider it a transition piece that don't quite measure up to its more scary compatriots.

Hussey and various other girls are living in a gorgeous snow covered sorority house getting reading to leave college for Christmas. One of them goes missing and it is soon clear that a killer is on the loose.Predating the more famous Halloween by 4 years, this is generally now acknowledged to be the first slasher movie and a cracking one, worthy of Hitchcock himself. The humour is wonderful and dark, the killer is a really nasty piece of work, the cast - Kidder, Dullea, Hindle and particularly the great John Saxon are on fine form. Above all this is a genuinely nerve tingling and a good police thriller that maintains a strong pervasive sense of fear and evil at Christmas - whilst still oddly feeling very Christmassy. Watch it on Christmas Eve.

So, for my expectations going into this, I didn't know what to expect, but I knew my expectations were high. I heard so many good things about Black Christmas that I hoped it would be at least good. Aside from knowing the general plot and knowing what happens in the 2006, and 2019 remakes (watched the killcounts) I had no clue what was going to happen in the story, and I'm happy I didn't know much, because the story here is very unpredictable, but I'll get more into that soon. So, all in all, my expectations were high, but not unreasonably high. Luckily, I can safely say that Black Christmas succeeded by expectations greatly.The plot for Black Christmas is basic, no doubt, but nonetheless, is still very effective. The basic plot is that a sorority house gets creepy and obscene phone calls while one the members of said sorority goes missing. Sounds pretty basic right? Well, that's because it is, but as I say every time I review a movie with a basic plot, a simple plot does not immediately equal bad or uninteresting. While I tend to enjoy movies that have more complex plots, I don't instantly dislike a movie if the story is simple. Black Christmas utilizes its simple story and creates an incredibly effective psychological thriller with it. Black Christmas does a great job at showing what the main characters are doing, and what the Caller is doing, and doing this creates a extremely strong sense of paranoia, which will stick with the viewer until the movie ends. I'll say this now, I don't count Black Christmas as a horror movie, or a slasher, which is how many people think of it when they hear the name "Black Christmas". But the phone calls are genuinely disturbing and haunting. The phone calls are spread out through the movie, which creates a sense of dread every time that damn phone rings. Each phone call is mentally taxing and by doing this, the viewer can relate to the main character, Jess, and understand they're point of view of the situation. The ending is the part I'm most mixed on, but it didn't ruin it for me, or even make me take off any points. I like the mystery and the fact that they never explain who the Caller is, but I would have liked to have known what went down at the end. We are left to wonder what happened, and I don't know if I like that, especially when you put that on top of the fact that the Caller's identity remains unknown. While the latter part isn't bad, mixing the two unknown aspects just feels like they didn't want to bother with answering questions, but this is a nitpick for me.The characters are some of the best I've seen in this genre. Everyone is likeable (aside from Barb) and, unlike most thrillers/slashers, you don't care if someone dies because everyone, aside from the final girl, is always a bad person in someway. But even the side characters I didn't want to die. And Jess was a great final girl, who felt very realistic and was easy to root for throughout the movie. A praise I can give for every character, likeable or not, is the fact that everyone feels so realistic and down to earth. All the decisions made feel real and like what the characters in this situation would actually do. I also have to give the writer praise, the way comedy relief is woven into the story is buttery smooth. The comedy relief doesn't feel out of place or unfunny, almost every joke lands, and even when it doesn't, it doesn't come off as desperate or cringeworthy. Imagine if when Jess hangs up the phone after an obscene phone call, she says, "So, that just happened." Man that would be terrible but also so funny.The cinematography is amazing. Even Black Christmas is 48 years old, it still holds up visually. I don't think I was watching a remastered version or anything like that, the entire atmosphere starts off feeling cozy and Christmassy, but soon devolves into paranoia, fear, and an overall feeling of feeling unsafe. Aside from the great atmosphere, most of the shots just look good. I love the first person shots with the Caller.Even though the cinematography still holds up, what about some other aspects? Starting off with the acting. A movie like this, you would expect to have bad acting. A low budget horror film from the early 70s? That doesn't sound like it will end well, but wow, the acting here is actually really good! There were no bad performances, and while the characters were written realistically, the actors also played them incredibly well, and helped bring out that writing. The only part that doesn't hold up as well, but also does at the same time, is the sound design. I LOVE the sound design. The creaking of the house, the slamming of the doors, just everything, but you can tell the movie is old when you hear the sound design. Lots of sounds sound edited in, and you can tell because the sounds that aren't edited in, suddenly become quiet and then become loud again. This isn't too common though and does not take away from the experience.Overall, I loved Black Christmas. A classic for sure, and a masterpiece in tension. So many scenes had me on the edge of my seat, which a lot of movies can't do to me. I do agree that this is a Christmas movie and Halloween movie at the same time. I think the rewatch value here is high because I already feel like I could rewatch it. I highly recommend you check this out. Especially if you are a big horror fan because this is basically a must watch, but it's also great for those who are new to horror, or just like watching a horror movie every now and then.

Really scary film with one scene near the end (hair is a clue for those who have seen this movie) that when I saw it in the theater had almost everyone jump out of their seats screaming. Well crafted claustophobic mood as one by one the college coeds are murdered on Christmas Eve in their soriorty house. The voice of the killer on the phone once heard can never be forgotten. Ending is really very different and disturbing. Recommended.

reviews.review_title: The greatest and most refreshing and unique horror film of all time
reviews.content: This movie is great on so many aspects. It sounds like a unoriginal slasher but this movie is unique different than any other slasher, and the movie itself is what started slasher movies. The soundtrack is great, the shots are amazing, the characters are good and likeable and aren't as dumb as a rock like in most horror movies. The deaths are brutal and creative. The movie has some great turns and twists it takes, and left me guessing, and the end reveal and is amazing and the end shot to the credits is one of the greatest movie endings of all time. This is a true masterpiece and is criminally underrated. MASTERPIECE 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Black Christmas decorates traditional festivities with blood, suffocation and disturbing phone calls.
reviews.content: Ho! Ho! Ho! Merry Christmas! And have a slashin' good time! The slasher sub-genre was most proficient during the mid-to-late 70s, with 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre', 'Halloween' and a plethora of spicy Argento features to add a worldly aesthetic. However, one film that innovated the tropes and traits commonly found in the aforementioned titles, was Bob Clark's Black Christmas. A horror "slasher" (if you can classify it as that...) where an anonymous serial killer remains secluded in a sorority house, gradually picking off the girls one by one. Just in time for Santa to come down that warmly lit chimney and deliver them coffins wrapped up in cute little bows.To say that Black Christmas was revolutionary and a blooded sprout for the blossoming sub-genre to come, would be an understatement. A nameless unknown killer that exhumes mental instability? Check. An expendable cast of characters that stupidly investigate ominous sounds by themselves? Check. Excruciating tension with every camera movement? Absolutely! Surprisingly, now that I've witnessed various films during the conception of a horror movement, it's incredibly easy to see how influential Black Christmas is. Not for its innovative concept, as other simpler thrillers utilise slashing techniques with efficiency ('Psycho'), but rather for its technical proficiency.Clark's direction, whilst unpolished, is solid throughout. Taut camera pans to explore the darkened hallways of the sorority house. Minimal sound editing to heighten the suspense. Excellent use of shadows to illustrate the antagonist's anonymity. Sublime POV perspective to place the viewer in the shoes of the killer. And a ramped up conclusive act that will have anyone watching perched on the edge of their seats eagerly anticipating to unwrap the plot twist, even if that narrative turn was predictable from the offset. The camera can be visible on specific occasions, mostly through reflections in picture frames as it glides through hallways. Emphasising that unrefined quality of Clark's novice-like direction. It does give the feature some flavour, perhaps not the jolly festivities one was yearning for. More egg nog than champagne.Yet what really injected some holiday spirit into the story, were the characters. Uniquely all acquiring a distinguishable personality that made them different and relatable. The shady drunk friend or the intellectual gal who has all the common sense (that is until she goes wandering by herself...!). The point is, they were all memorable, and that's a rare achievement in slashers. The second act, where the campus police become involved, does stagnate the overall pace with minimal storytelling momentum. Fortunately the third act immediately picks it back up for an explosive bauble of...slashing.So despite the lack of actual slashing, overall unrefined quality and inconsistent pacing, it's an extremely enjoyable horror flick that takes a gentle holiday season and turns it into a crazy murder-sesh. Perhaps my new annual Christmas film? We'll see...! I am sadistic after all!

Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, Keir Dullea, Andrea Martin and John Saxon star in this 1974 horror film. This takes place during Christmas time where a mysterious psychopath who calls himself, Billy sneaks into a sorority house and stalks the residents. Hussey (Romeo and Juliet) plays Jess, a young girl who begins getting unsettling phone calls from him and is also having trouble with her boyfriend, Peter (Dullea). Kidder (Superman) plays Barb, her alcoholic friend, Martin plays her other friend, Phyl and Saxon (A Nightmare on Elm Street) plays police Lieutenant, Fuller. This is a good horror/slasher flick with a decent cast, ominous score and it's one of the only films where the killer's identity is never revealed. I recommend this to any horror fan.

7/10 - after not enjoying the weird sci-fi element of the 2019 remake and in search of another great holiday flick (alongside Better Watch Out), I decided to check out one of the most influential slashers of all-time which had lots to love, but still felt a little stilted in some ways (so close, but so far from really hitting something truly fantastic)

Bloodless (but spooky) film about a killer in the house. The murderer kills sorority girls one by one, makes obscene phone calls and trips everyone out. Although it is now format and doesn't seem very eventful, keep in mind the year it was made (it pre-dates Halloween from 1978) and just watch.  It's extremely scary and the phone calls are pretty over the top

reviews.review_title: I loved this morbid BLACK CHRISTMAS .
reviews.content:
Lonely sorority sisters who are having a Christmas party in their sorority house during the Christmas break.
Peter (Keir Dullea) is a mad-killer who terrorizes the women by making threatening telephone calls. As the body count mounts.Directed by the director of A Christmas Story. So he made an excellent Christmas horror/slasher flick 9 years before A Christmas Story Awesome And the movie is excellent as well. Kidder's performance of the drunken, outspoken Barb is fantastic, followed closely by Romeo & Juliet's Olivia Hussey, who is truly beautiful in this movie. The camera work and direction is first rate, the first person perspective, heavy breathing effect. There were times that I felt the tension of the girls and I wondered what would happen next. I was genuinely uneasy. Creepy AF . I loved this morbid BLACK CHRISTMAS .

I've heard and read great things about this movie. Some people even implied it invented the genre, before Halloween did. I disagree. It's more of a thriller than a slasher. And it is so slow and boring you don't get into it. Even during the « death scenes ». Where nothing is clear and everything is suggested, only in a very confusing and obscure way. I had a hard time taking it seriously. This and the chatty dialogues dragged the movie down. The ending gave a sense of eeriness, but it was far too late. Not a movie I plan on rewatching, and probably stick with that 2006 remake. At least there was some action.

This film is one that I'll admit, I really did care for the first couple times that I've seen it. I don't want to make it sound like I hated the film, but it just wasn't one that really hit me. When I saw that it was playing at my local theater, I decided that I would check it out on the big screen to see if that altered my thoughts. The synopsis is during their Christmas break, a group of sorority girls are stalked by a stranger.We start out inside of a sorority house in college. Christmas is right around the corner and the winter break is starting. They're having a party and a good time going on inside. We then see someone stalking outside of the house. They climb up the side and enter into the attic through a window.Inside we see that one of the sisters, Barb (Margot Kidder), notices that the front door is open. She closes and goes back to the party. The other sisters are Jess (Olivia Hussey), Phyl (Andrea Martin) and Clare Harrison (Lynne Griffin). Barb has a bit of a drinking problem. There's a phone call for her and it's her mother who scolds her for drinking too. She tells her that she can't do the original plans and invites her and her sisters to come skiing. Everyone agrees except for Clare. Barb and her do not get along as Clare is more reserved. She calls her out for being a virgin and Clare goes to her room.The phone then rings and they have been getting prank called by someone who does heavy breathing and says some inappropriate things. Barb calls the person out this time and he yells some things are her. The house mother, Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) then shows up. She has bottles of alcohol hidden throughout the house and takes drinks whenever she can, which is quite funny.Clare plays with the house cat in her room while packing and hears something in the closet. The crazy person is in there and he attacks her. He kills her with a plastic bag and pulls her up into the attic. It should be pointed out that he sets her up in a rocking chair with a baby in her arm right in front of a window. He rocks her as well as speaks with her, but we don't get a good look at him.Clare's father, Mr. Harrison (James Edmond) arrives the next day to collect her. She doesn't show up to where they're supposed to meet. He's not very happy with what he is seeing from her sorority sisters, Mrs. Mac or the place that she is living. He also says that he didn't send her to college to drink and be loose.Jess then goes to see her boyfriend, Peter (Keir Dullea). The night before she called him and he was short with her. He lives in a conservatory and he wants to be a concert pianist, so he doesn't get a lot of sleep as he practices a lot. He has a big performance later that day. Jess drops on him that she is pregnant, but she is going to have an abortion. This upsets him that she made this decision without him and he wants to change her mind. She doesn't want to hear it thoughClare is not at the Christmas Party and this makes Mr. Harrison quite upset. They go to the police, but they won't do anything at first. It isn't until her boyfriend, Chris Hayden (Art Hindle) comes down to the throw a fit that Lt. Ken Fuller (John Saxon) gets involved. There's a 13 year old girl who goes missing around this time as well. A search results in a grisly discovery and Jess reports the obscene phone calls to the police. This leads them to tapping the phone so they can trace where the calls are coming from. It leads to quite a shocking discovery as we see other members of this house fall victim to this madman.I can say, much like how I felt after my second viewing, I do enjoy this film more and more with each viewing. After my second viewing I did know that this film is interesting is that it is regarded as influencing Halloween. There was almost consideration of making more horror films around holidays like this. Something I have to give this film is that basing it around Christmas is great. You have students going away for the holidays or just going home for them, so people can go missing and no one notices it.The killer in this film is quite creepy as well. The prank calls he is making are quite unnerving if I'm going to be perfectly honest. What I find interesting is the remake uses the things he says in this one to expand the story of the film for that one. I almost like that we never really figure out why some of things are said or who the names correlate to. I do like that he incorporates conversations from the house though, because it points to Peter as the prime suspect.I've heard debates whether this film is a slasher or if it is proto-slasher. There aren't very many kills in this one. They're spaced out quite a bit and it really focuses more on the mystery of who is doing it. That almost makes it feel more like a giallo. The issue then becomes though the ending of the movie. I don't want to spoil it, but that doesn't really mesh with how those films normally end. This does give us quite a bit of police procedural.There are still some glaring issues with this film for me though. The first is how no one discovers the body of Clare. She is positioned right in front of a window and we shown that you can see her from the street. I get there could be frost on the window, but at the end of the film, no one checks the attic. This is just kind of laughable to me after everything that goes down. The next issue I have will be with the pacing.I've already kind of touched on this. I just feel this film is a bit boring. It gets right into it, we get our introductions to the characters and the first murder is right there within the first 15 minutes. We do go through quite a bit of a lull before anything else happens. I like the investigation aspect of trying to find the missing girl. We just get a lot of drama aspects and kind of shy away from the horror for just a bit too long. I do think that the film does find its way and builds tension, but just some lulls I have issues with.The acting of the film is good. I absolutely love Hussey. She is quite young in this film, but I love her determination here. This film is actually ahead of its time here as she is a modern woman that is going to abort her pregnancy because she isn't ready for motherhood yet. This is actually very relevant now and she won't be told what to do by Peter. Dullea I think is good and it is interesting, because he really shows us toxic masculinity. I get part of it is the time this film came out, but that doesn't change it. Kidder is solid as the drunk and actually brings some good humor, the same with Waldman. It was fun seeing Saxon and Hindle in this film. I think that the rest of the cast really do round out the film for what was needed as well.I'll move next to the effects of the film. To be honest, they really aren't a lot of them as they do hide quite a bit. I do like the look of Clare after she's been killed. The blood in the film is a bit orange, but I chalk that up to being the era of the film. Mrs. Mac's death is also pretty cool as well. I'd say that overall, they were done practically and look fine to me.Now with that said, I give this film a lot of respect for its significance and its place in history. My rating does seem to be keep coming up with every viewing I have of it, so that is it too. I like the idea of this film, but I would have liked them to go a bit farther. I don't need everything explained, I just like more than what we got. It does get a bit boring as it focuses on some things that can bog it down. The climax and ending are good. The acting really does carry the film and the depth of the main characters is still socially relevant. It is a bit light on the effects, but they're done practically so that really does help. The soundtrack of the film really doesn't stand out, the Christmas music does set the mood of the time of year. I do think that this is a good movie and actually, it does have some socially commentary that is relevant. I would recommend this even if you don't like horror as it is has a good mystery.

I've got to admit, that I'm not into mindless slashers that much. If they're nicely made and or have great death scenes, they can be "fun" though! This one of the first slashers though and it seems like other slasher movies, have a lot to be thankful for, concerning boundary breaking ideas! Having said that, you have to feel free to enjoy a movie with no plot whatsoever, with girls (victims) on a Christmas day and a killer on the loose. That's all you get (plus a few death scenes of course) and if that's you're cup of tea, why not watch this movie and see how they did it in the 70s. Much better than the remake then!

reviews.review_title: A Moody, Efficient Time Capsule of Holiday Horror
reviews.content: Plagued by dirty phone calls, a houseful of rowdy sorority girls barks back at the perpetrator and prepares for the holiday break, unaware that a psychotic killer looms in the attic. When one sister goes missing, local police don't give the case much thought until it's almost too late.Written and directed by Bob Clark (who would, amusingly, go on to direct the perennial holiday classic A Christmas Story almost a decade later), Black Christmas is an efficient, low budget proto-slasher with a nice blend of character moments, tension-breaking humor and moody suspense. Rather than observing in fist-balled terror from a distance, the audience takes a direct, active role in the murders thanks to an persistent hand-held, killer's-eye perspective during the bloodiest scenes. While an obvious gimmick, this approach does add a unique dimension to the screen and lends the killings an intimate, face-to-face quality that feels different to its many peers and imitators.The cast is surprisingly human and relatable for the genre, from the most experienced players (Margot Kidder as a wise-cracking, foul-mouthed lush) to the relative rookies (first-timer Lynne Griffin, whose last suffocated gasp is pictured on all the promo materials), and tackles a number of social taboos between all the stabbings. The creepy phone calls still hold their own, too, a powerful reminder of just how invasive and personal an intimidating voice could feel in the days before voicemail or caller ID.

Not the kind of Christmas you want to dream about, unless you're a sadist. This little slasher movie that could kind of/sort of kicked off the genre. And it's Canadian! And almost exclusively set in a sorority house. The movie features performances by Margot Kidder, Keir Dullea (2001: A Space Odyssey), Olivia Hussey (Romeo and Juliet), Andrea Martin (SCTV), and crusty cop John Savage. Although it provides a blueprint for many lesser films to follow, Black Christmas also succeeds because it never once explains why people are being killed. Nothing about motive or rationale, just plain old death. Well shot, too - there are numerous long tracking shots, of which I'm definitely a fan. Was almost called Silent Night, Evil Night because producers were worried people would think it was actually a blaxploitation movie. I enjoyed pretty much every aspect of this Bob Clark feature - between his Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things and A Christmas Story, and come to think of it, it's kind of a cross between those two.

reviews.review_title: Remade again and again, imitated one film after another, Black Christmas still holds its own
reviews.content:
A provocative and well acted thriller, Black Christmas is not only original and well executed, but timelessly clever and quite fun to watch. I'll start with the films flaws, as there isn't much of them. I never found the film to be super entertaining in anyway, there are a few dull moments. However, it is very easy and engaging to watch, as the mystery at hands become more and more interesting as the film plays out. The film can be a bit tough to follow at times as well, as there are quite a few things going on at once, but perhaps the biggest flaw of the film is also something relatively small, that being the sound quality. Its irritating at times how loud it can be and how quiet it can be at other times. I'm not entirely sure if it is the quality of the film itself, or the film quality due to the streaming provider I watched it on, but a remastered version would be nice. Besides that, the film is quite smart. It isn't like other horror films at its time, not like the ones it is claimed to inspire. This is not a slasher film, contrary to what many believe, though it does serve as an inspiration for them. What this film has going for it though that other films that imitated it lacked, is the sense of psychological horror that it had going for it, and the unsureness of it all, which I always find quite brilliant. The cinematography is quite good, and very nostalgic, and the acting in it is quite good as well. Standouts for me would have to be first Margot Kidder as Barb, who provides an incredibly underrated performance, Olivia Hussey, John Saxon, Marian Waldman, and Keir Dullea. In the end, Black Christmas is a shining star among 70's horror, and despite it being nearly half a century old, it still remains to be frightening even today.
My Rating: 9.25/10

reviews.review_title: An important precursor to the slasher genre
reviews.content: Before violent holiday horror movies like John Carpenter's "Halloween" and Sean Cunningham's "Friday the 13th" hit theaters and shocked audiences and critics alike, there was "Black Christmas" which combined key ingredients that only a few years later were fully developed in "Halloween." Some trademark slasher elements in "Black Christmas" include extended POV shots from the killer's perspective, a string of bloody murders using a variety of sharp instruments and of course, the familiar climax involving a confrontation between the killer and the final girl. It's important to note that "Black Christmas" also acts as a precursor to phone horror movies like "When a Stranger Calls" and "Scream" where the killer stalks and harasses their victims with obscene phone calls.As a horror movie, "Black Christmas" has aged remarkably well where the disturbed killer is a terrifying and mostly unseen presence whose deadly stalking skills rival that of Michael Myers from "Halloween." Like "Halloween", the film contains a number of jumpscares that are effective, even today. A film like "Black Christmas" is highly recommended for fans of slasher movies and film buffs who want to learn more about the fundamentals of the slasher genre which can be traced all the way back to the early 60's with Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho" and Michael Powell's "Peeping Tom." While "Halloween" tends to be regarded as the first official slasher film of its kind, it's important to note that Halloween's formula derived its trademark elements from previous horror films like "Black Christmas" before taking full shape in "Halloween."
