This film was promoted in 1974 with the tagline "If this picture doesn't make your skin crawl, it's on too tight!", and practically wrote the rulebook for all future slasher scary movies, including Halloween (released four years later). It was only because of the 2019 remake coming up that I thought to watch this 1974 original again, and I'm glad I did, directed by Bob Clark (Porky's, A Christmas Story, Baby Geniuses, Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2). Basically, during the Christmas holidays, an unseen and disoriented man climbs up into the attic of a sorority house. One of the sorority sisters, Jess (Death on the Nile's Olivia Hussey), answers an obscene phone call from a mentally unstable man. It is implied that the caller has been calling the house regularly, other girls gather as the voice (Nick Mancuso) screams and curses them on the phone. Foul-mouthed Barb (Superman's Margot Kidder) takes the phone from Jess, she provokes the caller, who in turn threatens to kill her. Clare Harrison argues with Barb, she is worried that the caller could be a serial rapist. While in her bedroom packing for Christmas break, the stranger lures Clare into the closet, where she is suffocated by a plastic bag, and her dead body is placed on a chair in the attic. The following morning, Mr. Harrison (James Edmond) arrives at the school to pick up his daughter, but she does not show up at their agreed meeting place. At the sorority house, the housemother, Mrs. "Mac" MacHenry (Marian Waldman), is surprised by Clare's absence. Meanwhile, Jess meets her boyfriend, Peter (2001: A Space Odyssey's Keir Dullea), a neurotic music student. She tells Peter that she is pregnant and planning to get an abortion, angering him. In town, Mr. Harrison, accompanied by Barb and another of the girls, Phyllis "Phyl" Carlson (Andrea Martin), attempt to report Clare as missing, while Jess tells Clare's boyfriend Chris Hayden (Art Hindle) about Clare's sudden disappearance. They learn that another local girl named Janis Quaife has also seemingly vanished while walking home from school. While a drunken Barb is put to bed, Mr. Harrison, Chris, Jess, and Phyllis help search for Janis, hoping also to find Clare. Meanwhile, Mrs. Mac is lured up into the attic, where she discovers Clare's body. The killer throws a crane hook into her face, hanging and killing her. Janis's disfigured body is found by the police in the park, Jess returns, while the search for Clare continues. Jess answers another obscene phone call and decides to file a report with the police, only for Peter to appear and surprise her. He tries to persuade her into marrying him for the sake of their child, but Jess refuses. Peter leaves emotional, while Lieutenant Kenneth Fuller (A Nightmare on Elm Street's John Saxon) arrives to bug the telephone. While Jess is distracted by a choir of children arriving at the house carol singing, the killer enters Barb's bedroom. Barb is murdered her with a glass figurine, but her screams are drowned out by the singing children. After the children leave, Jess answers another unnerving phone call, and mentions the conversation between her and Peter. Lieutenant Fuller theorises that Peter could be responsible, due to the caller's knowledge of the argument and his mentality, but Jess doubts it. Moments later, Phyllis enters Barb's room and is ambushed by the killer, who murders her off-screen. Jess answers the telephone again, she stays on the line long enough to be traced by telephone company employee Bill Graham (Leslie "Les" Carlson). Sergeant Nash (Douglas "Doug" McGrath) instructs Jess to leave the house immediately, as the calls have been traced to be coming from within the sorority house. Jess arms herself with a poker and ventures upstairs, where she discovers Barb and Phyllis's maimed bodies. The killer appears and pursues Jess through the house, she locks herself in the cellar, while Peter appears outside one of the windows. He smashes the window to get to Jess, who proceeds to bludgeon him with the poker, assuming he is the killer. The police arrive, alerted by Jess's screams. They discover her barely conscious in the basement, with Peter's body next to her. They put Jess to bed and discuss the murders, unaware that the bodies of Clare and Mrs. MacHenry are still in the attic. While Jess is resting, with a policeman standing outside. The killer climbs down from the attic into her bedroom, Jess's fate is unknown, and the telephone begins to ring as the credits roll. Also starring Michael Rapport as Patrick, Leslie Carlson as Graham, Martha Gibson as Mrs. Quaife and Robert Warner as Doctor. Hussey and Kidder among the other young actresses give good performances as the victims to the maniac stalking them on the phone and in the house. This is a good slap in the face to the traditional festive movie full of happy families and joy, it feels creepy, and the kills are reasonably inventive, the bag death being the most memorable (featuring in both remakes), overall it's not a bad seasonal slasher horror. Good!

reviews.review_title: "WHERE DID YOU PUT THE BABY, BILLY!?"
reviews.content: Never has the sound of a ringing phone been used to such great effect than in Black Christmas, a film that I somehow knew absolutely nothing about going in, and one which I will never forget going forward. Rarely do I get my bones chilled or my brow wetted to such an extent while watching horror. Few film's from the genre have gripped me both in entertainment and in suspense like this one did. Not to mention, it boasts some of the better performances from scared women and questionable men that you'll find in the slasher arena. The blocking is tremendous and so is the cinematography. The sound design is tops, though, as the voice on the other end of that miserable phone will haunt me for some time.

The plot is simple--a crazy man hides in a mostly empty sorority house Christmas Eve.  He begins to stalk and kill the remaining girls.  This sounds like just another slasher thriller, but it's not.  For starters, it came out 4 years before "Halloween" started the slasher craze and it's an intelligent, very scary movie--how many slashers can you say that about? 
The film was shot in Canada on a low-budget.  With the exception of John Saxon, everybody was basically unknown (Margot Kidder made this before "Superman").  There's no sex, no nudity and very little blood and gore. Still, I've seen this movie at least 8 times and it scares me each and every time.  All during the movie, even when the characters are inside, you hear the wind blowing through the soundtrack.  It makes you feel the cold and chill the characters feel.  Also there are the obscene phone calls the girls in the sorority house are getting--they're deeply disturbing and the frightening music playing during them makes them worse.  A truly scary horror film--back in 1978 NBC cancelled a showing of the film--even edited they thought it was too disturbing to air!  That should tell you something.SPOILERSThe most terrifying moments in the movie--the phone calls (especially when you hear the killer pleading to be stopped);  when Olivia Hussey is grabbed by her hair; the opening murder and Margot Kidder's murder.Only complaint--the ending.  It was original back in 1974 but it's an overused cliche now.A definite must-see.  DON'T see it alone.  A commercial bomb when released this has deservedly acquired a cult following.

reviews.review_title: No one is safe even on Christmas
reviews.content: This movie builds tension like a staircase it's incredible .. this is uncomfortable horror, gives u the feeling that someone could be in the house or in the backyard.. the killer is truly terrifying .. we need movies like this today where a characters personality drives the audience insane of what the hell he's doing or gonna do next.

A seriously disturbed man stalks girls at a sorority house over Christmas break. It is sure to a very Black Christmas for most of them ...The film opens to the POV of a prowler outside of a large Victorian house which is a sorority house for women attending classes at the local university. He crawls up an outside ladder leading to the open attic. A bunch of the sorority sisters meanwhile are having a holiday party downstairs. After a terrifying and crude obscene phone call, one of the girls goes upstairs and is murdered by the prowler with a plastic bag and put in the attic to sit by the window.Our main characters include mostly the sorority sisters - Jess, the film's fiery heroine, Barb the house drunk, Phyl the level headed intelligent one, and Mrs. Mack, the house mother who is our comedic relief character always looking for booze anywhere she can find hidden around the house. After a few more phone calls, the killer starts coming out from his attic to attack the girls left at the sorority house during winter break. With only one girl left alive, will the killer be stopped or is she destined to be murdered?Black Christmas might be the best horror film I have ever seen. I rate it so high not only for it's quality, but for setting the tone of my favourite subgenres - the killer in the house and the slasher film. Pretty much every one that comes after this has used elements from this story. When A Stranger Calls and Halloween definitely found inspiration from this terrifying classic. Black Christmas still does it best - I have yet to see a film that musters the whole "the calls are coming from inside the house" routine the way that Bob Clark did in 1974. The moment that line and truth is revealed, the viewers heart sinks with the realization that our characters are in serious danger.The filming locations are set in my hometown of Toronto. I recognized most of the places which was nice, including the police station in the east end and the University of Toronto campus. The house they used is actually the film's biggest plus for me. Not only is the exterior eerie with the winter winds blowing and snow on the ground, but the inside is equally creepy with turns and dark corners and that attic where the killer hides out. Super effective location to make a movie like this.The acting is so superior for a horror film and for a low budget film like this, very unusual. Olivia Hussey is our final girl Jess and she plays the heck out of the role. She is such a strong female lead and is a unique one with her noticeable British accent. Marion Waldman as the house mother is one of the best things about Black Christmas. This lady is constantly seeking out small bottles of Sherry that she has hidden around the house, and is constantly grumbling around the place clearly so over her job as the head of the house. Margot Kidder and Andrea Martin are the supportive female characters and both were perfect for their roles.Everything about this classic is so creepy to me. The obscene phone calls are so manic and crazed that I still get goosebumps thinking about them. The murder scenes are well done, but it is the shadowy figure coming out from the attic each time that sets them up to be as effective as they are. The thing that is always talked about is the ending and how up in the air it is when it comes to figuring out the killers identity. Following an amazing chase scene involving Jess and the maniac, we are left to wonder who the actual killer is. Was it Jess' neurotic boyfriend, one of the other frat boys we see, or some crazed maniac who is perhaps named Billy? We never find and probably never will.Black Christmas is a film to be seen by all and should be studied by any horror director who is looking to make a movie in this genre. It is a perfect masterpiece.10/10

reviews.review_title: You knows when your sleeping and awake
reviews.content: The definition of a cult classic black Christmas was the standard whodunit set around Christmas.While house sorority girls are getting ready to head out for the holidays they are being stalked by a crazed maniac.It may be a controversial idea, but I found it better then Halloween. It has a mysterious killer, a big house to work with, faster paced and better characterization. I felt like a kid hiding under the covers during some of the brutal scenes. It could be very creepy like when the killer would taunt them or talk about sexual content that I suspect he was performing on the bodies.The music even became an entity that reached a pitch at climatic scenes resulting in nearly turning my hair white.I can't say there was ever a dull moment. I watched it dozens of times and have never been bored by it. It always has the characters involved in parties or on a hunt and noting around. I nearly suffered whiplash.Black Christmas may be ignored by critics at its release, but now has the cult following it deserved.Special mentions to Marget Kidder who was a delight and my favorite character. Olivia before her Romeo and Juliet days and John Saxon we all know from elm street. Ask for black Christmas this December. It'll be the best present you ever got.8/10.

I saw Black Christmas when it was under its alternate title Stranger In the House and knew this was a classic. It crawled under my skin unlike any other horror film (with the exception of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre). I don't know if there is a distinction between scary and disturbing but the film works on the latter. The premise cannot be more simplke: a lunatic is prowling around a college sorority house around the Christmas season, picking off one girl after another. Without knowing any better you'd think that this was a rip off of Halloween but it predates the John Carpenter film by four years. Halloween was probably heavily influenced by Black Christmas,especially the numerous Point of View shots. What distinguishes the two is that we have no idea who killer is or why he is killing girls. There are hints that this is a demented boyfriend who goes crazy when his girlfriend aborts his child, but nothing is clearly explained. It makes the killer all the more frightening because there is no apparent motive and we fear for each female left inside the sorority house. It is a film that I find more frightening than The Exorcist. The demonic possession of a 12 year old girl I find implausible but a lunatic in a house (especially if one recalls the Richard Speck killings of several student nurses) is terrifyingly plausible. There are scenes that still send a chill down my spine. The cast is outstanding and are more than just walking meat bags to be killed off. We feel their deaths more than any other slasher flicks. It's hard to believe that this is the same Bob Clark who will go on to make A Christmas Story. Although many see Halloween as the originator of the modern slasher flicks it was Black Christmas which ranks as one of the best.

reviews.review_title: A different kind of "Christmas Story" from Bob Clark.
reviews.content: Black Christmas, if nothing else, is a genuinely frightening film. Some have labeled it a "classic" but I'm not so sure I can go that far. True it clearly inspired numerous more successful films, but it's just "good" when taken on its own.Our story is simple enough. A deranged killer has snuck into the attic of a sorority house just as many of the girls are leaving for Christmas break. This guy is a real wacko. He begins calling the young women on a regular basis and threatening them in often obscure but VERY SPOOKY outbursts of jibberish. Then, he begins picking off those who remain behind one by one. The bulk of the latter half of the film centers around a police detective (John Saxon) trying to get to the bottom of everything and save the lives of the remaining girls. This film works mainly because of two reasons. First of all, this film has an atmosphere of gloom set over it like few I have ever seen before. Even though it's Xmas, and people should be having fun, the characters and the audience as well seem to know something terrible is going on around them. A prime example is the duality we are presented with when the group of carolers are singing to the beautiful Olivia Hussey while Margot Kidder is being stabbed to death in her bed at the same time. The second major factor that helps this film get its point across is the absolutely demented phone calls this killer makes. Wow! I have never heard anything more psychotic in any film that I can remember. These calls really make the case for just how screwed up this guy is. His multiple outbursts and different vocal tones will be ringing in your ears for a while after the film is over.The acting was decent, but I don't think anyone was particularly outstanding. The film had a noticeably restrictive budget, but Clark does what he can. This film sets quite a different tone than his later successes like Porky's and A Christmas Story. It makes me want to check out some of his other thrillers made early in his career.One thing about this film that also can give you the creeps is knowing that this sort of thing has happened in real life! Perhaps the most well-known incident like this was when Ted Bundy, one of America's most famous serial killers, dropped in for a visit to a sorority house at Florida State one evening. The results were very similar to what happened in this film. If you think about it, these houses full of young (and often attractive) women would seem a real beacon to these types of killers. Especially in a college town like the one I live in.Makes you wonder if or when this type of thing could happen again...7 of 10 starsSo sayeth the Hound.

Aside from a few logic holes like the totally inept police and the slightly slow pacing this is a fantastic scary horror. There are no laughs here as this is as serious as horror gets. This is what is so good about it. The creepy phone calls really set the mood leading towards the intense and petrifying scary ending. This is a very good and well-polished but still gritty stalker horror. The killer is always hidden. There aren't many jumps in the film, there doesn't need to be as there is this impending sense of doom that lingers throughout even after the intense ending. Very good horror film.

"Black Christmas" was a pioneering movie. It's safe to say that this was one of the first if not THE first slasher-flick of all time. As such, the movie has a lot going for itself. Everything that would later become a cliché is established here: the POV-shot of the killer entering rooms, the creative ways of picking off victims one by one, the final girl, etc. "Black Christmas" invented it all. On top of that the movie has top notch direction and an artful cinematography, which is sometimes reminiscent of Dario Argento's work. The acting is fine for the most part, and the mysterious killer and his creepy phone calls give Michael Myers a run for the money. So, if we take all that into consideration, "Black Christmas" is a genuine horror masterpiece.However, a lot of time has passed and a lot of slasher movies have been made since 1974. If you watch this movie now for the first time, it won't do much for you. You've seen these ideas before and probably in a more shocking way. "Black Christmas" may have been the first movie to do it, but other movies were the ones who made the basic slasher-elements famous.That's hardly director Bob Clark's fault, of course. It's just that if you're not a cineaste, you won't care too much about whether or not this movie was inventive when it first came out. All you'll care about is whether it can surprise and entertain you still, and truth be told, if you've seen the "Halloween"- and "Friday The 13th"-flicks or any movies of their ilk, then "Black Christmas" probably won't blow you away.However, if you do care about historical movie facts, then you must see Bob Clark's true holiday classic (the "false" one being "A Christmas Story" from 1983). After all, "Psycho" is also respected for the effect it originally had on audiences mostly. Even Hitchcock's masterpiece seems tame and predictable from today's point of view, so why should you be more critical when it comes to judging "Black Christmas"? For horror buffs, this one is a must, anyway.

reviews.review_title: A perfect slasher if not for the bloated subplots.
reviews.content: It's hard to write a review for Black Christmas. On one hand I thought much of the movie was a pathetic attempt at an emotional slasher film, and on the other hand there were scenes that were some of the best kill/scares in the history of horror movies. It's almost like Black Christmas flirts with perfection then jumps back to lame subplots. Yes, I understand that this film literally invented the slasher genre, but, no, I cannot call it perfectI can only call certain aspects perfect.As I said, the main standout flaw is the complete lack of focus. The movie starts out in a sorority house, but from there jumps to a lot of other places to focus on characters and subplots that don't really matter to the story at all. The whole subplot of Clare's father coming to the sorority house was completely pointless by the end of the film, and just takes away from the actual story. The subplot between Jess and her boyfriend should have been cut much shorter, in order to, once again, focus on the actual story. Most of all, the subplot of the missing child still has nothing to do whatsoever with anything else in the film. I don't understand why the director takes 20 minutes to go into it, when in the end, like all the other subplots, it is nothing important. It could have easily been a passing reference instead of its own section of the film. The police scenes, also, added nothing to the story except take away from the amazing atmosphere. Everything the police scenes added could have been done with phone conversations, instead of taking up half the movie time to show things the audience could have guessed. Without all these subplots the movie would have been much, much more effective and tense.Another problem I had was the title of the film is Black Christmas, but other than the opening and one of the death scenes, nothing in this movie referenced Christmas at all. Most of the time there wasn't even snow on the ground. It would have been so much more emotionally effective if it played into the Christmas nostalgia more than it did, but the movie made the ability to play Christmas songs more of a gimmick than a plot point.Though I'm being negative with almost every aspect of the film, I really did enjoy part of itthe actual story. When the movie isn't trying to have five different subplots that go nowhere, the actual core story is done to perfection. The killer, the kills, the girls, the sorority house, the phone calls, the endingall truly perfect, and by far the greatest slasher of all time. It's sad to see what is really a beautiful minimalist horror story turned into a bloated crime drama with more pointless subplots than kills, and that is the only thing holding this film from perfection.Overall, I wish I could go in and just watch the actual plot happen in Black Christmas, but I can't. Still, as much ranting as I did, there is something there that makes it better than so many movies that I've rated higher. Something that Hollywood forgot four decades ago. Maybe it's the fact this movie has very little blood, but is still very effective. Or, maybe, it's that the core plot was actually thought out, truly terrifying, emotionally captivating, and also something original that had never been done before it. I think that is it.4/10

reviews.review_title: A creepy tonic to Christmas cheer.
reviews.content: An excellent horror film, which manages to build up a quiet, considerable power.  While it may not be out-and-out BOO! YIKES! scary (very little is these days), it combines narrative and subtext to an agreeably creepy pitch. Imagine an episode of THE X-FILES without the gloss, or alien nonsense, or enervating conspiracy theories, or even Mulder and Scully.  Even the amusing accents (the film is Canadian) cease to grate after a while.The story is set in a placid all-girl sorority house on campus in some Canadian university, at Christmas time.  The girls are having a sedate party with some boy friends.  Outside a breathing camera lurches towards the house...  Like Argento's SUSPIRIA, this all-female community is the site of the most horrific repressions, anxieties, fears, waiting to burst out, both within (figured as alcoholism, unwanted pregnancy) and without (rapes, murders, obscene phone calls).  Cleverly, though, the girls don't go hysterically loopy - everything remains externalised - much more chilling, even if it lacks the full on psychogynaecology of the Italian masterpiece.For example, one girl's mother is clearly indifferent to her, gold-digging, she claims, after other men.  Another is a virgin who has previously, we deduce, lived in a very repressive, rigid family atmosphere.  Indeed, one of the noteworthy things about BLACK is how these girls are away from home for the first time - they have cut away from authority, patriarchy and tradition.  The film is not necessarily a reactionary plea, however - the girls' substitute authority figures - boyfriends - become the locus of the terror; and although their self-made family verges on the parodic (with their seemingly jovial, frustrated alcoholic housekeeper as mother substitute), it is a genuine, if finally useless, structure of support.I suppose the film could be seen as an examination of the deep traumas buried underneath the vociferous self-confidence of contemporary feminism - after all, it was directed by the man who would make that radical treatise on gender relations, PORKY'S.  The main plot centres on the lead's right to have an abortion, and the terrifying phone calls - a horrifying, babbling cacophony from the beyond - seem like the pleas of a dying child, or the malicious threats of an Id-mother.  The idea of the disembodied or unreferential voice (those things denied a presence in the film, and maybe our society; e.g. the psychological trauma of abortion), miscommunication, misread signs, disinformation all suggest a culture where all recognisable meaning has gone haywire.  As this is the film's anxiety, we may feel that it is somewhat right-wing.On the other hand, it's thematic interest is the family, set in a family away from a 'real' family.  The BLACK of the title in relation to CHRISTMAS suggests diabolical overtones, a distorted mirror of the Holy Family celebrated at this time.  Maybe the film is reactionary - charging newly independent women with destroying the structures of family and tradition, and unloosing untold terrors and demons.Or maybe it's very sympathetic to the characters' plight.  Patriarchy in all its forms pervade the film - the unseen killer/rapist; the ineffectual police lieutenant; the self-obsessed boyfriends; the downright idiotic cop. The only clever, likable characters are the women.  And, as in the case of Barb, their rejection of family is not necessarily willed.  The path to independence is certainly not made easy in this culture.The great thing about BLACK is how it shows the sheer ineffectuality of trying to specify the unspecifiable.  It is obviously madness to think that Peter could have committed all these crimes, and yet it is quite reasonable to demonise him - he reveals the monster beneath the sensitive New Man. The heroine discovers that she can rely on no-one but herself.  Even this isn't enough.  Notwithstanding the unreassuring ending, she still has to deal with the fallout of her actions, which are by no means resolved.  There is still the issue of the abortion, which is one reason the demon is not dead. There were obscene phone calls and rapes before she knew she was pregnant: the fears may be subjective, but the inability to connect everything makes the film the more scarily effective.As a horror film, BLACK's excellence derives from the disparity between the hysteria of the subject matter, and the cool film style, suggestive, sinister, yet withdrawn.  The breathy point of view camerawork may seem tiresome after HALLOWEEN and its dozy imitators, but here the idea of something submerged, concealed, unknowable, unconquerable, not even human, never mind the cartoon slasher we're used to, is superbly realised, slowing down time.  The images of the first dead girl, with the doll baby in her lap, and the cat purring beside her, will haunt me for a long, long time.

reviews.review_title: Has Always Remained My Favorite Slasher
reviews.content: I'm not even sure what sequence number can I assign to this year's re-watch, but what I am sure about though is that "Black Christmas" still remains my favorite slasher of all. Bob Clark did a terrific and highly creative job, and got hated back then, but eventually, deservedly it became a cult classic, and, more importantly, a huge influence to the genre - beginning with John Carpenter's "Halloween" which, in early stages, was meant to be a sequel to "Black Christmas".It's a bit of a slippery topic, about wether it's a slasher or not, but I made up my mind the first time I watched it - it is. What makes "Black Christmas" so enjoyable is the simplicity of the production, there are no over-the-top kills, no goofy chase scenes, no unintentional humor. Instead we get presented a contained, straight-forward, but unnerving story that's rooted in reality. The atmosphere feels pseudo claustrophobic and vulnerable. Bob Clark takes his sweet time to build the story, the characters and create suspense - by general slasher standards I'd deduct that "Black Christmas" is quite the slow-burn, but trust me, it's a value instead of a flaw. Despite an awfully tiny budget, "Black Christmas" feels polished and confident. The entire cast is almost unexpectedly terrific, with Olivia Hussey and John Saxon being the highlights & Marian Waldman provides a warming and healthy humorous character as the Sorority house's mother. The villain, the killer, mostly portrayed in back then extremely rarely used POV style, is just perfect for a slasher flick. The ambiguity surrounding him is all the character needs & his terrifying voice is an icon on its own. All the while the aforementioned qualities keep the movie going smoothly and creepily, even visually, given the budget, it's very creative - mad props to the cinematographer."Black Christmas" is, without a doubt, an overlooked movie if not also underrated. I might love it more than most of its viewers, but I'm telling you, it's a landmark in the horror genre that still has the ability to provide enough kicks. My rating: 9/10.

reviews.review_title: A foundation of the slasher sub genre that is a good film in its own right.
reviews.content: In the weeks leading up to Christmas, a sorority house is harassed by obscene phone calls that serve as a prelude to chilling murders.Released in 1974 to respectable box office and mixed reviews, the film helped pave the way for future films such as John Carpenter's Halloween and Sean S. Cunningham's Friday the 13th. But even taking its influence on future films out of the equation, Black Christmas is a chilling and well made thriller.Bob Clark strikes a good balance between character based moments, humorous moments, and suspenseful moments to build a film where the scares come organically from build up and release rather than through overuse of jump scares. Clark makes good use of the perspective from both the killer and the women in the sorority house, and we never learn anything about the killer other than whatever insane rants he divulges over his obscene calls that are so loosely constructed they may or may not contain the truth.The movie is anchored by great performances as well. John Saxon does a good job of playing the investigating officer Lt. Fuller, and Margot Kidder as the house's brash acerbic Barb brings some subtle hints of humanity to what could have easily just been a hate sink for the audience to want to die, but easily the best performance is Olivia Hussey as Jess. Jess is a fantastic protagonist who we see dealing with the dilemma of terminating a pregnancy despite her boyfriend's objections, and she brings that inner struggle to her performance quite well. She also conveys a caring nature thatmakes her an endearing character who we like spending time with.Black Christmas is a classic for a reason. From its well defined characters to it lean but creepy atmosphere it's a film every horror fan needs to see at minimum once.

reviews.review_title: Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire
reviews.content: This is definitely one of the best of its type; a crazed killer stalks a coed in a sorority house and unmercifully butchers her closest friends and any passersby that just happen to get in his way. What separates this from the typical slasher fare is an above-average script, above-average acting, and really good direction. Director Bob Clark, the director of such films like Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things and Murder by Decree, seemingly does everything right in this one and makes all the right choices(well, most of the time at least). His flair for creating hauntingly eerie scenes that stay with you is first-rate. Take the first murdered girl(happens in first ten minutes). We never see the killer but just his eyes. The girl is saran-wrapped in a dress bag and set in a rocking chair with an old doll. Her presence is filmed in such a stark manner as to really set the mood of this whole film. Clark then effectively builds tension by the girl's father looking for her - as no body is found - the coed, played by the beautiful Olivia Hussey, consistently receiving phone calls from what is some sick sex pervert on the outside, the police are then brought into the mix, and finally some red herrings that throw the viewer off track a bit at the very least. All this goes on with snow, caroling, decorations, and Christmas atmosphere like one might expect in a small college town of a similar ilk. The first death scene is for my money the most effective shot and running scene in the entire film, but there are other equally brilliant shots that Clark uses to shock and create suspense. One scene in particular has Margot Kidder getting acquainted with the man with the creepy eyes with cuts(no pun intended) to children singing mellifluous carols at front door for Hussey. The acting all around is pretty good. Hussey is adequate. Kidder is too. Andrea Martin is along as well. The main policeman is John Saxon. He is pretty good and seems to flourish in roles like this in the seventies. Many films have tried to create the same effect as Black Christmas, but so few have come close at all to reaching the level of this - at least in this genre. An impressively shot film with good locations and a very effective ending.

The Canadian classic, Black Christmas is one of the creepiest films ever made! December is a fun time when you are a kid, but this season is kind bored for an young person, at least for me, but Black Christmas brought to me happiness, a tradition for every Christmas eve, I mean a must watch every December 24. Bob Clark take us to a sorority house with a killer stalking a group of college girls, the thrilling story is full of a gray atmosphere, great acting and a scary house! The slasher film was originally born in 1960 with Peeping Tom (UK) and Psycho (USA), but in 1974, Canada brought it first slasher, the amazing Black Christmas. A cool feminist horror film.Billy is still out there, don't answer the phone.

I really enjoyed this film! It had such a creepy and unsettling atmosphere. At times, it made the hairs on my neck stand up! It wasn't scary in a jumpscare sense. It's the type of horror that burrows under your skin and makes you feel deeply unsettled. The acting was great, and the soundtrack was genuinely unnerving. The ending was also well done in my opinion. All movies have flaws, though. To start off, the whole calling while inside the house idea was a bit unrealistic. In the calls, the man can be heard screaming. There's no way no one couldn't hear him screaming while inside the home. Next, the movie felt a bit slow at some parts. Those are my only flaws with this film. In conclusion, while the movie had a couple of issues, I really enjoyed it. I thought it was well made and very creepy. I would definitely recommend this horror movie!

I must admit that I was looking forward to actually sitting down to watch this 1974 horror classic titled "Black Christmas". Yeah, I know, a mistake on my behalf for not watching it before now late in 2022. But I always did put it off, and opted to finally watch it now.And I must say that with the movie's rating of 7.1, as I sat down to watch it, and the fact that the movie had the likes of Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder and John Saxon on the cast list definitely helped fuel the expectation.However, I must say that writer Roy Moore didn't really managed to delive a script that provided me with much of any great entertainment. Sure, "Black Christmas" was watchable, but I hardly found the movie all that enjoyable or entertaining, and definitely not 7.1 rating worthy. But hey, to each their own.Director Bob Clark's 1974 movie felt too chaotic and disharmonious for my liking, so this was not a great viewing experience for me. And now that I have finally watched it and can tick it off of my to-watch-list, this is definitely not a horror movie that I will ever return to watch a second time.My rating of "Black Christmas" lands on a four out of ten stars.

Whilst it's widely thought that it was John Carpenter's Halloween that initiated the slasher genre those who actually know anything about horror know that it was actually Bob Clark's Black Christmas made in 1974. In fact, Clark and Carpenter worked together on a project after Black Christmas was made. Clark said to Carpenter that he no longer worked in horror but that he had had an idea for a horror film that was never realised. This would be based around the occasion of, you've guessed it, Halloween! Carpenter then later asked to use the idea for a film he was to due to work on and the rest is history. This isn't to say that Carpenter ripped off Clark but this explains how The Babysitter Murders (the original idea for Halloween) suddenly morphed into the masterpiece we now know and love.In fact, the opening shots of Black Christmas are similar to those of Halloween- the killer's point of view camera shot. Halloween reveals who this person is (and it's one hell of a reveal) but Black Christmas doesn't. In fact, the killer isn't revealed fully throughout the entire film which is the first reason that Black Christmas is so revolutionary.The story involves a group of female students on the night before they leave their sorority house to go home for the holidays. They start to receive very disturbing phone calls and things start to get dramatically worse soon after.Another reason to love Black Christmas is that the extent of the killer's mental instability is shown by the first girl he kills. She is suffocated and then placed in a rocking chair in the attic where the psycho is hiding out. Throughout the film we see him ranting and manically rocking her.Arguably some of the most disturbing sequences within the film are when the intruder calls the girls. They don't know the calls are actually being made by the killer who's in the attic within the same house. From the calls we come to learn that the person making them is called Billy and that he seems to be playing out incidents from his past, incidents rife with cruelty, abuse and possibly murder. Bob Clark used five different actors for the calls. These phone calls are some of the scariest, most disturbing and unsettling sequences I've ever seen in a horror film. They were even cut when the film was first released in the UK.Theres also the fact that Black Christmas was the first film to use the now established trope of a killer's phone calls coming from inside the same house as their potential victim(s). This was years before When A Stranger Calls.Another great thing about the film is the humour contained within the movie especially from Margot Kidder's character, Barb. It's amazing that such an unnerving film can still have genuinely funny interludes but without forsaking the movie's tension.But maybe thats because the film is extremely tense indeed. Theres a certain sense of doom to the proceedings that are depicted in the movie. A great example is where Olivia Hussey's character Jess has just found out that the calls are coming from the sorority house, that Billy is ensconced within it but so are two of her friends (the audience knows otherwise as we saw them get dispatched earlier). On going upstairs (even though the police have phoned and demanded that she leave the house immediately) she enters one of the girl's bedrooms to discover their dead bodies- and the killer looking at her through a crack in the door. This sequence is one of scariest in horror history.Add to this one of the most warped endings I've ever seen in a horror movie and you have a masterpiece.Theres only two horror films with the ability to give me sleepless nights. One is The Exorcist, the other is Black Christmas. Essential.

reviews.review_title: Good for a few first class scares. Worth 6 or 7 out of 10.
reviews.content: I think it is fascinating that 'Black Christmas' very clearly precedes the embodiment of the slasher genre (which began officially with 'Halloween' in 1978) yet so-called film critics often fail to acknowledge this fact. Although I did not find the movie to be 100% satisfying, it was certainly an original piece of work at the time it was released and therefore  deserves to be credited with being a major influence on such horror classics as 'Halloween', 'When a Stranger Calls' and 'Scream' among many others. In relation to the film itself, on the positive side it was atmospheric, undeniably creepy (the telephone calls are probably the most frightening ever filmed)and was free of the usual sex and extreme gore which often spoils such pictures. The abortion angle was also an intriguing and surprisingly adult issue to embrace in a movie of this type. In addition, it was endowed with a strong cast, making it interesting to see at least four reasonably well known actors appearing in what amounts to a fairly low budget shocker. Olivia Hussey seems an unlikely actress to appear in a film of this kind given some of her other roles, but her off-beat casting works very well. Margot Kidder made a star making impression to follow her effective performance in Brian De Palma's 'Sisters'(1973)and John Saxon got to play the police man role which he seemed to then enjoy repeating in other subsequent horror outings (i.e; 'Nightmare on Elm Street', 'Blood Beach' etc). However, I did not think that Keir Dullea was entirely well cast in the role of the boyfriend. He is certainly a talented actor with a gift for playing intense and even unbalanced parts but he seemed wasted here. He also appeared too old for the 20-something character he was representing. (I believe Mr Dullea was around 38 years of age when the movie was made). Other criticisms are that the film was a mite too slowly paced, and it was also highly improbable, especially in that the killer remained undiscovered for so long. Finally, I found the end to be a silly disappointment and rather succeeded in diminishing the overall effect of the film by its lack of any adequate explanation/conclusion to events. (However,to be fair,this is true of many horror films). Generally speaking, 'Black Christmas' is a reasonably effective shocker of its kind which will certainly appeal to fright fans (like me)and has deserved more attention over the years for being such an inspiration to future horror classic horror  (although I doubt if anti-horror film purists would agree with this credit).

I love horror films, but could only make it half way in before turning this snooze fest off. Too much talk and no horror. They should've added more slashing and blood and called it Red Christmas. Watch only if you have trouble sleeping because this will knock you out.

Spoiler...  They say this film influenced others; well it is average by today's standards.  This film builds great tension but is dated and laps over periods of time.  The relentless tension build up is what makes this movie.  The scare factor is very tame, and predictable for today's standards.  Plot twists, this is before call trace and shows the age of this film, where they have to wait to trace the caller and find out he is calling from the house. I could see this one coming right from the get go.  The comic relief is awful, the 70's must have been the I don't care rude and crude generation that reflects today's social decay.  The swearing, perverseness, drinking, and rude comments had a shock humor element then, but in today's Jenny Jones, Jerry Springer society make one's eyes roll.  It seems in that era of filming everyone has to yell, for many of us who work customer service just find it idiotic, not funny, or even amusing. (explains why so many disgruntled customers have the 70's styled mustaches, leather vests and boots). I work at the Post Office and see this daily, and with my experiences with unbalanced people I find the caller's messages scary.  They must have experience with these phone calls or studied mental illnesses. The caller rants, rambles, repeats himself, and goes on a senseless tangent. A different sense of reality.  Everyone in this film has a problem, the drinking bit is too much, and builds little character development.  The unbalanced boyfriend ending, and the cops too stupid to check the rest of the house is a little too much. 6/10

A top-notch horror film from the 1970s, Black Christmas' only drawback is that it occasionally drags. There are a handful of times that you wish things would speed up but perhaps Bob Clark is just building the suspense, because once things begin to happen you'll be far more ensnared than you'd otherwise be.The story concerns a sorority house where the girls receive prank calls from a psycho. When Clare (Lynne Griffin) goes missing, her father (James Edmond) shows up to locate her. Since Clare didn't make it home her sorority friends grow more concerned with the obscene caller and wonder if he is to blame for Clare's disappearance. But Clare's loss is just the beginning as the girls get picked off one-by-one.STORY: $$$$ (The script is really quite strong. Characterization is not forfeited for blood and guts in this tight little slasher. Olivia Hussey and Keir Dullea play a couple who bicker over her pregnancy, Margot Kidder is a lush who seems to be following in the footsteps of their alcoholic house mother Marian Waldman. You will like these characters. Suspense is in large supply as well. Director Bob Clark has a knack for placing you on the edge of your seat and then giving said seat a swift kick at the right time to jar your senses).ACTING: $$$ (The acting is generally strong along the board. Genre favorite John Saxon is terrific as usual in the role of the town sheriff but he is upstaged in the acting department in his own precinct by Doug McGrath as Sergeant Nash. McGrath masterfully portrays the rube desk sergeant who is the butt of every joke. The scene where Margot Kidder leaves him the sorority house' phone number is a riot! Keri Dullea is effectively pompous as Olivia Hussey's emotional unstable boyfriend and Miss Hussey shines as the mother hen even though she opts not be a mother. Art Hindle, man-fur and all, does a fine job as Clare's jock boyfriend while Margot Kidder gives one of her best performances as the crass Barb).NUDITY: None

It really has a lot of potential to be a slasher genre defining movie, but Halloween got it.
Blame the writing , screenplay ,low budget etc. occasional suspense , Slow pacing of this movie puts its viewers to sleep but it's not a dumb or illogical movie unlike others in this very particular genre.
Ah ! Margot kidder was so goddamn beautiful in this movie!

It's a shame I wasn't shown this film sooner. Now it's not really a 10/10 but I'd give it a strong 8 to a 9... but I think it deserves a 10 because of the simple fact that it REALLY is ahead if it's time and influenced not only Halloween but MAN this film was more than ahead of its time. There's no cliche teen sex or even nudity, the characters shine all around the block it's not really one main character that has too much of the spotlight until it starts going down by the numbers. The music isn't as effective say as Halloween but it gets the job done. The sound effects are skin crawling and the ending is the most iconic endings I've ever seen in ANY horror film. I absolutely loved this film and just as I make it my duty to watch Halloween every Halloween I will watch this film every Christmas. Good job Clarke, you have 2 of one of the most iconic Christmas films down in the bag. He invented the slasher genre with this and inspired many to come.

reviews.review_title: A Black & Blue & Bloody Christmas To You Too!
reviews.content: Like, am I the only one who thinks that Black Christmas is nothing more than just an over-rated piece of 'Slasher Trash'? At best, I'd say that this particular Horror film is only marginally better than the rest of the junk that's out there.And, yes, I know that Black Christmas can, in a sense, be considered the "original" Slasher flick, since it proceeds both Halloween and Friday The 13th by years - But I honestly don't give a damn about that sort of thing - 'Cause I still don't think it's all that good, anyways.And, besides that - I still can't figure out how the heck the psycho-killer was able to make those insane phone calls of his from the attic inside the Sorority House. Like, that would've meant that he would've had to have had his own private line up there. And I sure don't recall seeing this nut making any sort of arrangements about this special 'obscene-calls only' service with the phone company, or anything like that.And speaking about those ghastly, irksome phone calls in Black Christmas - According to Director Bob Clark - 5 people (both men and women) were apparently responsible for talking all that gross gibberish stuff over the phone, including Clark, himself. I think it's kind of interesting to note how little profanity was actually used in the things that this wacko said.And, in conclusion - I can't begin to tell you how glad I am that Black Christmas was not followed by a bloody sequel. With the utterly dissatisfactory way in which this film ended, it was sure ripe for one.

reviews.review_title: Creepiest phone calls you'll ever hear in film
reviews.content: This Original Classic pre-dates John Carpenter's Halloween and introduces many film tropes that have become Staples in the slasher genre. Sure plenty of slashers were made before this like the many Italian giallos films, but black christmas was the one to really kickstart the genre. John Carpenter even said this movie was what influenced him to do Halloween.The killer Billy is never seen, other than a silhouette in one scene, and his phone calls are disturbing. I believe you could go insane if you listen to them long enough. It's uses of POV camera techniques gives an eeriee & horrifying perspective into Billy's bloodthirsty lurking. The film especially has things you wouldn't see common in 1974 films such a strong vulgar language & the main character considering getting an abortion. It's an excellent horror film to be observed even if its premise is now basic. Good characters and a chilling holiday atmosphere.

Canadian director Bob Clark's Black Christmas (1974) gets a lot of love these days from many horror fans who cite it as the inspiration for John Carpenter's classic, Halloween, and some even claim it to be the original slasher filmthe one that started the sub-genre that spawned not just Michael Myers but countless other masked maniacs. Whilst I am not in total agreement with them (Mario Bava's Bay Of Blood, for example, follows the body count style of the genre and was made in 1971), I do agree that this film must have been highly influential on Mr.Carpenter, who obviously modelled some of his film's scenes on Black Christmas's best moments (although Halloween is still the superior movie, in my humble opinion).Clark sets his seminal shocker in a sorority house during the Christmas holidays, where a group of young women are killed one by one by a crazy, ranting maniac who has also been scaring them with a series of sick telephone calls. Starring Keir Dullea, Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder and cult movie favourite John Saxon, the film has no shortage of talent in the acting department, and Clark delivers quite a few stylish directorial flourishes that really help to crank up the tension.From the get go, Black Christmas introduces plot elements and visual techniques that were to become a staple of stalk 'n' slash movies for years to come: creepy POV shots; the careful framing of shots to reveal movement in the background; the killer's heavy breathing on the soundtrack; the final victim frantically fleeing from the maniac (after having discovered the mutilated bodies of her friends). We also get to see where When A Stranger Calls (1979) got its 'We've traced the call... it's coming from inside the house' moment fromthe exact same thing occurs in Black Christmas!Also particularly effective are the telephone calls made by the maniac; a mixture of unintelligible ranting, guttural moans, violent threats and crude obscenities, they are very unsettling and help convey exactly how demented the (unseen) murderer truly is. Another factor that adds to the creepy vibe of the film is the fact that we never get to find out who the killer is or why he is attacking these seemingly innocent girls. Even at the end, Clark gives nothing away about his identity. By not giving us any background details, or any motivation for his actions, he turns the killer into a 'bogeyman' (another idea borrowed by Carpenter for his movie).Unfortunately, there are also several things that let the film down slightly.Firstly, there is a lack of any really likable characters: Hussey's heroine is rather selfish, Kidder's character is a loud mouthed drunk, and Dullea plays a rather dull and obsessive pianist. Worst of all is the drunken house mother, a nasty woman who thankfully meets a suitably violent end. At least Carpenter had the good sense to make some of his victims a little more likable, thus actually making the audience give a damn about whether they lived or not.Clark also neglects to put in any real scares; creepiness the film has in spades, but genuine shocks are in short supply. And with the few deaths being rather bloodless, the 'yuck' factor is also kept fairly low (unless you find endless shots of a body with a plastic bag over its head particularly nauseating).Lastly, Clark tries to inject some humour into the proceedings, but fails spectacularly: Kidder's weak prank about fellatio is desperately unfunny and the drunken house mother's search for booze is truly cringe-worthy.Black Christmas is a film that all horror fans should see, since it helped to define a whole horror sub-genre, but to say it is better than Halloween is definitely going a step too far.

This is considered a cult, classic and protoslasher, all the terms popular with fans and scholars of genre and slasher filmmaking. It's obvious being made in the mid 70s that the Italian Giallo (POV shots) was popularly used and Bob Clark's earliest entry with Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things also had influence on this film.The innocence of Jess, played by Argentinean Olivia Hussey (real name Olivia Osuna) was perfectly cast opposite of her sorority sisters, like loud-mouthed Barb played by the late Margot Kidder and the outrageous Marian Waldman as the house mother! Supporting actors such cult veteran star, John Saxon and Crononberg's The Brood leading actor, Art Hindle.The rest of the interior location are excellent in creating (although the house is insanely large) claustrophobic and dark. Strong dubbing of the murderer's voice still create a distrubing chill today.Roy Moore wrote this script in his late 20s Bob Clark was not a beginner,he was building a grouping of filmwork. This film precedes the similar plot twists of Halloween and When a Stranger Calls. They are some weak spots in the story but the chill feel of shots, oddly though behind cheerful imagery of Christmas.This is definitely a film that should be seen and appreciate by filmbuffs and horror fans.

The Plot = A group of young college girls decide to stick around they're sorority house for the Christmas holidays, not knowing a mysterious psychopath is hiding in they're attic, making obscene, disturbing phone calls, and that's just the beginning, he eventually proceeds to slaughter the kills one by one in a brutal fashion.Many consider Halloween as the first ever slasher movie but it isn't "Black Christmas" is but sadly this gem never managed the popularity "Halloween" and remained forgotten for years well until they made that not very good remake last year.Black Christmas was and still is bleak movie that packs a punch and gave me genuine goosebumps from beginning to end. I loved the dark imposing claustrophobic feel, the film handled its now known slasher formula like a freaking pro, tossing our way with full force moments of pure shock, a baffling whodunit, hard hitting plot twists and an expert use of the "killer is in the house" motif. The film's firm execution in terms of its conventions. Personally, the element that got under my skin the deepest had to be the killers' phone ramblings. I mean this dude was a hands down, to the core loon. He leaped into these bizarro monologues, taking on different voices (a man, woman, child), going on about things that only he understood while taking the random dramatic pause to slip in a heart felt "I'm gonna kill you" in there. What a CLASS ACT! The phone calls butcher boy (or girl) made, established him early on as one crazy mother to be reckoned with and since we never really got to see the lad throughout (apart from his heart warming toying with his victims' cadavers), that turned him into a constant thick cloud of doom spread wide about this tale. You didn't see him but man did you feel him! The acting was top of it's range in this movie Olivia Hussy (Jess) was solid from beginning to end, Keir Dullea (Peter) played his creepy, neurotic part well, I really enjoyed the house mother Mrs Mac she was great and stole every scene she was in, Margot Kidder was the stand out in this movie and brought in some much needed humor as the alcoholic and chain smoking drunk. Actors always come through when they play themselves. Another statement to that rule applied to John Saxon (LT Fuller) who once more played John Saxon...he was wonderful at it as per usual. Doug McGrath (Nash) was responsible for a few straight chuckles as the incompetent cop.Okay the murders may not be gory but they're still nasty and quite brutal like We get a girl being choked by a plastic bag, a semi blood wet stabbing and after the fact damaged corpses. Although not too graphic, the film still hit hard via the viciousness behind its dirty deeds.The directing was top notch Clark set up an unsettling dark mood from frame one, exploiting his creepy setting fully while giving us hints of slick style on the way (loved the killer POV shots and the slow motion). He also liked to inter-cut murder sequences with mundane events which made the scenes quite effective. And I have to give the man extra credit for two things: 1- That very scary shot of the eyeball (you'll know when u see it) killed me and the ending (which I won't dare give away) was brilliant.All in all Black Christmas is a definite cult classic because it's a well rounded horror flick.

reviews.review_title: "Bye, Baby Bunting, Daddy's Gone A Hunting!"...
reviews.content: It's Christmastime, and a houseful of sorority sisters are leaving for their various holiday destinations. Unbeknownst to the small group staying behind, someone has climbed in through the attic window. This occurs shortly after a series of disturbing, obscene phone calls. When one of the girls vanishes, the fear begins to build. Those who have stayed behind will wish they had gone home this Christmas.During all of this, Jess (Olivia Hussey) is having some serious relationship problems with her intense boyfriend, Peter (Keir Dullea), who doesn't handle the situation very well.Offsetting all of this is the audacious Barb (Margot Kidder). Never without a drink and / or a cigarette, she can't seem to open her mouth without a dirty joke coming out! Barb offers comic relief to the otherwise bleak circumstances. Amazingly, the levity only increases the level of dread!Director Bob Clark's BLACK CHRISTMAS is a yuletide horror classic. Clark wisely chose to keep his madman hidden, making him all the more frightening. Listening closely to the increasingly deranged phone calls, one gets an idea of what sort of person is making them, deepening the sense of unease. We are every bit as clueless as his victims. This holds true even after several viewings!A gripping, highly influential masterpiece.Co-stars John Saxon as police Lt. Fuller...

I'm not sure why a lot of people like this film.  I didn't think it was all that great.  Also known as SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT, directed by Bob Clark of PORKY'S fame, this one involves psychotic killer who hides in the attic of a sorority house and starts killing off all the "girls", one by one.  
I say "girls" because most of them look over 30 instead of 20, especially Margot Kidder as the slutty one with the foul mouth.  (Check out Brian DePalma's SISTERS if you want to see Kidder in a terrifying role)The film does just fine until the last 15 minutes or so when Olivia Hussey goes upstairs to look for her friends and doesn't follow police instructions to leave the house.  What a dumb bitch.  Anybody who is THAT dumb deserves to be killed.It's also pretty obvious 40 minutes into the film who the killer is, but director Clark tries to pull a fast one at the very end of the film by implying that it's not him.  It looks like Clark wants to have it both ways, casting doubt upon the whole thing and trying to leave it open-ended like he does.  There's no gore being shown and very little blood, making the whole thing look pretty tame by today's standards.   In fact, the only thing missing is the ax-wielding Santa.  But no matter folks, that'll come in a later film.The Critical Mass DVD has filmographies for most of the cast along with a short, uninformative interview with Saxon that doesn't reveal much of anything, and no extras from Bob Clark.  At least not in the DVD version I saw.  Maybe Clark was embarrassed by the whole thing, who knows  He should be.3 out of 10

reviews.review_title: The best Christmas horror movie ever
reviews.content:
An unknown, crazed killer stalks girls at a sorority house at Christmas. He also subjects them to multiple obscene 'phone calls, with much use if the c word, they really are quite shocking. Black Christmas really set the template for the slasher movie: sorority girls, high body count, red herrings, point of view shots, brutal murders, etc. Though
to be fair some of these elements were to be found in Italian giallo movies prior. Incredibly creepy and tense throughout, some humour is to be found in the antics of the drunken housemother and of one of the girls, who plays a funny prank at the police station. Great cast, including one of my favourite actors, John Saxon. This is a masterpiece of horror that really needs to be seen at Xmas. Essential viewing on my calendar, ho ho ho!

Pre-dating what is generally considered the ultimate Slasher film by several years - the original "Halloween" - "Black Christmas" is a highly-underrated, and amazing horror-slasher flick which would set the standard for practically every slasher film to follow - from the ringing telephones, the 'don't go upstairs', re-hearings and of course a strong female lead."Black Christmas'" strong female lead is the equally underrated Olivia Hussey, whose fantastic accent is a special bonus to her calm and sympathetic character Jessica. While the majority of slasher films all feature a female lead (though there are exceptions like "A Nightmare on Elm Street 2", "Prom Night 3: The Last Kiss" and "Friday the 13th VI: Jason Lives" which all have a male lead) not every female lead is as terrific as Hussey's Jessica. (Exceptions being Neve Campbell's Sidney from the "Scream" Trilogy, Heather Langenkamp's Nancy from "A Nightmare on Elm Street", Lar Park-Lincoln's Tina from "Friday the 13th VII: The New Blood" and of course Jaime Lee Curtis' Laurie from various "Halloween").Jessica's resourcefulness, and cool personality makes her a character that you really care about, and the fact that she has various real life stories going on (abortion for example - something I don't think has been featured in a slasher since "Black Christmas") makes her a very likable character. The majority of the characters in "Black Christmas" are actually very realistic and likable. Margot Kidder's Barbie provides a lot of the comic relief, but has the most tragic death also. Andrea Martin is excellent as frizzy-haired (though its nice frizzy-hair) Phyllis. John Saxon is always great in his performances, and his role as Lt. Fuller is no exception. Keir Duller does a good job of playing perhaps the most unlikeable, but very realistic, Peter, Jessica's over-bearing and high-strung boyfriend. Marian Waldman is a riot as the house-mother for the sorority girls, Mrs. Mac.The plot, pacing and general story is probably nothing new to anyone who has seen "Scream" or "Halloween", as previously mentioned, many slashers take a least a note or two from "Black Christmas", which does everything splendidly. Great direction, interesting camera angles, a couple of good jump scenes, and then there's the telephone calls...perhaps one of the most disturbing things in all slasher movies.So overall, "Black Christmas" is an amazing slasher-horror film, setting the stage for a myriad of followers over the years, but thirty years later, does not seem out-dated or cheesy. Sure, there's not a lot of gore, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. And for the pre-cursor to the likes of "Halloween" and "Scream" to be this good, then it's certainly worth a watch, even if just to watch for all the things in the film that will eventually become standard conventions in slasher films.

reviews.review_title: Very good horror/who-goes-there film. Eerie and creepy...
reviews.content: As good as they come in this genre. Shall we call it the 'slasher', genre, for lack of a better word?! Four years before Carpenter's classic "Halloween" made its way into moviegoers hearts and minds, this Canadian gem came out in 1974. Bob Clark (the director) was truly a genius in the art of movie making. Innovative in so many ways that I won´t try to cover them all.Filmed in Toronto but supposed to be an American quiet town up north (why not Toronto?), the homicidal maniac "Billy" is very(!) naughty come Christmas. Breaking and entering into a girls sorority house during the Christmas holiday, "Billy" starts acting bad Santa. He´s not giving gifts but taking the poor girls lives instead.Built on tension, mood and suspense, this classic is truly utterly scary and creepy. Watch how Clark uses the panning of the camera to create depth in the house. Eerie as hell! And those chilling and utterly mad phone calls...truly insane. See it on your own risk...

Black Christmas, directed and produced by Bob Clark is one of the best Christmas films ever made! Clark used a lot of vetern film making tools to add a lot of depth and mystery to this film. The story was very fresh, original, and stays on track with great pacing. Black Christmas was not only a Christmas classic, but sparked a lot of influence towards John Carpenter's Halloween, Wes Craven's Scream, and Sean S. Cunningham's Friday The 13th, with it's horror elements & tactics.The lead characters were extremely entertaining, showing a lot of pure emotions. The supportive cast complimented the leads well, because they actually had purpose, unlike most supportive characters in horror and/or Christmas films. I like how Bob Clark made the killer a complete mystery; he didn't even let us see his face! The phone calls and actual physical violence he portrays was vicious, and very creepy.The screenplay by Roy Moore was right to the point, and unfiltered, which I can really appreciate for this kind of film. Some dialogues and scenes got a tad stale, but the screenplay was above average, and carried great merit.There was only a few things that I could really nit pick in this film. The story definitely was original and inspiring to other film makers, but I'd be lying if I said there wasn't a few disposable or dry scenes. Other than that, there's other minor things you could fault, but it's not something that would really bring the rating down.Overall, Black Christmas is a must watch every year before Christmas! You will be hooked from beginning to end!

from what I've heard,this film is supposed to be 'one of the greatest'Truthfully? It's boring. My skin is on too tight, apparently. Seriously, it was just too boring for me. No parts made me jump,hearing a man make disgusting phone calls and screaming like a little kid who didn't get its cookie doesn't cut it for me. But I will admit there was only one good part, is where the eye is in the door way hinges.That scene was entertaining.But doesn't scare me. I definitely wouldn't consider this as 'the greatest' My Bloody Valentine Remake was scarier than this.

reviews.review_title: Still a good movie, but not a horror classic
reviews.content: I enjoyed my first viewing of Bob Clark's "Black Christmas" more than my most recent viewing. I still feel that the film is an accomplished piece of work and established a structure and screen language that have been much imitated. The characters are intelligent and screenwriter Roy Moore even takes a shot at the abortion issue.The obscene phone calls made by the killer are truly obscene (much use of the word "c**t"), and his psychotic rants are rather amusing, if not a little disturbing. The killer's POV, which opens the movie, is effective, and the image of a suffocated victim lurking by a window is a memorable one.The film doesn't scare me, though, or make me uneasy. Perhaps I've seen too many horror films. I can't fault Clark for his direction or Carl Zitter for his atmospheric score, more a soundscape than a traditionally structured series of compositions. I simply found the film a bit slow the last time around.Clark's "Deathdream" is one of my favorite horror films of all time (see my review), and it was made before "Christmas". Certainly, "Christmas" is a larger scale production, but, for me, it does not possess the intimacy of "Deathdream" and the sense of crawling horror. It plays more like a mystery than a horror film and lacks the tragedy that made "Deathdream" so effective. Bob Clark may have thought so, too, because "Christmas"'s score sounds exactly like "Deathdream" (same composer), there is a creepy rocking chair (like the one "Andy" used in Deathdream"), and the house exteriors look like the house exteriors in, yes, you guessed it, "Deathdream".Still, a very good movie, but not, for me, a horror classic.

Love this movie. One of the first and most influential of its kind. A likeable group of sorority girls get stalked from within. Still a pretty creepy movie and holds up well. The ambiguity element really adds a lot to this film in the same way as John Carpenter's The Thing. 10/10 slasher.

Black Christmas, also known as Silent Night, Evil Night (the title they initially gave it for the first American screenings so movie-goers wouldn't mistake it for a blaxploitation film), is generally considered to be one of the first classic slasher flicks, and apparently even had a hand in inspiring John Carpenter's Halloween. But you might know director Bob Clark from a very different Christmas movie - one that will probably be playing on at least one 24-hour loop on some basic cable channel this week - A Christmas Story.It's a shame that this movie didn't get the recognition it deserved at the time, but it has gone on to become a cult horror film in the years since. It's smart, well-acted, wonderfully shot, terrifying, and even genuinely funny at times.** SPOILERS! **I knew I was in for a treat during the opening shots, moving seamlessly between the inside and outside of the beautiful sorority house and showing POV shots of the mysterious killer making his way around the home (I especially loved the shot of him climbing the trellis). There's a great theme throughout of happy, celebratory, or even just mundane things going on in the house while the killer lurks within... super creepy. I think the whole "Babysitter and the Man Upstairs" legend in general is TERRIFYING so the use of it was great - it's one thing to know that the threat is outside trying to get in, but what about when you're locking it inside with you? The search party coming by and almost cheerfully reminding the girls to "just keep your doors and windows locked and you'll be safe!" was a chilling reminder.The phone calls were surprisingly scary - and surprisingly vulgar. The killer's alternating between multiple voices/personalities, seeming to scold himself at times, crying, screaming... the calls became more and more frenzied and his incomprehensible fury makes him unrecognizable as even a human threat. There's no way to know his background, his motives, which makes him terrifying in a much less tangible way. We can't relate to him, we can't see our own pain or shortcomings in his motivation, which makes him completely unpredictable and alien.I enjoyed that, aside from the (possibly unrelated?) girl being killed in the nearby park, the main characters don't have any idea that murder is afoot until it's too late. The victims themselves have NO idea, but even Jess (Olivia Hussey) has no indication that anyone has been killed until she finally swings Barb's bedroom door open in the last 15 minutes or so - we're the only people privy to that information.Speaking of which, the kills - surprisingly few, really, considering its status as a slasher film - are all creative and well done. There's no lingering on blood spurting from knife wounds, no over-exaggerated looks of horror that go on for too long, no shirts being ripped open for no reason besides showing a hint of breasts. They're quick and effective but still fun. My favorite is probably Barb being stabbed with her own crystal unicorn grabbed from behind her bed - shot beautifully and the juxtaposition of Jess listening to a young choir singing carols downstairs is just awesome - but the image of Clare in the rocking chair with the plastic garment bag sucked into her mouth is classic for a reason. That reveal definitely got a gasp from me, and the occasional return to the attic - showing his hand rocking the chair her corpse sat in, or her cat innocently licking the bag she was contained in - was a cruel reminder that the search for her was hopeless.There's no denying that there's a strong feminist undertone to the whole film - or, really, far less subtle than that. This movie taking place in the early 70's - and just a year after Roe v. Wade was decided - is important context for its content. Women being terrorized by a dominating and violent male presence is par for the course for countless horror and slasher films, but it feels more relevant here, more close to home. Barb's murder being the most intimate - taking place in her own bedroom, practically in the throes of sleep, with one of her own belongings - was no accident considering we saw her crassness offend multiple male authority figures (Clare's father and a local sergeant, most obviously, but she fights back - verbally anyway - against the crazed prank caller, too).In addition to the more direct threat of the looming killer, we have more pervasive examples of men attempting to silence women in a variety of ways. The bumbling sergeant first ignoring Clare going missing because she's probably shacked up with some guy and then ignoring the prank calls because it's "probably one of your boyfriends playing a joke". Clare's father is basically just walking disapproval throughout the entire movie, turning his nose up at Mrs. Mac's language, posters around the sorority house, and Barb's attempts to be humorous in her slurred, drunken state.And, more directly, there is Jess informing her boyfriend, Peter (Keir Dullea), in no unclear terms that she is pregnant with his child and seeking an abortion. Again, the freshness of Roe v. Wade in American society informed his hateful response - "don't you think about anyone but yourself", and later "let's get one thing straight: you are not going to abort that baby". He's outraged at the idea that she dare make a decision about her own body without his express approval, and is pushed further into his own spiral of deflecting blame when she rejects his very matter-of-fact marriage proposal. He's belligerent to the point of being rightfully suspected as the killer - especially after seeing him destroy that piano after his unfavorable recital.The irony of such gruesome acts being carried out during what is supposed to be the happiest, coziest time of year is constant but not obnoxiously so - it's more something that we notice rather than something that is being told to us, if that makes sense. The warm glow of the colored Christmas lights, the metallic tinsel on the wreaths, the campus emptying out as people scurry off to see their families... it all feels incredibly nostalgic until we remember there's a goddamn psychopath holed up in the attic.Which leads us to the ending, which is amazingly dark, even for a horror flick. There is so often some kind of humanization of the villain, or maybe a dramatic standoff between the final survivor and the killer. We almost get that, or at least we think we might, when Jess is cowering in the basement after Peter smashes his way in. When the police find her slumped over with a dead Peter on top of her, we think there's a chance - albeit small - that the nightmare is over. Jess has not only defeated her would-be killer, but she's defeated this domineering male presence that is trying to control her. But as the camera pans away from her, sedated in bed, and glides by the attic - mumbling and giggling echoing off the walls - and eventually outside, we hear the phone ringing and ringing as the credits roll, and we're reminded that evil often does prevail.Ultimately, a brilliant and sorely under-appreciated film. Go watch it now, get into the Christmas spirit!

reviews.review_title: it was ok WARNING CONTAINS A SPOILER
