reviews.content: i was reading some of the other comments on this film and most of them say how great and scary this movie is. don't listen to that. i will give this movie one thing it started the horror genre, the way Bob Clark directed it was alot like the way John Carpenter did Halloween, but Halloween blows this movie away, another movie that this is like is Scream with the phone calls, but once again Scream blows this movie away, though i will say the phone calls were good, very strange, my problem with the movie is it is way too slow, put it this way the first hour and ten minutes are kind of a waste, but the final 30 minutes are very good, the concept to the movie is good, the writter fails to bring the goods, it's worth a check though. one other problem i have with this film is you never find out who the killer is. i give it *** out of ***** only cause of the storyline.

reviews.review_title: A horror movie staple/ Nearly forgotten gem
reviews.content: Students of a sorority house start receiving a series of increasingly frightening prank phone calls, escalating into a series of ghastly murder in this effectively creepy tightly-plotted little movie. All of the major actors in it feel real and fleshed out, barring an underused James Edmond as Clair's father. Perhaps it hasn't aged as well as everyone would have hoped, (the abortion sub-plot, really doesn't have anything to do with anything, and some of the dialog comes off as hokey now) but with this and "A Christmas Story" Bob Clark has made two of the staples of holiday viewing, albeit in opposite ends of the spectrum. It's too bad that he hasn't done anything good since 1983.My Grade: A-

reviews.review_title: Superior horror movie, but not as innovative or important as some say
reviews.content: Having read some reviewers say that Halloween was a rip-off of Black Christmas, I watched this movie and I'm relieved to say it's not really the case, since Halloween is the summum of horror movies for me. There is not a lot in common between the two movies that I can think of: madman killing people, heavy breathing/mysterious killer and nice POV camera work. I liked the POV in this movie, but it wasn't as effective as in Halloween because we see from the killer perspective before he commits a murder, therefore there was not really any suspense in those scenes, since we know where the killer is. In Halloween, the POV is used to create suspense when the killer is prowling, but it's not used before the murders, the fear of the unknown is what works best for me in those cases.Also, some people seem to think this movie invented POV in horror movies or the slasher flick. This is far from the truth, people should check some of Mario Bava's work or Peeping Tom. It was still an interesting stepping stone for the genre, but nothing innovative.Still, I found the first half chilling and interesting, but after a few murders, the movie became a little tedious because of the dumb script and predictable plot in the second half. Still, this movie gave me some chills in the first 30 minutes, I liked the bleak ending and the nice camera work and atmosphere, so it all adds up to a superior horror movie, well worth seeing but not quite a classic.7/10

An obscene phone calling maniac living in the attic of a sorority stalkscoeds during the Christmas season. Exceptionally well directed and crafted film features the right amount of humor and chills to keep you at the edge of your seat. The film grips you into it early on with a frightening phone call and keeps you in its grip all the way untill the finish with a bone chilling ending. Olivia Hussey turns in an excellent performance as the pregent heroine, Keir Duella is terrifying as Hussey's controlling boyfriend,  and Margot Kidder is an absolute riot as a druken sorority sister.Trivia note: Film predates both Halloween and When A Stranger Calls by several years. These films both have similar premises to Black Christmas.
Rated R; Violence and Profanity.

reviews.review_title: Horrendously overrated as far as I'm concerned.
reviews.content: Black Christmas is set in a girls sorority house around Christmas, one of the girls Clare Harrison (Lynne Griffin) is spending the festive season with her father at home but is brutally killed in her room before she meets up with him. The next morning & her dad (James Edmond) raises the alarm & contacts the police who organise a search where they find the dead body of a young child, meanwhile the sorority house has been receiving obscene phone calls which they tell the police about. Lieutenant Fuller (John Saxon) decides all the clues point the the sorority house with very good reason as there's a killer on the loose inside...This Canadian production was produced & directed by Bob Clark & I have to say I think Black Christmas is vastly overrated, considered by some to be the very first slasher film ever made I'd personally say it's more of a thriller although I can see why some would say that. The script by Ray Moore is very serious & tries to build tension up & remain quite taught but I have to say I was pretty bored by it. It takes ages to do anything & then we get the god awful ending, some people complain about horror films not having much of a story & Black Christmas would almost certainly give those people more ammunition as the killer is never seen, the killer's motives are never revealed neither is the basic question of who he is. I'm sorry but even Jason Voorhees & Freddy Kruger had back stories, at least they had some sort of motive no matter how flimsy it was while here in Black Christmas there is nothing. Some may like the ambiguity & sure it works well enough for most of the film but I'd have liked some sort of pay-off, some sort of explanation, some sort of twist, some sort of story behind the killer & a proper ending, you see Black Christmas doesn't so much as end as just stops. On the plus the plus side it's watchable, the character's are good & more human than in a lot of horror films although for me that's just not enough to want to sit through 100 minutes of this again.Since it was Chritsmas Day only a few days ago Black Christmas was an appropriate film to sit down & watch last night & director Clark does a really good job here & the films best asset is it's atmosphere & style, there are some great point-of-view shots from the killer's perspective & there's definitely a creepy chilly atmosphere to it. The film looks quite gritty & is far less glossy than the average Hollywood flick which helps it as well but despite some good visuals & a nice dark atmosphere I still didn't like the story & that's what really sinks Black Christmas for me. The body count is low & there's absolutely zero gore. Was it just me or did anyone else have problems understanding the obscene phone calls? I mean the guy speaking sounding like he was doing a bad Donald Duck impression! The ending doesn't work either on a factual level, the cops wouldn't leave Jessica alone in the house after what she had just gone through & considering what had just taken place they wouldn't have left the house anyway let alone not even bother searching the attic.Technically the film is well made & is pretty impressive, shot on location in Toronto, Ontario in Canada. The acting is fine, the likes of Kier Dullea, Ovlia Hussey, Margot Kidder & genre favourite John Saxon put in good performances.Black Christmas is considered by some to be the very first slasher film ever made which I can see why while other's claim it's the best slasher ever made which I can't agree with at all as I think it's one of the most overrated, I'm not saying it's a bad film by any stretch of the imagination it's just one that I personally didn't like & can't see why so many people do despite their reasoning. Remade by Hollywood as Black Christmas (2006) which I actually prefer as it has more of a story.

.... would be a more appropriate name for this thoroughly dull supposed shocker, which rarely rises above indifferent.WARNING: REVIEW CONTAINS MAJOR SPOILERS. ONLY READ IF YOU'VE SEEN THE FILM.John Saxon and Margot Kidder try gamely with a feeble script that tries to offset it's own predictability by crowbarring in misfiring comic setpieces. Not only do these work against the tone of the piece, they also distract from the main plot. The plot itself is so tedious that we have to wait until the last twenty minutes for the police to work out the killer's been in the house all along... something we were shown from the very beginning. This irritating game of catch-up is only expounded upon by the "twist" ending, which must be obvious even to an amoeba, and a hundred times more obvious to anyone who's seen that particular episode of Alfred Hitchcock Presents.To make matters worse, when this movie was shown on American TV they changed the name to Stranger In The House. Wow, what a sensible network decision that was! I wonder if the same network changed the name of Citizen Kane to It's His Sled and Planet of the Apes to It's Earth All Along Really, You Know. This is not even to mention the classic character stupidity, with Olivia Hussey being told to leave the house by the police. So does she get out and leave? Guess. People that stupid and annoying deserved to be butchered by an unfrightening mad axeman.

reviews.review_title: Prototypical and exemplary slasher-film with a realistic and suspenseful atmosphere
reviews.content: Say 'Slasher Film' and most people will probably say 'Scream', 'Friday the 13th', or 'Halloween'what's more, most will probably be referring to the franchises each of these has spawned rather than have a particular movie in mind. The fact that (despite the inevitable and tired re-make) most people don't know about/haven't seen 'Black Christmas' is certainly criminal as in terms of chills, suspense, and quality of filmmaking it is far ahead of virtually every other film in the slasher genre. What's more, 'Black Christmas has the prestige of being (after respectful nods have been made towards 'Silent Night. Bloody Night' and some Italian gialli) the film which kick-started the genre.As befitting a slasher film, the set-up will be familiar: a group of teenagers, here composed of a group of Sorority girls and a few boyfriends, are picked off one-by-one by a maniacal killer. In addition, other slasher tropes like the menacing phone-calls-coming-from-inside-the-house, the holiday theme, and the (kind of) final girl really do put most viewers in a state where surprises are not to be expected. However, 'Black Christmas' certainly raises itself above the imitations that followed in presenting a realistic and engaging atmosphere which captures the suspense of what is, when looked at without cinematically desensitized eyes, a scary idea: a mentally deranged person killing without apparent motive. The realistic touch comes from the pared down direction which is reminiscent (or should that be prescient?) of Carpenter's approach in Halloween, the time taken to build up a relationship with the characters, the absence of over-the-top Tom Savini-style "kills" (which have the effect of distancing the viewer from the fact that someone has died), and a thankful absence of the strained conservative moral message that teenagers should listen to adults and avoid drugs and sex before marriage etc.It is a wonder this film is not more widely recognised. I believe it is due to the fact that it doesn't present us with a tangible figure of fear like Myers, Voorhees, Freddy, the Fisherman, or Ghostface etc who, even though masked, nonetheless localise and personify fear and in doing so suggest ways to combat it. In contrast, 'Black Christmas', apart from a startling eyeball shot, offers us nothing to hang our fear (and our consumerist franchise fetishes) on. As such, while 'Black Christmas' and its killer may not have entered the pop-culture lexicon, this has meant that the film has retained its power and sense of discomfort and maybe, like the killer, the film belongs in the periphery where most people don't look.

reviews.review_title: It's the season to be sadist...fallalalla lala la la!
reviews.content: Considering the time it was released, this 'Black Christmas' must be regarded as slightly more important than your average slasher in which gorgeous sorority babes are being exterminated. Black Christmas is a trendsetter, opening the gates for Michael Myerses and Jason Vorheeses who'll only be popular several years later. The plot is as simple as it ever wasbut here, it's new and even rather courageous! Lovely looking girls harassed by obscene phone calls and stalked by a familiar killer. Imaginatively timed around the holiday-season when the university babes are in a party mood and packing to spend Christmas with their families. Producer-director Bob Clark (who regretfully continued his career with horny adolescent crap like 'Porky's') uses many horror-clichés for the first time here: dumb cops, scream-queens, the isolated location of a fraternity house and the different stereotype-categories of female students. And  most of all  Black Christmas contains an old-fashioned scariness, still efficient even by today's horror standards. Finally, there still is room for comical undertones and good acting. The eminent John Saxon, but also the beautiful looking Olivia Hussey and Margot Kidder (Lois Lane!!!) Horror fans can't afford themselves to skip this one. Black Christmas is a modest milestone in the field of scary cinema.

reviews.review_title: Very Good Early Example Of The "Slasher" Genre
reviews.content: It would be an exaggeration to suggest that "Black Christmas" gave birth to the slasher genre. It is, however, without any doubt one of the best of the early examples of the genre, and it's very obvious that it provided at least some inspiration to what I would still consider to be the absolute best of the genre - John Carpenter's "Halloween" which came out a few years later. Carpenter (at least in his first Halloween film) learned a lesson from "Black Christmas" that a lot of later slasher films forgot - the "horror" isn't in blood and gore and overly and unnecessarily graphic violence, and you don't need naked young women to keep people watching! There are no naked young women in this (although there's sexual content in the phone calls) and "Black Christmas" actually contains surprisingly little blood and gore. Really there's only one scene - the only murder that's actually depicted, and certainly by modern standards it's not particularly graphic. The film creates its horror and suspense through the use of atmosphere and setting - and by letting the viewers in on what's happening from the start. We may not know who the killer is, but we know that the killer is in the house - which makes this all the more suspenseful, because at literally any moment of any scene set in the house, something could happen. That really very little does happen only heightens the expectation.The story revolves around a sorority house just before Christmas. As the movie opens, while a party is going on inside, a stranger (whom we never see) climbs the side of the house and gets into the attic. We're than introduced to the fact that the girls in the house have been getting a series of creepy obscene phone calls. The story builds from there as the first girl is killed, and while it takes a while for anyone else to die, that sets the stage for a truly creepy movie watching experience. The ambiguous open ending also provided obvious inspiration for later similar films that left similar open and ambiguous endings, but perhaps kept returning to the well too often.The cast is pretty decent. Apparently the producers tried to recruit some pretty big name people for this (I understand, for example, that Bette Davis was approached to play the role of the house mother) but couldn't get them. In the end, we got early film appearances from people who became fairly recognizable in later years, especially Margot Kidder, who played the drunken Barb. This is certainly deserving of recognition as an influential film that helped in the rise of a genre that has sadly now often chosen to focus on blood and gore more than story. (7/10)

Now this is what a slasher flick should be. Four years before the unprecedented success of John Carpenter's landmark American horror film "Halloween" in 1978, there was this little gem from Canada called "Black Christmas," directed in 1974 by the late Bob Clark ("A Christmas Story," my #4 favorite film of all time and Clark's possible anti-thesis to this film), and was arguably the first true slasher film (1974 was also the same year that American filmmaker Tobe Hooper directed the landmark "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre")."Black Christmas" is an expertly directed horror film, there's no question about that. The story is incredibly simple, yet stylishly executed. It's deliberately and excellently paced by Bob Clark, who skillfully injects the film with a wicked sense of dread from the get-go, undercut with some slickly timed dark humor (a lot of which is actually quite hilarious). Said humor is appropriately biting and deserves some well-placed laughs but unlike most movies to mix comedy and horror, "Black Christmas" doesn't sacrifice one for the other. In other words, what starts out as a serious thriller doesn't devolve into a mindless, gore-filled slapstick comedy (like "Evil Dead II," which I love by the way). First and foremost, this is a horror film - a seriously effective and scary one at that.Upon having watched "Black Christmas," there's no doubt in my mind that John Carpenter and company watched this film at least once (and took some very, very good notes) and it most definitely played a hand in influencing the directorial style of "Halloween" (although it's widely known that Alfred Hitchcock's landmark 1960 thriller "Psycho" had the most influence on "Halloween"). (Even though I've never uncovered any information pertaining to this claim, anyone who watches "Black Christmas" and then re-watches "Halloween" will see some of the elements that undoubtedly influenced the latter film. I love "Halloween," by the way, and having this information on-hand makes me appreciate both films even more as seriously scary horror flicks.)What makes "Black Christmas" such an important staple in the horror genre is that a lot of the slasher movie elements that most likely first appeared in this film were later used, and popularized, by "Halloween" just four years later down the road. Most importantly, is the fact that many times throughout the picture, the film is shown from the point-of-view of an unseen killer. We many times see his actions as he goes about the prowl for potential victims, in this case the residents of the Pi Kappa Sig sorority house. We also hear his breathes as he stalks the house sisters, and he is always that unseen-but-always-felt presence in the room, like something horrible is lurking just out of sight in the shadows.The women of the Pi Kappa Sig house are preparing to leave for the Christmas holidays, but a few - Jess (Olivia Hussey), Barb (Margot Kidder), Phyl (Andrea Martin), and house mother Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) - decide to stay behind. However, someone has been making obscene phone calls to the house and scaring the living daylights out of the women. And it isn't long before the unseen presence begins to systematically eliminate the women in some particularly gruesome and creative ways. It's up to the police, led by Lt. Fuller (John Saxon), to try to find this psycho before he kills anyone else.Even though "Black Christmas" does feature some particularly gruesome and shocking scenes of murder and mayhem, it actually contains very little gore (it's possible that it, like "Halloween," took a few cues from "Psycho"), the film still works largely through the power of suggestion - like what you don't see is far more terrifying because your mind allows you to fill in the gaps. Additionally, there's also a very low body count.It's entirely possible that Olivia Hussey was probably the original scream queen, although, like the actress has said herself in interviews included on the 2006 special edition DVD, she actually doesn't do any screaming in the movie. All the characters in this film are three-dimensional and likable, especially Margot Kidder's drunken party-girl Barb. She was probably my favorite character. Kidder, who is probably most famous in the cinematic world for her work as Lois Lane in the "Superman" series films - "Superman II" (1980) saw her at her best, in my opinion - gets some of this film's best lines and also provides some of the best comedic moments. This is another aspect of "Black Christmas" that I find so ingenious: to create so many likable characters so it's much more tragic when the Unseen Killer begins offing them. It's just a shame that its many, many like-minded imitators (or even its 2006 remake) over the years didn't follow the same pattern."Black Christmas" is a film that I've wanted to see for a long time. All the good things I've heard about it are true. This is one scary fright flick that helped give birth to a new sub-genre of horror, and later influenced "Halloween," "Friday the 13th" (1980) and my favorite slasher flick of all time, "A Nightmare on Elm Street" (1984). It's also pretty funny, which admittedly, I was unprepared for, and made my appreciation for this film even greater. But make no mistake, the first order of business in "Black Christmas" is horror, and scaring the living daylights out of you, which it does in spades with suspense, easily identifiable and memorable characters (especially Margot Kidder - go, Margot!), Bob Clark's sharp direction, and minimal gore. So don't let its imitators fool you. "Black Christmas" is one holiday-themed horror film that has you re-thinking those yuletide celebrations.I dare you to watch it alone.10/10

reviews.review_title: Not the type of film I'd watch over the holidays, but much better than I expected.
reviews.content: The mixture of the holiday season and slasher horror isn't exactly what I'd call a proper mix for the Christmas season, but for some reason, this one comes off unscathed thanks to a tense atmosphere aided by a witty screenplay. it deals with three women staying at their sorority for the holidays, Olivia Hussey, Margo Kidder and Andrea mtartin, and stalked by a psychotic killer who keeps calling them with very spooky threats. The audience witnesses one of the girls, preparing to leave, becoming a victim of the killer, and her disappearance is what sets off the mystery. Marian Waldman, as the dipsomaniac house mother, steals the film, obviously emulating veteran comic Patsy Kelly with her boisterous manner. Then there's John Saxon as the police lieutenant, perplexed by the incompetence of his sergeants and doing his best to solve the mystery.The young Margo Kidder is very funny as an extremely sarcastic and foul mouthed student, very sexually graphic in her manner and not someone who will be told to act like a lady. Ironic, it's the sweet looking hussy who is pregnant out of wedlock, threatening to get an abortion and threatened by her boyfriend who is against it. The young Andrea Martin, long before she became famous for her comic portrayals and show stopping stage roles, is their nerdy friend, staying put even though there is danger around.This is one of those films I have avoided watching simply because I don't think that the holidays should be exploited like this but I did find this much better once I got into it. Taking it several steps beyond the TV movie thriller very popular at this time especially those surrounding sorority girls in jeopardy, this manages to take a rather exploitive premise and makes it gripping. It's not the gore that becomes scary. It's the frightening phone calls with sound effects and screams that will really keep you on edge. I may not wrap this up to put it under my Christmas tree, but I am glad that I did not avoid watching it when the opportunity came around.

A group of sorority girls are gradually picked off by an omnipresent but unseen obscene phone-caller. 'Black Christmas' was one of the first offerings in a soon to be bloated, derivative genre and needs to be considered (or blamed) accordingly. Compared to a 'modern' sorority-splatter-sicko-saga, the gore is kept to a minimum, the victims are competent actresses who remain clothed, and more attention is given to the ancillary story (in this case, the police attempts to trace the calls). Versatile director Bob Clark ('Porky's' (1981), 'A Christmas Story' (1983) ?!) does a good job of maintaining a creepy tension (nowadays, nothing would be a surprise, then, I suspect that there were shocked viewers) but I found the ending a bit abrupt. Watchable for what it is but a must see for discerning slasher-fans or Christmas movie completists.

Black Christmas - 1974.( This Films Rates B+ )
After a disturbing obscene phone call, a sorority house is stalked during Christmas break. Its really so 1970's, scenery and all, but the atmosphere is perfectly dark and creepy. The phone calls are deeply disturbing even by today's standards. Not always the best acted, sometimes bad, sometimes good and sometimes just stupid and funny. Like, what? "Fellatio - 2 8 8 0". Not much gore and often times very predictable, yet still genuinely effective. There are plots holes for sure and the killer isnt always the most believable person. You'll see lots of Christmas decorations so you can feel festive enough for this to be a Christmas movie. Is that really the dumbest cop ever? And whats up with those random Christmas carolers around the one hour mark or the search party not long after. Ultimately the ending makes the movie even if slightly absurd, but those camera angles!

reviews.review_title: Might Have Been Impressive Way Back When... But Kind Of Old Hat Now...
reviews.content: BLACK CHRISTMAS (2 outta 5 stars)I remember that this movie was a big deal (at least in Canada) back in 1974. It was a huge hit and audiences raved about how scary it was.  This was a slasher movie that pre-dated Halloween and Friday the 13th... it probably didn't seem as cliched then as it does now.  In fact, a lot of scary movies that came out later sure seem to have been influenced by this one.  Young women in a large, spooky sorority house are plagued by weird, obscene phone calls... and then mysteriously they start to vanish, one by one... victims of a crazed psycho killer (sound familiar yet?)  The movie is competently-made... but the acting is very uneven.  SCTV's Andrea Martin plays one of the sorority girls and it's a little difficult to accept her in a "straight" role... as accustomed as we are to see her making fun of movies like this.  Margot Kidder plays another of the girls... the wild, outspoken, rebellious one (might as well have a target pinned to her back... dang!) The rest of the actors are Canadian performers of varying degrees of competence.  Some of the scenes are suspenseful... even if some of the goings-on defy logic and/or common sense.  (I mean, really...can nobody SEE the dead girl's body sitting right beside the upstairs window?)

Directer: Bob Clark, Script:Roy Moore, Cast: Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, Keir Dullea, John Saxon.This is one of my all time favorite horror/slasher/thrillers. It is about a group of sorority girls that are being terrorized by a psychopath. Christmass vacation has just started in this small college town(actually Toronto!) so most of the girls have left the sorority house leaving few behind.At the beginning of the film we see some unknown person climbing up into the house. This,of course, is the killer. The girls start to receive very disturbing phone calls(from inside the house!). This guys voice still gives me the creeps. The girls are not threatened at first. They think it is just some sicko pervert(sorority houses probably get a lot of calls like that!)but the calls get more violent and numerous. Eventually,the girls start to come up missing. When the dead body of a young girl is found in a nearby park, they get downright scarred.This movie has a great cast and a great sense of style. Olivia Hussey was a classic 70's beauty(she became popular after doing Romeo and Juliet). She add class to this movie. Margot Kidder is hilarious as the raunchy fowl mouthed Barbie. That fellatio joke is classic! This movie has some very funny moments but it does not distract from the horror. John Saxon, horror movie icon, plays the police detective. Kier Dullea(from 2001: a space odyssey)plays his rather dry self but it is adequate for the part.We never see the characters face in this movie. It is the atmosphere and the sense of unknown that makes this movie scary. This movie has no real gore yet it has some of the best death scenes in horror. Wait till you see how Margot Kidder dies, it is rather unique! The first girl that he kills he does so by suffocating her in a plastic bag. He then sticks her up in the attic. She is shown from time to time in the the attic on a rocking chair---creepy! This movie also has a creepy ending.This film is one of the greats of the horror genre yet it seems to be often overlooked. The problem might have been timing. It was made right after The Exorcist and and the same time as Texas Chainsaw. I think it got overshadowed by both of these films. No doubt it had a huge influence in the slasher sub-genre that would continue with Halloween and Friday the 13th. Bob Clark is a rather diverse director. He did movies from the teen sex comedy Porky's to the warm family film A Christmass Story. Black Christmass is to be remade in 2006 with Clark serving as executive producer.

reviews.review_title: Gives birth to other slasher films!
reviews.content:
Before "Halloween", before "Friday the 13th", before "A Nightmare on Elm Street", there's "Black Christmas". It's the holidays, and a group of sororities are either staying over, or going home for the holidays. They would get a obscene phone call, and all they could hear are grunts and moans. And a few explicit words from the caller. They would notify the police about the calls, but one of the sorority members goes missing. What is even worse, that a young girl was killed nearby the house.
Not only is it the earlier slasher movie, but it also gives birth to "When a Stranger Calls" a few years later. This is one movie, no one needs to forget.
4 out of 5 stars

reviews.review_title: A Christmas Horror Classic That Will Send Shivers Up And Down Your Spine.
reviews.content: The movie starts out with a prowler/killer approaching the Phi Kappa Sigma Sorority house. The girls are throwing a Christmas party, they have no idea that a stranger has gotten into the house. Later that night, they start getting strange phone calls from a guy using 3 different voices. One is a perverted voice, the other Billy; and someone named Agnes. Barb( Margot Kidder) answers the phone, and she just laughs it off like who cares. Claire ( Lynne Griffin) who is leaving for the break to meet her father, doesn't take it lightly, leaves to finish packing upstairs. While packing she is suffocated with a plastic bag, and taken up to the attack. When Claire's father comes the next day and explains she didn't show up; red flags are raised. Jess( Olivia Hussey) gets Barb, and Phil(Andrea Martin) to file a report at the police department. The first time they go the Desk Sgt. Nash( Doug McGrath) doesn't take it seriously. When a girl is murdered in the park close by and the calls are still happening, Lt Ken Fuller(John Saxon) gets involved. The calls still come and this time they seem personal like only someone close to her would know.Jess, has her own problems, especially how will she tell her boyfriend Perter(Keir Dulla) she's pregnant. She goes to the conservatory, and tells him she wants an abortion. When she tells him he flips, he is high strung and orders her around. He's control freak who is threatening; and could go off like a firework . When Jess gets back she gets another call, and it sounds so much like Peter; that it's chilling. Peter is weird he sneaks in the house to take a nap, and approaches Jess like a creep. When I first saw this movie I thought Peter was the killer, but who's Billy? While watching this movie I notice that the killer wears the same clothes Pete wears. I also think he and the killer look alike, i.e. when Barb gets killed the killer resembles him to a T. I do think he made some of the calls from the upstairs phone; because he was in the house at the time she receive one.That one she got got the phone company involved. When Jess was on the phone to the police Peter started down the stairs. Jess had no idea he was there; and too me that's a little unnerving.When a tap is put on the line on the two phones downstairs. Lt Fuller and lineman Graham(Les Carlson) tells Jess in order to catch the person, she needs to keep them on the line. Phil has a talk with Jess before she goes to bed. Jess thinks it could be Peter, but isn't sure. Phil gives her some advice, then goes to bed. Ten minutes later a call comes in, and they get the location. Sgt. Nash phones Lt. Fuller and tells him the calls are coming from inside the house. When Nash calls Jess and tells her the news, she warns Barb and Phil. When she discovers they have been murdered, and the killer is still in the room. Jess fights back and escapes to the basement. It's about two minutes later, Peter shows up and knocks on the basement window. He eventually gets in, but Jess doesn't trust him. She ends up killing him with a fire poker. Afterwards when they find Jess, people in the background think he is the killer or is he? I loved this movie especially the joke on Sgt. Nash. One thing this move has in it is a little comic relief, especially the Fellatio joke on Nash. There were others, but that one had me going for awhile.I didn't see this movie until after the re-make came out, the original is always the best. Too me I think there could have been two killers Peter and Billy. Peter was just so creepy, and was always around when someone was killed. The whole sneaking in the house to take a nap; WTF-WHO DOES THAT/? This is a fact, this movie is a must see. If this movie doesn't give you the creeps, check your pulse.

My expectations for "Black Christmas" were high, but somehow the film just doesn't deliver. The atmosphere is creepy and builds tension, the characters are developed, there is even a marginal attempt at humor, but ultimately I was disappointed. My biggest objection is the unresolved ending. I realize this begs for a sequel, but the story is so simple, that a second film really has nowhere to go. Another problem is the movie is very claustrophobic, with the camera constantly tracking the unseen killer throughout the sorority house. John Saxon seems wasted and his screen time insufficient. "Black Christmas" would make a superior short, but at 98 minutes, it is way too long for such slight material. - MERK

reviews.review_title: May have Inspired Halloween, but Nowhere Near as Scary
reviews.content: Very good pioneering slasher film, but it is simply not in the same league as Halloween. Don't be fooled by the lovers of this film who say it's better; while good, it's definitely not near the classic that Halloween is.Olivia Hussey just does not demonstrate the same fear that Jamie Lee Curtis does and John Saxon appears too cool as a cumber to match the "everyone needs to be afraid" distraught characterization that Donald Pleasance brought to his authority figure.Margot Kidder, however, shines as the comic relief, better than the similar characters in Halloween. But finally, the killer just does not create the same sense of doomsday that Michael Myers does.All in all, an entertaining and early slasher film for which it deserves credit, but it's not the opus that some reviewers would have you believe.

reviews.review_title: Cold, classy, and straightforward; still manages a good slice of old-fashioned suspense.
reviews.content: Black Christmas isn't the horror film that started it all. In fact, it isn't even perfect horror to begin with, however, it's certainly one not to be missed. Directed by Bob Clark, creator of the childhood comedy A Christmas Story, Black Christmas is undeniably a somewhat agitated and graphic film for the time it was made. It features above marginal acting as well from Margot Kidder, John Saxon, Keir Dullea and Olivia Hussey. The film has a great advantage though of good acting by the female leads played by Kidder and Hussey and there isn't a lot of gore, which proves Clark relies on good Hitchcokian suspense to scare, making the film not to be hampered by typical gatutus sex, nudity, gore, or sleaze.The story is about an obscene phone caller that dials up a sorority house. Finally the police trace the calls... and he's in the house!!!! Along the way, Black Christmas has the sorority girls go vanishing one by one. Still they don't really get it, going about their drunken holiday revelry without a care. The movie has several very interesting plot twists, but perhaps for new viewers it's now predictable and sometimes frustrating, such as the entire concept that we never really see the killer, who hides in the attic the entire time. Suspicions are cast on the crazy-boyfriend-as-a-potential-suspect (Dullea) of the coed (Hussey) that survives the longest, but his creepiness is never fully explored.Overall, while Black Christmas is innovative but made a strong attempt at suspense and terror, it would easily inspire many latter-day horror movies like Student Bodies, When a Stranger Calls, Silent Night, Deadly Night, Halloween, just to name a few, its progeny wouldn't always improve on the formula. Highly recommended!!!

Not gonna lie i was pretty excited to see this film ,i mean how little slasher films are based around christmas holidays, but and the end i was left dissapointed black christmas end up being film with bunch of phone calls and nothing more only towards end it started to show what we love in slashers but by then it was already to late to satify me

I watched this movie because I was told it was an over-looked classic. After watching it, I now know why it's "over-looked". This movie may have came out before Halloween, but it's inferior in every possible way to Carpenter's masterpiece. For starters, the amount of plot holes in this film is large. One glaring one being when Billy makes the phone calls and screams at the top of his lungs from supposedly in the house, nobody hears him. I can't fathom that. They must of been deaf. I'm still also confused as to how Billy can make those calls inside the house. How can he dial the same number from a phone inside the same house? Aren't all of the lines connected? Why would the phone ring? It makes no sense to me. I also found it funny how the cops didn't seem to bother checking around the house to find any bodies...as the body upstairs of the first girl murdered is shown at the ending.All and All, I felt this movie was poorly written. It didn't scare me one bit. If anything I laughed multiple times at the bad acting and incoherent rants from Billy. It gets a 4/10 from me, and that's being generous.

reviews.review_title: The scariest film of all time.
reviews.content: I've just watched this again for the umpteenth time. It never ceases to terrify me. This is the ultimate scary movie.My Dad recorded this from the TV back in the early 80's when i was little and my Mum told me under no circumstances am I to watch this film which was a total red rag to a bull. So i managed to watch it at some point...alone and my God I wished I hadn't.Set in a Sorority house and the girls are receiving obscene phone calls (and I mean obscene). Can't really say anything more without spoilers.This film gets creepier and creepier as it progresses and by the end you should be terrified. To get the best effect, watch it alone with all the lights off.....if you dare.

Black Christmas (1974) ** 1/2 (out of 4) Bob Clark's cult classic about a maniac terrorizing girls at a sorority house. There's no doubt this is the film that started all the 'stalk and slash' films and it's clear to see this film's influence on Halloween and while I respect this film a lot I really can't say I enjoyed all of it. There are some really great moments scattered throughout the film but at the same time I feel there are some pretty slow moments. The greatest thing is the terrific atmosphere that Clark's able to build from the terrific opening scene. I liked that fact that Clark went for atmosphere over gore and the final thirty minutes are full of suspense. The problem I have is the first hour, which is just too slow for me. I don't mind a slowly paced film but I thought everything dealing with the search of the missing girl really took away from what was important and that was the killer and the phone calls. The performances are better than average and of course there's John Saxon who's always worth watching. Again, the film has a lot of respect from me but there needed to be a few more changes to make it real good.

reviews.review_title: not scary, but disturbing and entertaining movie
reviews.content: after watching black Christmas,i have to say it wasn't scary,so much as disturbing.sort of along the line of the original when a stranger calls,except in a sorority house.in fact when a stranger calls came out five years later and almost certainly borrowed its premise from black Christmas,though it was less entertaining and not as well done.black Christmas also had some humour in it,mainly in the form of the sorority house mother mrs mac,played by marian waldman,who had more than a bit of a drinking problem and was very liberal in her use of questionable language.also providing some humour was margot kidder, who played barbi,one of the sorority sisters.the characters in black Christmas were not as developed as they could have been,but from what we are shown of them,they are likable.this movie was entertaining, though as i said not,scary and not overly suspenseful.in fact it could have worked equally well as simply a drama.there is some very course language in the form of the psychopath,so if you are easily offended by very foul language,you won't like this movie.otherwise you could do a lot worse with your time .if you enjoy or have enjoyed black Christmas, then you should check out the 2006 remake of when a stranger calls,which is far superior to the original.as for black Christmas, 6* out of 10

Before I sat down to watch "Black Christmas" (1975) for the first time, director Bob Clark had been two for two with me. I had loved his previous two flicks--the zombie gut-muncher "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things" and his living-dead Vietnam vet horror comedy "Deathdream," both from 1972--and so was very stoked to see "Black Christmas," a film with a great rep and a loving cult behind it. Now that I have finally seen the film, I'm aware of what this cult has known for decades: This movie, besides being highly influential, is also intelligently scripted, well acted by all, deliberately paced and, ultimately, extremely suspenseful. Concerning a psychopathic nutjob who not only makes obscene phone calls to a sorority house (possibly the creepiest phone calls in screen history; you'll be thanking heaven for modern-day "caller ID"), but who also hides in the attic and does some occasional butchering, the film is the template for a raft of more famous slasher flicks that followed. Margot Kidder, Andrea Martin and especially the gorgeous Olivia Hussey (I just love the way she says "Hello") are all very fine, and John Saxon, here playing a police lieutenant, gets a chance to show how very appealing he can be when NOT playing coldhearted dirtbags. I must confess that the first time I watched this film, the open-ended finale left me a little annoyed (I guess I needed a bit more closure); I didn't mind this ending the second time I watched the picture, however, and even thought it kinda cool and freaky. To make things even better, the "Special Edition" DVD that I just watched comes with almost two hours' (!) worth of interviews, plus other features. It is truly a godsend for all members of the "Black Christmas" cult.

~Spoiler~ Black Christmas is a mainstay of slasher cinema. It is one of the early films that set the standard for what would come. But if you are going to enjoy the movie, I must warn you of the hype. Black Christmas was said to have been better than Halloween by many people. I had heard this on numerous occasions before watching the film. I should have known that was untrue (Halloween in one of my favorite films). That stigma may have hindered my enjoyment of the movie somewhat. Now, don't let my complaints lead you away from the picture. Regardless of a little over hyping, it is a must-see. I wouldn't say that Halloween is in any way, shape, or form a copy of Black Christmas, but John Carpenter may owe a bit to the film. The opening shots of the film beautifully utilize the POV shots we are used to seeing in countless slasher films. And of course the holiday title is something Bob Clark should be thanked for. What Clark did differently was to break almost every slasher film rule before they were even written. In a normal flick, the people who have sex get it first and the heroine is always virginal. Not so in this case. The first girl killed is the virgin and our heroine is far from virginal: she's pregnant! It is very unconventional and impressive in that regard. Also impressive is John Saxon, as always. The man is a genre icon. Actually, the acting from everyone in the film is superb. I found that to be another surprising factor. But with names like Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, and Art Hindle I should have expected quality performances. My main complaint is the pacing and the ending. The film crawls along a bit before really picking up and the ending isn't justified. I like the fact that the killer does not die and his motives go completely unexplained. I thought that was brilliant. The problem with the ending is that there is no reason why the girl is left alone in that house. Why did everyone just disappear? Shouldn't she have been rushed to the hospital? Much like the ending of Poltergeist (where the family stays in the house one more night), there isn't sufficient enough reason for what happened. But the final shots would have lost their impact without a helpless girl still in the house. So despite a few flaws and its hype of being better than Halloween, I would say you couldn't go wrong revisiting this holiday classic. Avoid the remake AT ALL COSTS!
One of the creepiest and most effective slasher films ever made. A criminally underrated masterpiece of slasher cinema.

I'll keep this short because I'd rather not spend much time dwelling on this movie. I found this movie to be highly overrated, boring and grossly irritating. It's comical to say this gave birth to the slasher genre and for movies like Halloween and Friday the 13th owe their existence to this dull flick. The acting was as putrid as the direction of the film. The only redeeming part of the movie was John Saxon and that's solely due to him being in Nightmare on Elm St. People give the remake a hard time, but it's much more entertaining than this dumpster fire of a movie. I'd rather watch a marathon of Lifetime movies before ever being subjected to this pile of garbage again.

reviews.review_title: You couldn't pay me enough money to get me to go in that attic.
reviews.content: Random thoughts about this chilling classic: Several years before John Carpenter's wildly overrated Halloween, there was Bob Clark's Black Christmas, quite possibly the best, most underrated horror/ thriller ever produced. Presumably, Carpenter shares this adoration, as Halloween is, at times, a scene-for-scene ripoff.Sweet girl Claire is the first one to be killed in a surprisingly brutal burst of violence by a psycho killer stalking a sorority house at Christmastime. Her dead body, with a plastic coat bag wrapped over her head, is a chilling sight (one which was, unfortunately, revealed on the front cover of the original video box!) Her father then shows up to search for her, around the same time another girl is attacked in the park, and ..... a string of obscene, threatening phone calls plague the missing girl's sorority house.Margot Kidder's character amusingly gives the psycho caller a tongue lashing of his own, before he very calmly states, "I'm going to kill you," and softly hangs up the phone. Chilling and intentionally humorous, not an easy combination to pull off. Indeed, the film's first two thirds are also played largely for intentional humour, to give the audience a chance to breathe in between acts of violence by the unseen killer - which only make his violent outbursts even more shocking.Peter's right eye brightly lit by a lamp, while the rest of his face is largely darkened in shadow, as Jess tells him she's pregnant; then later, we see the killer's left eye brightly lit twice, while the rest of him is in shadows. Silhouette of killer's hair looks similar to Peter, but his clothing is different. Was that director Bob Clark showing us the killer, or providing us with a red herring? And why did Peter go around at the back of the house, and smash his way through the basement window to get to Jess, immediately after the killer was chasing her? Good timing on his part, or incredibly poor timing? One of my favourite scenes has John Saxon's Lt. Fuller walking into a pitch black piano room, silhouetted in the doorway, switching the lights on to see Peter's piano, smashed to bits. Fuller walks toward it in complete silence, and we can see the gears turning over in his mind as he imagines the possibilities of Peter being a violent killer.Strikingly beautiful photography in the wintry setting, and inside the sorority house, is another major asset.Hauntingly beautiful, minimalist music score (which, according to composer Carl Zittrer, was accomplished by lightly strumming wooden forks over piano wire) added to its already odd atmosphere, without distracting from it.I cannot think of anything I would change about this film, nor can I think of any other movie with so many unanswered questions, yet which still contains such a satisfying ending- an ending which still sends a chill down my spine. As we recap the scenes of the crimes, the telephone starts to ring and continues endlessly in the silent night.That ending recap, incidentally, was copied almost identically four years later by John Carpenter in Halloween. A vastly inferior film, in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: Santa's not the fusing on this screen
reviews.content: This is the very first of it's kind in more than one aspect:  1) It is basically the first real slasher film.  2)  It is the first movie to really employ the phone terror tactic.  3)  It is the first movie to show the film through the killer's eyesight.  This are 3 very big firsts, because they have shaped the horror genre very drastically.  So this is like a monument to the whole genre of horror.  Is it worthy of this title?  Yes, it was a very daring, slick movie that was overlooked when it came out, but it has now quickly become a classic.  People are finally recognizing it for what it was.  It isn't fair to compare this movie to Halloween.  Halloween had a much bigger budget, and more polished shooting.  The guys that made Black Christmas didn't have very much to work with, but they still pulled something tremendous off.  The gore is basically non-existant in this film, but there is a fair amount of suspense to it which is a plus to most people. Now what really makes this movie shine is the atmosphere, it is really straight to the point and very dark.  The movie begins immediately, there is no beating around the bush!  And the movie also ends very abruptly leaving you in question at times.  That is another plus.  Basically, all appreciators of the slasher genre should check this movie out, if they haven't done so already.  I don't know if others will enjoy this though, as it doesn't have much else to offer.

reviews.review_title: Decent (But Kind Of Dull) Mid-70's Slasher
reviews.content: Before everyone comes gunning for me for my relatively low review of this "classic" slasher - let me start by embarrassing myself by admitting that although I consider myself knowledgeable in most things horror-related - this is one of the classic films that I just watched recently...by recently I mean last night. I know, I know...how could this be, how can you be a "true horror fan", blah, blah, blah - well kiss my ass, I just never got around to this one (or tons of others that I'm now making an effort to go back and revisit...). So with that out of the way, I'll give you my honest opinion...BLACK Christmas is not a bad film by any means. It definitely deserves it's place as a classic slasher film. But, with all of the similar films that I HAVE seen, although BLACK Christmas is obviously one of the originators, it's still like many of the other films I've seen in the slasher genre - and personally the 70's-80's slasher films are not among my favorite of the horror-genre overall. I prefer the more exploitative films of that time frame as opposed to the suspenseful horror films of the time - so my mid-grade rating of this film is based strictly on my own personal opinion...The long and short of this one is about a psycho that sneaks into a girls dorm and starts making obscene phone calls and picking off the "tenents" one-by-one. That's pretty much it.Not necessarily a bad premise - I've seen films work with a lot less, but like I said before, there's not much in BLACK Christmas that I haven't seen before. There is a noticeable lack of gore, which is another gripe of mine with the slasher films of this time-frame (yes, I'm one of those...) and the film dragged in a lot of places. Anyone who is into the classic slashers should definitely check this one out, but I personally just didn't find it as "scary" or enthralling as most others - sorry... 6/10

Sorority girls getting disturbing phone calls over the Christmas holiday don't know the deranged caller has moved into their attic with plans to kill them.Filled with slasher genre hallmarks before they were cliches, Black Christmas is the perfect slasher film. It's filled with interesting characters, tons of suspense, disturbing moments, and an uneasy ending that's sure to haunt you for days after seeing it.

The cast are excellent John "B movie king" Saxon, Margot Kidder and Olivia Hussey are all standouts. Black Christmas will make you laugh, shudder and jump in equal measures. If you are a fan of ground breaking, CGI free original and pure horror this is the perfect film for you. After being at the upper end pricewise it has come down significantly in price. So buy now to avoid disappointment but only if you enjoy being scared.

I heard a little bit about Black Christmas a couple years ago when I was watching on TV the scariest movies of all time, Black Christmas wasn't high on the list, but it was in there, and I remember looking at some of the clips they showed and I was completely scared. They also remade the movie and I was curious to see the original first before I saw the remake, the strange thing is when I watched this movie, it sent chills down my spine. Normally most horror movies don't do that, it'll get you scared, but don't get to you like Black Christmas did, this movie just gave me everything I could want from a horror film. Those calls were just so beyond creepy, the voice, you knew what was coming to these girls for the holidays and it wasn't going to be peace on Earth. My only problem with this movie... "Whatever you do... DON'T GO UP THOSE STAIRS!" said by a policeman, what does the girl do? Oh, she goes upstairs, but I guess we wouldn't have a movie if she did the sensible thing.Some sorority girls are spending their Christmas vacation at the house and are just going to enjoy the holidays together. But after some disturbing phone calls with men heavily breathing, making foul sexual suggestions, and even involving blood curdling screams, the girls have a bit of a scare when the mysterious stranger won't stop calling. Something else has happened, one of the sisters has gone missing, when the girls along with some of their friends try to figure out how these calls and the disappearances of other sorority sisters, the might not want to know where the call is coming from.Black Christmas is a classic and should definitely be watched in the dark, this movie just had me scared and wanting more. It makes you wanna just stay in your room and unplug the phone, we all get prank phone calls at least once, but this is our worst nightmare is when those calls are just more than a mear threat. Olivia Hussy was a great selection, I've only seen her in Romeo and Juliet and the TV mini series IT, I didn't know as a teen she could be so great for a horror movie. Like I said there are some cliché's that I was a little angry with, but this movie does deliver some good scares and will not disappoint you, it's a true sleepover classic.8/10

reviews.review_title: One of the first slasher movies ever created? Yes, please!
reviews.content: Not a perfect film, but it has a certain charm to it. I do wish it got released somewhere in December as opposed to October. I know October is the month of Halloween, but with a title like "Black Christmas", I think December would've been more appropriate. I like how the characters aren't overly sexualized unlike most slasher movie characters, though. Truly a classic!

reviews.review_title: There ain't no room for Christmas miracles or presents.
reviews.content: "Black Christmas" is an important movie for the Horror genre because it generates opinions of all kinds. People might love it or might not find the greatness about it. Many other people haven't even watched it. But something for sure is that the movie is one of the most important moments in Horror history. A killer on the loose terrorizes an all girl Sorority House with obscene/disturbing phone calls. Little do they know that the deranged killer is hiding in the attic. The believed prank calls take another twist when the caller threatens to death one of the girls. To make things worse, a local young girl is raped and murdered by a killer on the loose. Could it be that it's the same man that is making the calls? The first phone call presumes that a girl has been raped because the caller uses obscene language towards a girl's intimate parts and later makes sounds involving a choking. This all happens on Christmas eve! To make things worse, the hider manages to get down the attic and murder one of the sorority girls. This is where hell breaks loose. Then, one by one these girls and their housemother find terrible fates at the hands of the deranged intruder. The calls continue but each time get nastier and scarier. Police traces the calls and find the shocking truth: the calls are coming from inside the house. It seems that the housemother had two different lines in the house. One of the extensions was in the attic, where nobody would ever enter. The attic is filled with old, dusty toys and old furniture. Also, there are photographs that may be from the killer's family. It seems that the killer lived there before it was used as a Sorority House. The atmosphere surrounding Christmas is more than tense. First, the missing girl that later is found dead, then the missing sorority house girl that seems to have vanished from earth but nobody knows that her dead body is wrapped in plastic, sitting on a rocking chair in the attic!. The prime suspect is Peter, the boyfriend of one of the sorority girls. Many clues lead to believe that he's doing the phone calls but nothing is sure. Meanwhile people wonder what's going on, 7 people have been murdered by a mysterious lunatic. A series of events lead to a confrontation with Jesse and the hider from the attic (who's name is believed to be Billy). Will police come before Billy kills Jesse? How will things end in this mysterious situation? Who really is Billy? Watch "Black Christmas"'s ending to make your own conclusions. Your brain will have a hard time trying to figure out a satisfactory conclusion. What a fantastic suspenseful, mysterious Horror movie this is. The events are displayed in a suspenseful way that increases the scare factor. There are very tense moments that carry the whole movie. The highlight is the infamous, classic moment of the "eye in the closet". That's one of the most frightening moments in Horror history; not because of what's visually displayed, but because what it means for the movie. Also, the phone calls are incredibly disturbing, nerve tensing, and can scare the audience without showing anything. The voices are chilling plus the obscene dialog and yells add more tension to the situations. This is a sui generis movie that has been copied over the years. The acting is perfect. Olivia Hussey delivers a believable, tender, strong, performance as Jesse. She knows really how to scream and how to deal with a maniac. I totally bought it. She was perfect enough to carry the whole film. Special mention for Margot Kidder as the drunk, rebel Babs. She was the comedic part of the movie. Too bad she found such a terrible fate. Keir Dullea plays really good his part as Peter, the paranoid but aggressive boyfriend. The man's acting is powerful. And John Saxon did his all time role perfectly. He can't do wrong. The rest of the cast is great. Marian Waldman and Andrea Martin play supporting roles at perfection. You really feel bad for the characters as you get to know them and generate feelings towards them. The death scenes are perfectly done. There's minimal gore but the scenes are very effective. The glass unicorn death scene is a classic scary moment. As many people know and recognize, BC set the standards for the slasher genre. John Carpenter's "Halloween" is obviously inspired on BC. The killer's POV, the score, the Holiday setting, the situations, etc. Carpenter centered his movie on the killer, giving him a personality while Bob Clark used the killer as an element to increase the tense atmosphere. Black Christmas is a perfect Horror movie. First of all (and most important) it is scary, tense, suspenseful and dark. There ain't no room for Christmas miracles or presents. The killer is as menacing as you can get. Probably the most deranged villain on these kind of movies. I wanted though to know more about him but that's what makes this movie great: that you can figure out whatever you want. Your imagination may create a creepier situation that the real one. The ending is great. It leaves too much for your imagination and still is scary. Watch this gem and give it the credit that it deserves because it's one of the most important, influential Horror movies of all time. No room for Christmas songs or Santa Claus, "Black Christmas" will send up shivers up your funny bone. Believe all the hype towards it.

reviews.review_title: Far Superior To The Feminist 2019 Remake, But Still Bad
reviews.content:
Pros:
1. The first-person view of Billy (Albert J. Dunk) helps to imbue more tension as it feels like you're the one stalking the victim.
2. Albert J. Dunk delivers a fantastic creepy voice-acting performance.
3. The does a really good job at cementing the horror atmosphere.
4. The last 20 minutes are captivating, intense, and thrilling. It's a shame this only happened towards the end.
5. The film keeping the identity and physical appearance of Billy shrouded in mystery, helps to increase the tension, suspense, and intrigue, as you're constantly trying to guess who it is.
6. The shot of Billy's eye through the door crack is utterly terrifying and bone-chilling.Cons:
1. Most of the acting performances are very wooden and flat.
2. There are quite a few useless characters as they are given nothing to do. Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman), for example, is only there to be a drunk.
3. The comedy is massively unfunny. The fellatio gag is presented as the height of the humour, and it's awful.
4. The film is needlessly slow-paced, especially after the first kill where very little happens.
5. The dialogue is clunky and is often used to spew out forced exposition.
6. Most of the characters that die are either unlikable and/ or uninteresting. This makes it hard to care.

reviews.review_title: Have Yourself A Very Merry Black Christmas
reviews.content:
In 1974, Bob Clarke's Black Xmas kick started the teenage slasher sub-genre. The seasonal slasher went on to leave an impression on John Carpenter, who years later gave us Halloween. So, do I expect to be disappointed with a remake of such am iconic cult classic? It is hard to get excited over teenage slasher films these days, but Glen Morgan reinstalled that excitement. Billy Lenz has just been released from a mental institution and is looking to find his childhood home where he was abused by his mother. However, the house is now occupied by sorority sisters. With the students unaware of the troubled history of the house and a deranged killer seeking revenge, it's a race against time for the college girls to survive.
An aspect of this movie that makes it stand out is that it delves into Billy's back story and it gives the film more depth. The sorority sisters each have something different to bring to the table, this makes it easier to get a bond with the characters. As the producers were responsible for films such as Final Destination, I was hoping for gory scenes and I received them. Overall, yes, it is predictable at times, but it is worth the watch and has a decent twist at the end.

reviews.review_title: Classic? Perhaps. Classic example of crap? Precisely.
reviews.content: After waiting all this time to see BC, Netflix finally started carrying it, and I promptly pushed it to the top of my queue. I wasn't expecting a film better than Halloween, as no horror can surpass it, IMO. I WAS expecting a creepy movie with some similar elements, though...and boy did this movie disappoint! The phone calls were nowhere near frightening or unsettling, and they actually made me laugh a few times. There was no build-up before any of the murders...I never once gripped the arm of the sofa, or felt the urge to yell, "look out, he's in the room!", which is what makes slashers so enjoyable. Th 'red herring' wasn't a very good one, because, well, WE knew it wasn't him, because we follow the murderer into the house in the very beginning, which made the revelation at the end kind of, erm, pointless. The movies was decently acted, though at times a bit overacted...John Saxon was the best thing about the movie. Overall, I was EXTREMELY disappointed with this 'classic' horror flick. I'll stick to Halloween, and many other look-a-likes, any day of the week. 4/10

This film was at one point critized as being another countless Halloween clone, however this terrifying film was released four years before Halloween, and was re-released shortly after Halloween. In any rate, Black Christmas is a stylish, sleak and mysterious film about a sorority house which is terrorized by an unknown assialiant during Christmas break and makes frightening phone calls and then kills the sorority sisters one by one. The film has a resembled all-star cast including Olivia Hussey (Romeo and Juliet) in the lead role, Keir Dullea (2001- A Space Oddessy) protrays her estranged boyfriend, Margot Kidder (Sisters, Superman) is funny as the drunk and bitchy Barb, Andrea Martin (My Big Fat Greek Wedding) plays the caring Phyl and John Saxon (Nightmare on Elm Street) protrays the worried and hard ass detective. Canadian actress Marian Waldman also stars as the funny and loveable sorority house mother. This film was directed by Bob Clark who did a fine job at creating suspense and building tension and a good twist in the end. Clark went on to direct the Porky's films and the classic A Christmas Story. Black Christmas is highly recommended of fans of the early slasher genre, it should be viewed before seeing Halloween and other popular slasher films of the 80's.

reviews.review_title: possibly the scariest film i've ever seen
reviews.content: o god rest the soul of bob clark for having brought this amazing gem of filmaking to the screen. this is such a horrifying film, that i can barely go into my attic anymore, and every time i see a rocking chair, a crane hook or a unicorn, i can't help but squint. the music by Carl Zittrer is just amazing. How do people make that kind of sound? what's the instrument or machine called? i have to know. olivia hussey is just dman beautiful in this movie, and margot kidder (who is equally attractive) is the one thing that made me calm down during the film during it's scary scenes...but then the movie f***s it all up and kills her off! now, i knew her character would die, but i didn't think so grotesquely. also, the ominous ending. why didn't the director choose to show Olivia Hussey die? Because she's Olivia hussey, damn it!! 9 stars. here's to the best(and first) slasher film ever made.

Forget about the 2006 version, THIS movie is where the terror really started. It's time for Christmas break, and the sorority sisters make plans for the holiday, but the strange anonymous phone calls are beginning to put them on edge. When Clare disappears, they contact the police, who don't express much concern. Meanwhile Jess is planning to get an abortion, but boyfriend Peter is very much against it. The police finally begin to get concerned when a 13-year-old girl is found dead in the park. They set up a wiretap to the sorority house, but will they be in time to prevent a sorority girl attrition problem?"Black Christmas" is that rare horror movie that gets everything right. This is a movie that just oozes atmosphere. Every frame is dripping with dread and setting the film on the Christmas just adds to the excitement of it all. Not only this but the film is also scary as hell with some excellent performances and an ending that is sure to give every horror fan chills. What is the most incredible aspect of this groundbreaking slasher film? Throughout the entire film, we see various sorority girls getting hacked to death and receiving strange telephone calls. What we don't see is our psycho, Billy. No motive, no reason, no face, no man..Billy could be anyone of us. If that doesn't make a true psycho, I really don't know what does."Black Christmas" is quite simply the best horror movie I've ever seen. Some give the credit to "Halloween" to being the first real American slasher film but that simply is not fair. "Black Christmas" did it first and did it better. It is the grandmother of the slasher film, four years before "Halloween". "Black Christmas'" power is impossible to deny; its characters are compelling, the imagery poignant, and the acting top- notch. If you haven't seen it yet, you are in for one scary "Christmas" treat.

Don't get me wrong, if you've read my reviews before, you'd know I love horror films, but this one is sorta boring at some parts. I actually saw the remake of Black Christmas before I saw this, maybe that's why I don't like it as much. In other words, I'm saying I like the remake better than the original. Usually, it's the other way around. It does have some good parts; like the killing scenes, and it has the classic look of the 70's. People are always saying this is the original slasher and HALLOWEEN isn't, but that doesn't matter to me. It doesn't matter which is the original slasher, because I love HALLOWEEN better. Maybe one day, I'll give this movie a 2nd chance. If you love classic slashers, maybe you'll like BLACK Christmas!!!

Film deals with a sorority having to fight off a vicious, obscene phone calling killer during the christmas season. Acting in this film is perfect, the suspense becomes unbearable, the direction tight, and filled with a great sense of humor. Years ahead of its time. Lots of 80's slasher films ripped-off this early classic. People will notice similarites between this Halloween, but this came out first. 9/10

A very simple tale, with the slaughter of a bunch of sorority girls during the Christmas period.  This film is reminiscent of 'Halloween', so now we know where John Carpenter got most of his ideas (heavy breathing, POV shots) from.The main difference between this and 'Halloween' is the fact that the killer is never actually seen in full - the most we ever see of him is his eye peeping through a crack in the door.  The death scenes are also far more inventive - the first girl to die is killed using the plastic surrounding the dry-cleaning in her wardrobe (Michael Myers isn't intelligent enough to do that), and her dead body is glimpsed throughout the rest of the film sitting in a rocking chair in the attic.  The most disturbing aspect of this film, however, is the way the killer rants down the phone (from inside the house!!!! - top that Scream!)- they make no sense at all and serve to make him all the more creepy.The ending of this film is a total shocker, almost totally unexpected!  I won't spoil it for those of you who haven't seen it, but let's just say it'll have you checking all those dark corners in your house for things that go bump in the night!!!I saw 'Black Christmas' over the Christmas period in 2000, when UK TV station Channel 4 decided, in their infinite wisdom, that what the schedules really need at Christmas is a slasher movie.  I'm glad they did show it, as I had never even heard of it before..... which is a bit surprising considering the cast of Olivia Hussey, Keir Dullea (post-2001) and Margot Kidder (pre-Superman).If you can find this film in your local video store (probably under the title 'Silent Night, Evil Night'),go ahead and rent it - I guarantee you will not be disappointed.  You'll be creeped right out, but you definitely won't be disappointed.

I have often wondered why there are so many bad horror movies these days. Movies that instead of focusing on suspense and real chills, just pour endless amounts of blood in your face, thinking this will do the trick, and hopefully become a cult classic. Film after film, more and more horror movies are becoming increasingly similar, and you can almost guess the whole entire plot of the movie, no more than 10 minutes into the film. Everything in horror these days is all about over the top special effects, numbingly loud thumping music, that is supposed to get you scared. Black Christmas (the original) is (IMO) one of the best and scariest horror movies ever made. Why? you ask. Let me tell you. There are so many reasons. First. In horror today, when someone (usually the pretty girl) is walking towards a door or a room (thinking someone will be there) - and they are. The film makers feel the need to spoil the moment with ridiculously loud music that is (intended) to get you all hyped up for the big surprise. When they don't realise that this spoils 99% of the scene. For instance, 10 minutes into the movie, one of the sorority girls "Claire" goes up stairs to her room, to pack some things, preparing for a trip. While entering the room she is greeted by the house cat "Claud". While packing, Claire hears a strange meow. At first she just ignores, but the meow gets more and more intense and chillingly creepy. She then notices that the meow is coming from the closet (not far from where she is standing) at the end of the room (and the closet door is open). She paces towards the closet (with a terrified stare) quickly realising that the meow is not coming from the house cat, asking "Who is that?" several times. The thing that makes this scene 'GOLD' is while walking to the closet and asking "Who is that?" there is no music! - just dead silence. This makes the scene and situation seem more real and 1000 times more scary. The viewers are at the edge of their seat, hanging on to pure silence while she walks further and further to the closet. This is far more terrifying than continuous loud music, that spoils the moment, because you know by the music when the killer is going to approach. That scene is horror at it's best and everyone should see the film for that scene alone. Secondly, the entrance of the movie is shocking. The camera is filmed like a documentary (like the camera is the stalker, walking nearer and nearer to the house) While spying on his victims he realises he is able to climb to the top of the house where he can enter the attic. The directer's captured this amazingly and it gave off that feeling, that raw, real, scare, that this really could happen to anyone. One of the standout scares and scenes that stick in your brain are the chillingly disturbing phone call scenes. The girls receive numerous phone calls from the same man, only there's a catch. It's not your typical Scream phone call were the killer asks "Are you alone?" and "What's your favourite scary movie?" he talks with himself, displaying what appears to be a severe split personality. The phone calls get more and more scary as the movie goes on. Especially near the end were the killer actually goes crazy portraying more than 4 different voices and characters - the horrific sound of his voice will haunt you after the movie is over (which I guess is great for the Creator, as all the best horror movies make long lasting impressions). The last thing I will say is there are a lot of people, reviewers, saying the end was disappointing because they still don't know who the killer is. Huh? lets get this straight. The killer isn't a person in the movie who is coming across nice, nor is he pretending to be a close friend - in fact he doesn't know any of the girls at all. He is merely a deranged, dangerous man who passed a sorority house and thought it would be fun to hide inside their attic and hack them off 1 by 1. I will not spoil the rest of the movie for those who haven't seen it. All I will say is if you want a great horror movie that when the credits role you will be afraid to walk upstairs, THIS IS THE MOVIE FOR YOU. You will also be staring at your attic door for about a week.

I had read quite a few reviews of BLACK Christmas (1974) before purchasing it, never having watched the film before. I certainly felt elated afterwards that it was very much worth picking up. I am saying this because, having grown up on Alan Frank's book HORROR MOVIES - in which this was not mentioned at all! - I didn't quite know what to expect. It's certainly one of the finest 'slasher' films I have ever watched, not that I can say I'm a rabid fan of this sub-genre.As with most of the landmark horror films of the 1970s, BLACK Christmas was a low-budget production but the film is very well-made and this factor never becomes a problem. The screenplay by Roy Moore was fairly original for its time, though it's since been copied ad nauseam: the mostly young cast does extremely well here - it helps that many were professional actors, making the audience care for the characters' fate - which cannot be said for virtually any of its contemporaries (not even John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN [1978]). Again, it skilfully integrates generous doses of humor to offset the generally high-strung and claustrophobic mood. Tension is admirably built-up and sustained throughout, particularly during the last half-hour.
