The murder scenes, though not too many in number, are certainly very effective - and thankfully done without the need for extensive use of gore.Technically, the film is also well up to par: Reg Morris' cinematography superbly captures the sinister atmosphere of the house making it a major character in the proceedings, as well as the killer's state of mind through a frequent use of the subjective camera. Expert editing keeps the audience on edge throughout, but it is at its most effective during Margot Kidder's death scene (a veritable Argento moment) and the finale. Carl Zittrer's unusual and largely dissonant score is very unsettling, and another big plus. The killer's attitude reminded me a bit of Andy Robinson's psycho in DIRTY HARRY (1971), and the weird and pretty haunting sounds he makes (the girls themselves dub him 'The Moaner') were probably inspired by Mercedes McCambridge's demon voice in THE EXORCIST (1973) - but they are even more impressive, and scary, for not showing the person making them!The comedy element of this film is worth a special mention: from the posters hung up on the walls of the sorority to Marian Waldman's boozy antics as the contemptuous house mother to Margot Kidder's turtle anecdote during a party and her 'telephone exchange' scene at the Police Station (which, later on, is also beset by a trigger-happy old man who literally shoots one of the officers in the ass!), the film is quite hilarious at times - which, in a film of its type, is not easy to come across and even harder to pull off! Still, BLACK Christmas' most memorable comic foil is Douglas McGrath playing a baffled cop put upon by just about everyone, including his own colleagues and superiors; these scenes are far better handled than the sorry attempts at comedy in Wes Craven's THE LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT (1972), that's for sure!The leading roles are nicely filled: Olivia Hussey projects more than just beauty as the strong-willed heroine; Keir Dullea essays his relatively difficult role admirably; Margot Kidder is impressive in what she has to do, and probably influenced her later casting as Lois Lane in SUPERMAN - THE MOVIE (1978); John Saxon is suitably commanding as the Police Lieutenant intent on capturing the madman. If there is one thing about the film which I find unsatisfying is the lack of sufficient clarity in the killer's backstory (reminding me of Dario Argento's OPERA [1987] which I have only watched for the first time a couple of weeks ago). I know this was probably done on purpose but, usually in this type of film, all the plot threads are neatly woven by the end - whereas here we rather emerge from the whole enthralling ordeal (echoed, to a certain extent, by HALLOWEEN's conclusion) none the wiser!Much has been said of the film's Original Aspect Ratio. The end titles clearly give this as being shot in Panavision, so I don't know why anyone would prefer to watch it 'full frame'. Actually, once I had watched it I couldn't envision the film in this way, and sure enough the scenes that appear in the documentary are not as effective for this very reason! The DVD supplements are extensive but, all in all, something of a mixed bag: the two Audio Commentaries are very interesting, even though quite a bit of info is repeated verbatim elsewhere on the disc - also, Bob Clark's track (which is fuller than the John Saxon/Keir Dullea one) quite often suffers from poor audio making his comments hard to understand; the three interview segments, two of them with Saxon and another one with Clark, deal with the rest of their work as well as their obvious fondness for BLACK Christmas; though it basically covers all grounds, the documentary disappoints slightly due to the amateurishness of its production (it certainly pales in comparison with Blue Underground's or Laurent Bouzereau's efforts which grace numerous DVD editions of classic films) - still, my favorite bit is the greatly moving anecdote involving Edmond O'Brien's failing health which prevented him from taking the role later filled by John Saxon; numerous trailers and radio spots (narrated by a familiar voice later to play a prominent part in Clark's MURDER BY DECREE [1978]) are great fun, as is the photo gallery which features a good selection of stills, posters and behind-the-scenes shots; finally, the alternate credit sequences and reversible cover art are nice to have, too.The disc also includes a special preview of MURDER BY DECREE by way of its theatrical trailer (which, apparently, is in pretty bad shape!), announcing it to be coming soon on Critical Mass DVD. Does anyone have any idea when this will be released and what supplements will be included - the film is certainly intriguing and Anchor Bay's DVD (that was only released in January) seems to be quite satisfactory, but who knows if it could be improved?Having watched BLACK Christmas, I'm certainly interested in catching up with other Bob Clark horror films, particularly his two earlier efforts - CHILDREN SHOULDN'T PLAY WITH DEAD THINGS (1972; coming soon on R2 DVD from Anchor Bay UK) and DEATHDREAM (1972; aka: DEAD OF NIGHT).

Not fun to watch. No character or bit of dialogue is memorable. The entire plot is dreadful, a joyless affair. That this movie spawned countless slasher movies does not impress. People have been remaking this movie for years, I mean don't you have a story that's original? It just sucks, the whole genre the whole concept is such an awful movie to watch regardless of the incarnation and they keep making this movie or a movie just like it.

reviews.review_title: Black Christmas (1974, Bob Clark) This is a solid holiday themed horror flick if a bit dated
reviews.content: 'Black Christmas' is a 1974 movie directed by Bob Clark and starring Olivia Hussey. Clark had a prolific directing career but would be most well known for another holiday project directing, 'A Christmas Story' in 1983. Keir Dullea and Margot Kidder costar here in a film about a crazed killer picking off girls in a sorority house one at a time. The film was made in Canada for less than one million dollars, and while it received mixed reviews at the time of its release, it has gone on to achieve cult status as well as being labeled one of the best horror movies of all time by some. The film would inspire 2 remakes from 2006 and 2019.Hussey stars as Jess who lives in a sorority house with a bunch of other girls and their house mother. In the film's first scene we witness a figure crawling into the attic. It is Christmas time and there is a holiday party in progress when an obscene call comes in from someone ranting and moaning nonsensically. Following this a girl goes missing although we are witness to her murder. As a search begins for the missing girl when her father arrives the next day our mysterious killer keeps picking off girls one at a time until only our "final girl" remains. There is a side story as Jess reveals to her boyfriend she is pregnant and intends on getting an abortion. All the missing girl drama starts happening before the couple can resolve anything, but the police speculate the boyfriend, Peter, played by Dullea, may actually be the killer. All of these elements factors in as the final scenes unfold and the killer attempts to bag the last remaining girl in the house.Despite a few off kilter performances this is actually a pretty well crafted horror movie. It is a very early example of the slasher film, but it does not fall prey to many of the tropes as that sub-genre was still in its infancy in 1974 and had not really developed any standard. The directing is quite good and I enjoy how the film maker shies away from any standard explanation or resolution to the film. In our modern age especially with the slasher film writers feel like they need to explain everything such as the killer's backstory and what makes them tick and where they come from etc. Sometimes what makes more interesting, compelling cinema is leaving things mysterious and unexplained. This is a good film for the genre and does a job of taking the urban legend regarding the killer is in the house motif and spinning it into a fully realized holiday themed, horror film.Eric's Grade: B.
Above-average, early slasher movie is well directed, has suspense and ominous atmosphere and a capable cast; the open ending, however, is somewhat disappointing.

I don't know how I have missed this gem over the years! Wait I do know, it was made in 1974, in Canada. Hollywood thought it was king, and like the US car industry, had given up trying. (We all know Hollywood.)Firstly, if someone wants to make a mid 1970s nostalgia film, and you're in charge of set decoration, or wardrobe, this is a great film to study. No over the top trends, just spot on real sets and costuming.Secondly, I don't think I have ever seen so many real firsts in one film. Everything eventually shows up in Hollywood years later. Really amazing when you see so many franchise ideas packed into a single film.I found the casting interesting also. Lots of folks you'll recognize for sure.What you will not see is a lot of special effects blood and gore, but you will get an earful of profanity that may offend folks with what I call a "PC ear." So be forewarned. The UK release had the censor remove most of it BTW.I think this is a must see classic!

reviews.review_title: The father of the slasher genre.
reviews.content: Black Christmas tells the story of a group of girls in a sorority house who are getting obscene calls from a mysterious man. The calls grow increasingly more macabre as the film moves on. Soon, a girl in the sorority goes missing, and everybody goes on the search while the calls continue. There is a killer on the loose, and as time moves on, he grows more and more blood hungry...Black Christmas isn't the best slasher movie ever made, but it's the movie that started it all, and for that it deserves respect.Black Christmas borrows it's basic plot from the most famous urban legend of all time, and adds a bunch of characters and plot developments to make it more interesting. The plot is pretty good for a low budget slasher movie, and it's still creepy today. Many of the devices used in most slasher movies came from this film including the point of view shots and the tension building silences. Though Halloween started the slasher boom of the 80s, it wouldn't have been made the way it was had it not been for Black Christmas, and fans of Halloween should recognize that. The movie uses many creepy build up scenes to build tension and makes the smart choice of never showing the killer's face. We only get to hear his deeply disturbed voice through phone calls, and an eyeball through the shadows. It is especially creepy that we have no knowledge of the killer's identity or his motive, however a motive can be put together by anyone with an imagination through the phone calls. Bob Clark, who went on to do the famous Christmas film A Christmas Story, did a very good job with this film.The acting is pretty good. Keir Dullea gave an intense performance, and Canadians Margot Kidder and Andrea Martin were both funny and dramatic.Overall, Black Christmas isn't a great classic, but it was the first slasher movie ever made, and it is the reason that most slasher movies are the way they are.7/10

I am sure this movie is far less known than John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN, made two four years later, more or less the same scheme, a psycho killer on rampage in a quiet neighborhood. But the story telling, editing, directing style is not the same, such a shame. But the stalker calling from the inside, I have already seen this before in horror series episodes, before and of course after this Bob Clark's movie. ALFRED HITCHCOCK PRESENTS show, back in the late fifties and early sixties, told us this topic. This Canadian movie is quite excellent, riveting, terrific atmosphere provider. A milestone, but unfortunately unknown milestone in the seventies horror films.

reviews.review_title: So scary it will put you off scary movies!
reviews.content: It's not often you find a movie so scary as this. There was no fun about it, it was just non-stop scary and it's probably one of the best horror movies of all time. They all say that Halloween was THE horror movie but I tell you after you watch this movie, you'll change your mind. If you think that horror movies are not really scary and you're just wasting your money, rent Black Christmas and you'll literally be screaming through the movie. With The Omen you can have fun with it because it can't happen but once you watch this murder-massacre movie, you'll want guards behind your house. There were some excellent performances by Olivia Hussey as the main character and Margot Kidder was a supporting actress in this movie. In my opinion it was scarier than "The Exorcist" and should have won Oscars for Bob Clark for "Best Director", Olivia Hussey for "Best Actress" and Margot Kidder for "Best Supporting Actress". This movie makes other scary movies look like comedies. Once you watch it, you'll remember it forever!!

While having grown in popularity and recognition in the past years, Black Christmas is an under appreciated horror gem from director Bob Clark, the same who would later bring the much beloved A Christmas Story. This I feel is a better film, capturing a more timeless sense of Christmas cheer than the overly sentimental Christmas Story, but putting a psychotic murder mystery twist on the season.Black Christmas is set in a sorority house as the holiday break sees most of the residents leave to spend time with family, with a few staying behind to look after the house. However a deranged stalker takes refuge in the home with them, making obscene disturbing phone calls and picking off the remaining residents one by one. The characters are well written and performed authentically, all are smart and interesting making you care for them (unlike a lot of horror movies these days), and the casting is amazing. Olivia Hussey plays Jess, who has a secret between her and her boyfriend Peter (played by Keir Dullea, Dave from 2001 A Space Odyssey), Margot Kidder as the crass alcoholic Barb, Andrea Martin (pre SCTV stardom) as the reasonable yet timid Phyl, Marian Waldman as the frumpy boozing house mother Mrs Mac (easily steals a lot of scenes with her secret sherry stashes), and John Saxon as the police lieutenant Ken Fuller investigating the harassing calls.The film is innovative in more than just being a prototype to the future slasher genre which would explode in the 70's and 80's, with first person POV shots from the killer, a goosebump inducing experimental soundtrack made up broken piano sounds that creeps throughout, and some tropes that would later become famous with films like When a Stranger Calls and Halloween. There is also little blood through out the movie, with some kills being more about tension than execution as they build up to the moment. The film is a slow burn in tension with characters becoming uneasy over days as well as the phone calls getting more personal and insane, so if you're looking for a gory kill a minute horror you might not be very impressed with this film.However if you're looking for a creepy Christmas horror to experience this year I'd gladly recommend you check out this unique early slasher. And don't bother with the remake, even if you're looking for gory kill a minute horror it does not deliver and is absolutely bland in comparison.

It's not a movie with a great or original story (which horror movie does anyway?) or approach but this is simply one fine and effective genre movie, with a fine premise, good settings and some wonderful genre moments.Amazing thing is that director Bob Clark started his career with movies like this but soon continued on making movies such as "Porky's" and "Baby Geniuses", which is obviously a totally different genre. A waste of his talent? Well, in all honesty horror movies from the '70's are definitely better ones than the ones from the '80's of '90's, so I'm not too sure about it actually if Clark would had continued to direct horror movies during his later career those movies would had been as good as this one, mostly in terms of style.'70's movies of course have a very distinctive style and atmosphere. Some of the best and most classic horror movies also date back from the '70's. Movies such as "The Exorcist", "The Omen", "Don't Look Now", "Halloween" oh and I can just go on and on. This movie wasn't the first slasher and it also wasn't the most influential or best known one (credit for that still mostly goes to John Carpenter's "Halloween") but it's nevertheless obvious that this movie inspired later film-makers and is a fine example of the genre from the '70's.It's a really effective horror movie, that features all of the right required ingredients. It doesn't make this the most original genre movie with its style or approach but it's simply one fine executed one. The movie has a good dark and mysterious atmosphere and it also really knows to be scary in parts. Especially the phone calls within the movie, which play a key part, are really scary. I don't know what it is but phone calls are always scary and effective material for horror movies. Just think about movies such as "Scream", "When a Stranger Calls" or "Sorry, Wrong Number".What also helps the movie is its atmospheric musical score from Carl Zittrer, who used to work a lot with Bob Clark during his career.The movie also really has a great cast with actors you wouldn't necessarily normally expect in a genre movie such as this one. Margot Kidder is really great in this movie, in a fairly early role from her. The movie also stars Keir Dullea, who unfortunately doesn't ever star in that many movies.A great movie for the fans of the genre, as well as to everyone else for all that matter.8/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

Our local festival theatre was showing Black Christmas for one night only so we decided it would be fun to go see it again. It was the 3rd time but the 1st on the big screen. We weren't disappointed. The film was shown in one of the larger theatres not the small venues they also had. The theatre was quite crowded although not full.From the beginning where we follow the serial killer through his eyes into the sorority house the film packed a punch. Billy is truly one sick crap. No we never get know who he is nor do we ever see him except in one scene that was truly disturbing all we see are his eyes. At times there were shadows in the background that made no sounds. But we heard his voice and it was truly disturbing.That the film does have a certain cheese element and lapses of logic does not take away from the fact that this film should rank up there with the best horror films. Suggestion and not seeing the killer are far better than seeing some crazed guy in a hockey mask come at you. It is not the first but many that came after pay homage to Black Christmas. Think Halloween. Before that there was Psycho and Peeping Tom (that ruined Michael Powell's career). And going back even further there was The Spiral Staircase (1945) where a deranged killer stalked girls with disabilities. Pretty daring for its time.Margot Kidder in particular stands out in the cast. This was before Superman. One should also see her in Sisters another truly creepy film. Sadly she has passed away. Also good was Olivia Hussey and Keir Dullea was just creepy and disturbing. John Saxon also appeared as did Andrea Martin before SCTV.But it was the atmosphere created an atmosphere of dread and the voice of a deranged killer that you never saw. Yes the ending was ambiguous leaving the audience shaken and up in the air. And the phone kept ringing. "The calls are coming from the house."

reviews.review_title: Essential viewing for fans of horror, and thrillers alike
reviews.content: Easily the scariest movie I have ever bore witness to, even to this day, Black Christmas set the standard for the "slasher movie." I could drone on for hours about how much I enjoy this movie, but I'll try to keep this short. If you don't know the plot, here it is: Sorority house during X-mas break, where we learn the girls have been receiving obscene phone calls, inter-mixed with some unknown intruder scaling up a wall to an open attic window. What follows are some of the most intense, and downright harrowing phone calls, switching from sexual innuendos and pig noises, to what seems like different characters screaming out names that make no sense (not at first, anyway). The story progresses with Jess (Hussey), seeming to be the recipient of the calls, telling her boyfriend Peter (Dullea) that she is pregnant, but does not want to keep the baby. Peter flips out, and starts to act a little cuckoo himself. Enter John Saxon as Lt. Fuller, who while investigating the disappearance of a 12 yr. old girl, keeps a tab on the strange calls coming in to the sorority house. I'll leave it at that, as the movie keeps you on the edge of your seat until the harrowing ending, which answers nothing and everything at the same time. If you haven't watched this film yet, go find it now. It is well acted, intense, and at times flat out disturbing. This is proof that all the crap that's being thrown out today cannot hold a flame to a movie that was made 30 years ago, with no sex, and limited on-screen violence. What makes this movie is the fact that the killer is never shown, and you really have to pay attention to his babbling on the phone, and with your imagination you can start to piece together why this dude is really off his rocker (no pun intended!). Please keep in mind that this movie predated Halloween, Friday the 13th, etc... by quite a few years, and you can notice some of the quirks that would become standards of these types of movie. However, none have, and ever will, match the creepiness of the "eyeball scene" and others. It still gives me nightmares. In closing, this is more of a serial killer movie than anything else, and when you think about people like Ted Bundy who actually went into a sorority house in Florida, and killed young women, it just makes it all the more terrifying.If you have an attic, nail the door shut.9 out of 10 stars.

reviews.review_title: Not that great, not even for 1974.
reviews.content: This one is highly overrated in my opinion, even for a 1974 horror movie. I'll admit there is a slight suspense building but it's all much too weak in the end. The killings are not that visual, it's all too subjective to be interesting. The story reminded me a bit of the movie House On Sorority Row (1982), it's basically the same, with the exception that you get some answers in that one. I rated that one slightly lower though, the quality was just not there. In Black Christmas you don't get clear answers in the end and that's always a turn off for me, I just don't like open endings where they keep you guessing, I don't see the point of that. So besides the suspense building there isn't much good to write about Black Christmas. It's a mystery to me why it scores so high on here, but then again I get that a lot with other movies also. I must have a bad taste for movies.

Haunting, dark, atmospheric and suspenseful are probably the best adjectives to describe director Bob Clark's underrated horror film. Before there was "Halloween" in 1978, four years earlier came this terrifying slay ride (pun intended) from the man who would give us "A Christmas Story" in 1983.Set in a sorority house during the Christmas season, a group of young women are stalked, taunted and mercilessly seen by an unseen madman living in their house's attic. The tension only escalates as the girls are picked off one by one and the phone calls are garbled insane gibberish, filling the film's main heroine with dread as she becomes the 'final girl'. Can she and anyone else survive the terror of the night?The film's cast is impeccable from Olivia Hussey plays main protagonist, Jess, to Margot Kidder (four years before she would become Lois Lane) as the foul-mouthed Barb, Andrea Martin as levelheaded Phyllis 'Phyl', Keir Dullea (best known as Dave Bowman in '2001 a Space Odyssey') as Jess's unhinged boyfriend, Peter, and John Saxon as the policeman assigned to watch the town and ultimately solve the murders. The cast displays a quirky chemistry and genuine sense of mistrust as the tension ramps up in the narrative.The story is simplistic in its narrative: murders occurring in the sorority house and everyone is under suspicion. However the film is original in its format with inventive techniques as POV shots from the killer's perspective (soon to be overused in later horror films), obscene phone calls that taunt the surviving girls ('Scream' would borrow the phone call angle, but put its own spin on escalating tension) and a limited use of violence in order to scare the viewer with what is not seen rather than what does happen. Most audiences and critics were unsatisfied with the film's ending as there are questions left unanswered, but this makes "Black Christmas" so different from its successors as it begs us to wonder what happens after the credits. Any horror fan should definitely see this little gem and I promise it'll haunt your dreams.

Although I love scary movies I have never been a true fan of the slasher genre. I rented this after seeing the good reviews it got on this sight and was very impressed! The music score is very creepy, the villain is completely insane (there are connections to "When a Stranger Calls" (another great movie) with the anonymous phone calls, and the movie is just plain scary--this is coming from someone who didn't think "Halloween" was that scary. (MILD SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!!)I thought Margot Kidder was kind of annoying, but her death made me afraid to go to sleep for a week! (END OF SPOILER!!!!!)Another thing I liked about this movie is that many things about the killer are left up to your imagination (something I think is very scary) You never really find out who he is or why he's doing this.I recommend this movie highly.

reviews.review_title: I strongly recommend watching this classic
reviews.content: Black Christmas (1974) is currently available for free on Tubi and the storyline focuses on a sorority house missing a few ladies and a few of the sisters and parents waiting for them to return...as the killer continues to pluck them off. This movie is directed by Bob Clark (A Christmas Story and Porkys) and stars Olivia Hussey (Death on the Nile), Margot Kidder (The Amityville Horror), John Saxon (A Nightmare on Elm Street), Keir Dullea (2001: A Space Odyssey) and Marian Waldman (Phobia). First thing I'll say is these characters love to drink. There's a scene a woman brushes her teeth then gargles with liquor afterwards. This is still an extremely fun movie with some great kill scenes and intensity. The ending reminded me of "When a Stranger Calls" and makes the movie come together well. I loved the final fade out sequence too. This has an eerie feel throughout and a great conclusion. I strongly recommend watching this classic if you never have. I'd score this a solid 8/10.

reviews.review_title: the start of the slasher genre. ***spoiler alert***
reviews.content:
Black Christmas, almost 50 years old and even as you see it nowadays in 2021 it sometimes gives you the creeps. Not that it is scary but the telephone calls are never explained and the way the caller talks, well, that gives you goosebumps. Some do say that Blood Feast (1963) started it all but for me this one comes closer to the typical slasher items.It must have been the first time that POV is used from the killer's point. The breathing does give it a more scary part. A thing used a few years later in Halloween (1978) and in Friday The 13th (1980).Nothing is explained, who is the killer? Why does he kill? Motives? And some shots are just so eerie that they used it a lot in the flicks to come. The close-up of the eye, classic. The intruder, classic. A holiday as theme, classic. The obnly thing slashers added was the gratuitous nudity.It never had the intention to start a new genre but it did. Okay, here and there it isn't up to date anymore but hey, 50 years remember! If you want to see were it all started this is the one. Sadly, some don't like it, no in your face or on-camera killings, but remember, Halloween didn't had any blood at all throughout the flick.I'm sure when you are watching the flicks from the slasher heydays you will remember alot from Black Christmas. Even for a low budget.
Gore 0/5
Nudity 0/5
Effects 2/5
Story 4/5
Comedy 0/5

I tried to watch this movie many times, but something always had to stop me. Yesterday I finally could see it entirely. From the get go it seems to be an extremely creepy movie, mostly because of the dark version of "Silent Night", but after some moments I could see it wouldn't be that scary. Plot is interesting and sometimes even funny, mainly because of those old people saying such bad words all the time-- come on, old women from a convent aren't supposed to be that rude. What bores me the most is that it took too long for something nice to happen, along with that annoying telephone ringing all the time. However, last scenes are suffocating. That scene with a girl in bed, supposedly sleeping, creeped me out, since ANYTHING could happen to scare the spectator. Happily, directors in that era weren't that mean with us. Surely this film inspired "When a stranger calls" and some others, but it is no big deal after all.

reviews.review_title: Enticing potential, sullied by shoddy narrative writing
reviews.content: Reputed classic that 'Black Christmas' is, I especially appreciate the small details that make the film all the more rich. The house used as the chief filming location was a super find. Director Bob Clark arranges some great shots, some accordingly inspired directly by Roy Moore's meticulous screenplay. The care for hair, makeup, and costume design is gratifying, and set design and decoration too. Characterizations are built with sharp personalities, and there's some wonderfully smart dialogue and small character moments that in the first place do much to round out the picture, and secondly, lend a measure of cheeky humor. Even before taking into account the slasher horror, there's a lot to like about this movie.I admit I'm surprised by the film's relative lack of eventfulness. I suppose I'm used to slashers being a total bloodbath, but in this case the title is more about the gnawing unease surrounding the events, and shock at the murders that do take place. Though employed sparingly, I quite like the somewhat discordant, ambient chords in Carl Zittrer's score that help to form that little measure of atmosphere. I'm less impressed with some aspects about the course of events that at best could be chalked up to seeming carelessness in the screenplay, or at worst, unimaginative writing that demands contrivances for the narrative to work. There are several astoundingly poor decisions, outright blunders, or oversights on the part of characters that strain suspension of disbelief, even through to the very end. Then factor in a killer with no discernible rhyme or reason to his activities, and a B-plot that produces admirable feminist thematic content - with the trade-off that it mostly feels very out of place in the feature.I do really like the cast, with more noteworthy names and faces than I knew. I think everyone involved puts in a swell performance of admirable range, and nuance. The climax is executed very well, and I love the uncertainty in the ending. There's rather a fair bit to enjoy about this picture - so I'm a bit remiss that I find myself wanting to like it more than I do. For all its strengths, a questionable screenplay leaves me very skeptical, and put out. Why, though imperfect, most things about 'Black Christmas' are done very well: characters, dialogue, scene writing, technical craft, direction, and so on. The real killer here isn't on the other end of a phone, it's the narrative. I had such a hard time engaging with storytelling this spotty, increasingly so, as to dampen my enthusiasm about those many elements that are done well. It's a shame, really.It's not altogether bad, but as I see it, the flaws reduce a potentially excellent slasher to solidly average tedium. I can understand how it's gained a cult following in the years since its release, but I plainly disagree with how well it's regarded. You could do a lot worse, but there are also countless better horror films to enjoy. 'Black Christmas' is ultimately modestly worthwhile, if you chance upon it, but there's just no reason to go out of your way.

reviews.review_title: Amazing - the birth of the slasher
reviews.content: This is from 74, so slashers weren't there yet. I think this film started it. Bob Clark is an incredible director. The film is great. Forget the remakes. Watch the original! :)

reviews.review_title: What emerged in 1974 as modestly successful on a low-budget resurfaces as one of the most disturbing films ever made 40 years later. A true cult classic worthy of recognition.
reviews.content: Sometime after I became reacquainted with horror films during Halloween season in 2017- about a month after I saw IT in theaters- I was up late in the living room one night after my parents went to bed and browsing through a horror and B-movie streaming service when I came across Black Christmas (1974). I did not know what to expect, but what followed the next 100 minutes not only didn't disappoint me like most modern films do, it actually managed to DISTURB me a bit and keep me away from the attic for about a week. With that, I believe that Black Christmas stood the test of time and may very well be one of the most disturbing films ever made. Black Christmas is truly a great horror film worthy of recognition.Directed by Benjamin Robert "Bob" Clark (of A Christmas Story fame) after two other low-budget horror films (Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things in 1972 and Deathdream A.K.A. Dead Of Night in 1974), Bob Clark reached the height of his horror career with this film, as it manages to go above and beyond in terms of story, cinematography, editing, acting, dialog, and soundtrack. Black Christmas was initially released on October 11th, 1974 in Canada before being released in the United States on December 20th later that same year under the title "Silent Night, Evil Night". It was later rereleased in American theaters on December 26th, 1975 bearing the title we all know and love.First, the STORY. Black Christmas tells the tale of college girls who are staying at a sorority house during the holidays when a stranger with some form of psychosis sneaks and breaks into said house through the attic (where The Stranger, dubbed "Billy, spends the majority of the entire film) and eventually starts to kill them off one by one. Unlike Clark's last two films, the idea behind the antagonist isn't supernatural like a zombie or vampire, but rather something very close to a mentally-ill person with a home invasion involved. This approach WORKS, as it is a concept that is grounded in reality. It COULD happen to someone in real life. This becomes nightmarish when at the end of the film, little is revealed and we still know close to nothing about "Billy"- his motivations, backstory, and what he LOOKS like all withstanding. Making the killer as enigmatic as possible was another thing that worked; it really enforces the idea that the unknown is terrifying.Then, we have the EDITING. The film sets the tone right away using two of your five senses with a long and aged shot of the house with eerie Christmas carolers singing "Silent Night, Holy Night" in the background as the title fades in with the opening credits. THIS is how you establish an ominous and atmospheric mood. It WORKS. Bob Clark's Black Christmas is a VERY dark and disturbing motion picture, and it has been said that John Carpenter's Halloween (1978) started out as a POTENTIAL SEQUEL to this film. Carpenter and Clark were discussing the film while working on an unmade/unreleased project, where Carpenter asked (Clark) if there was going to be a sequel, and what it would be about. Clark told him that he had no plans to do a sequel, but if there were to be one, the Stranger/killer would've eventually been caught and would've escaped from a mental asylum on Halloween the following year...and he would call it "Halloween". The Halloween that materialized in 1978 had a catchy minimalist soundtrack that is iconic amongst horror fans, but Black Christmas's soundtrack (by Carl Zittrer) was constructed using a piano with forks, combs, and knives onto the strings of it to warp the sound keys, as well as distort the sound further by recording the sounds onto an audiotape and make the sound slower. If this isn't a well composed piece of minimalist music, I don't know what is. I also want to point out that the smallest things, such as the distant sound of a dog barking in the background adds on to the unnerving nature of the film. I can't fully explain it, but it WORKS.Next, we have the CINEMATOGRAPHY. Right after the opening credits, a shaky POV shot (later used in Halloween) is shown approaching the house, climbing a trellis into the attic, and lurking around the house. We mostly see the killer as a shadow on the wall in some shots and his POV in others. the former is especially effective during the shot where the killer is carrying his first victim up to the attic. We are shown the first floor from the stairs as the camera pans up, revealing The Stranger's walking legs as he walks out of frame, leaving us with only his shadow carrying the body and eerie sound effects in the background. The most iconic scenes that are the CLOSEST we get to ever seeing "Billy", we see him about to stab someone with his ENITRE BODY (sans left eye) framed in shadow, and we later see that same eye peeking through a crack in the door. This approach strengthens the enigmatic nature of the character, and that works too. Another scene that disturbs me the more I think about it, is a scene after his second kill where he abruptly starts SCREAMING and TRASHING the attic (shown through POV) OUT OF NOWHERE. This particular moment is one of the most disturbing scenes in the film.The ACTING and DIALOG. The characters aren't poorly written and have some development at best, while certain others are disposable. Our (deconstructed) final girl Jessica Bradford (Olivia Hussey) is pregnant by her boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea) and wants to get an abortion despite his urging against it, thus setting him up as an effective red-herring. (Margot Kidder)'s Barb steals to show as she (and to a bigger extent, the house mother) spend most of the movie getting drunk and becoming memorable out of it. John Saxon and the other actors did an excellent job. Their dialog is well-written and adds depth to the characters. "Billy"/The Stranger, on the other hand, interacts almost exclusively with the other characters through a series of nonsensical yet disturbing obscene phone calls. The noises he makes on the phone are HORRIFYING, partially because it seems as if multiple voices are coming through the other line mixed in with grotesque-sounding animal noises.In conclusion, Bob Clark's Black Christmas is an underrated classic that is worthy of the recognition it gets, and personally deserves more, ESPECIALLY considering that Halloween (1978) wouldn't have existed without it. The combination of the overall tone, music, acting, and special effects make Black Christmas into a well-crafted masterpiece, and even though it's been nearly 50 YEARS since it's initial release, it STILL holds up as a film.If you plan on buying a copy, look no further than the Scream Factory 2-disc Collector's Edition from 2016. It includes a restoration of the original negative and interchangeable audio set-up on the first disc, and a bonus disc with the 2008 Critical Mass Blu-Ray and EVERY special feature included in past home video releases. A true essential in terms of a Christmas movie gift.

reviews.review_title: Horror movie fans know this is before HalloweeN
reviews.content: First off I want to say the remake is totally lame but this one is awesome! It's a fun slow burn horror film and this is before John Carpenter HalloweeN film came out. The story is good, the acting is great, and the script is good. The phone calls are down right disturbing like it's better than the remakes phone call. Yeah this movie is a pre Scream world at the time but it's effective still. The kills are creative but the sad part about this movie is that it's forgetable like not alot of people know this movie. This is my review on Black Christmas (1974), a forgetable underrated classic.

Here is a film that is not usually present in Christmas day-time programs although its action happens around Christmas and has even a scene with a choir of children singing carols. Filmed in 1974 in Canada Black Christmas is a combination of seasonal movies and horror, more precisely one of the first films of the 'slash' sub-genre.Film director Bob Clark is author and this is one of the first in a career that will still includes some successes of the genre, and even a second film (A Christmas Story) with the theme of Christmas. Clark demonstrates that by 1974 he already mastered many of the secrets of the trade and assimilated the lessons of the masters of the previous generations and especially Hitchcock. The film takes place in one of those American sorority houses. Thrill is induced at the beginning by mysterious and threatening phone calls, because shortly afterward the home tenants begin to disappear one by one, and the bodies to accumulate. I will not tell more so that I do not take away the pleasure of watching for those who still are interested to see the film.'Black Christmas' deserves to be viewed primarily by enthusiasts of the genre, but not only them. I can not say it is a film that time has not made ​​its mark , but interestingly good as its parts are now more visible. At launch it was almost 'destroyed' by some critics, for example that of New York Times. Although some of the critic's objections are deserved (acting seemed pretty sketchy to me), I believe he lost sight of the exact build-up of the atmosphere, using the enclosed space to create the feeling of claustrophobia and daring approach to social topics such as the right of women to decide about abortion (in general it can be said that this is a feminist film). Of course, the 1974-75 critic could not have anticipated that the film will open the way to other horror films that take place in the student environment such as the series 'Scream' and 'I Know What You Did Last Summer' . But there are at least two scenes close to masterpiece that he should not have missed. In one of them a girl's father and the mother of another girl - both disappeared - search their daughters at night in a frozen park. A body is found. To whom it belongs? The whole scene is rendered in its profound horror just filming two parents, there not need to see any body to understand whose death has been confirmed. Groovy and psychologically excellent. The second great scene is the final and I will not tell anything about it, so that I do not deprive anybody of the pleasure of a viewing which I recommend.

A tense, taut & terrifying nightmare that hasn't aged a day, Black Christmas is one of the finest examples of its genre that also ranks amongst the greatest works of 1970s cinema. Enveloped with a chilling sense of dread, filled with rich characters you actually care about, and scoring high marks on all fronts, this Canadian horror is the slasher film that inspired every other slasher film.Directed by Bob Clark, this story remains relevant today coz it presents a scenario that many women around the world still find themselves in. Things may not be as extreme for most as it turns out for these characters but the threat, harassment & the psychological trauma of it all is more than relatable & just as tormenting on the emotional scale. As for Clark's direction, it's brilliant throughout.The film employs POV camerawork to show us events from the killer's perspective and heightens the tension & suspense with gripping, nail-biting intensity. Editing is immaculate, for its 98 mins runtime simply flies by. Humour is aptly integrated into the narrative. Terrific sound design keeps us on alert at all times. And acting from the entire cast is excellent as well, thus leaving nothing to complain about.On an overall scale, Black Christmas is an unnerving, unsettling & uncomfortable chiller with a simple & straightforward plot that is exceedingly well told. A work of first-rate craftsmanship that is accomplished on both technical & storytelling fronts, this timeless classic is one of the best films of its year, one of the greatest films of the 1970s, and is undeniably one of its genre's finest offerings. Essential viewing. Strongly recommended.
If you like the genre this one is just made for you. Black Christmas is one of those early examples of the genre and still good, maybe even an essential watch for the lover of the art of horror.

I came into this with a deeper familiarity with the 2006 cut of this film, which was a fun romp mind you but nothing serious and expected something simillar from this film too, but my expectations were defied and in a good way.This film is chilling to say the least. It gives me all the same feeling of dread I sometimes feel when I look out my windows at night and feel like there's someone watching me.There's a layer of, almost realism to this film in some aspects. The POV shots are so effective at unwillingly putting you into the killers shoes, you just feel his sense of trespass and presence throughout the film and it's a actually rather frightening.Here. This is definitely more of a film about fearing what you can't see, and if that's more your thing you'll definitely get a kick out of this one.Not to mention this is the perfect antidote to any unwanted feelings of "holiday charm." I think I will make a tradition out of watching this every holiday season.

Seeing the fun but definitely trashy remake of Black Christmas sparked interest to see the original. Definitely worth watching, and definitely influential.I can definitely see how this film may have influenced When A Stranger Calls and even Halloween, which is more popular and well-known than this. It has a similar set-up, with a slow pace. I liked the pace, have nothing against it, but I did think that the film broke the suspense many times by cutting away to other things. There was one scene that really scared me though, and it's the scene right before a girl screams at the body in the park, when we hear the 'stranger' laughing in the attic and then he goes crazy hitting the body of the murdered girl and we see the body of the woman as well. The shot of the girl's face covered in the plastic sheeting is horrifying as well. Ultimately, I enjoyed this, but honestly I did expect better. I do think that the original Halloween is better (although Olivia Hussey beats Curtis, simply because she's just too cute). I also liked how the film starts with one character, making me think that was the lead and then it transitions into another. All in all, good, and although more kudos for this it isn't THAT much better than the stylized and trashy version of the remake. One question though, was the backstory of the killer in the remake completely made up?

The characters are awful. I think this was trying to reflect the young adult post hippie era moral confusion. Anyway, it falls flat with bad script and unlikable characters. I watched half , not scary, gave up.

Not sure why people are saying this is a great horror movie. Total waste of time. It is a very boring movie. More comical than horrific. Actually, at its best, the movie can qualify as quasi-pornographic (like so many "horror" or "slasher" movies of the 70's and 80's).

Black Christmas is one of the greatest horror movies of all time. It builds up a scary atmosphere not only blood and gore like other movies. (Friday The 13th) Imagine getting phone calls and on the other end someone is using three or four voices, their comments are sexual in nature, they are filled with profanity and they say I'm going to kill you. (ring a bell, SCREAM) The phone calls are very strange and bizzare and just listening to them gives you the chills (the calls are coming from inside the house). There is also a bit of a who done it, you think you know who it is and then there is a twist. There is violence like all good horror movies, but not too much, there a funny scenes. I especially liked the directing of the scenes with the killer. We don't see the killer but we move with his eyes, and we hear him panting, puffing, and making strange noises. Phone calls were excellent, with the weirdest noises coming from the killer. great performance by the actors. This movie was made before a lot of the other horror movies and many have tried to copy it greatness but failed. WATCH IT!!

Not a bad slasher film (though there is precious little slashing shown). Director Bob Clark creates an occasionally eerie film starring Olivia Hussey as a college girl whose sorority sisters are being bumped off by a lunatic. The crazed killer enjoys making increasingly bizarre crank calls after each slaying. Needless to say, Hussey (nor anyone else) catches on to what's happening. It's creepy, features a lot of haunting images and Hussey is terrific. Among those playing sorority girls are 26-year old Margot Kidder & 27-year old Andrea Martin. Kidder is the foul-mouthed drunkard while a pre-SCTV Martin is the Earth mother. Keir Dullea & John Saxon are in it too as is Marian Waldman, who adds a lot of kick as the soused house mother.

Chirstmas time is my favorite season, it's hard to say why may'be because it something that brings togetherness which to me is it's true spirit. It's also a time where we believe we are the safest, however as an old saying goes s... happens, it doesn't matter what time of year it is. This is one of my favorite horror/Chirstmas films of all time if you can believe that.This film was not just one of the first slasher films but also one's set in a season. The fact that this was set up in the Christmas time was a risky move and I felt it was a good risk, who'd of thought Christmas in the horror genre could be a great combo. Let alone the fact this was the late great Bob Clark's first Christmas film where his second is of course my favorite Christmas film of all time "A Christmas Story" so two in a row isn't bad.The production value is great, it was made on a low or modest budget and I really felt they used it well and right. The setting was in a neighborhood and a Sorority House that looked like any house and neighborhood I'd pass by which gives the film a sense of familiarity; let alone most of the film takes place in the Sorority House.The cast is good Margot Kidder as Barb is a character you love to dislike because she is practically a dirtbag on wheels, but she just has some really funny spitfire lines. John Saxton is good as the level headed Lt. Fuller, tirelessly hunting down the elusive killer.But I mainly really like Olivia Hussey as Jess. This is one of those underrated actresses I really like (and on a sidenote "Romeo and Juliet" one of my favorite movies). I'll level with you sometimes I like actors and actresses that are under the radar a lot more than ones that are in the limelight way too long.Anyway back to the jist of things, the character Jess I really like she's good protagonist that is fraking gorgeous with the warm persona to boot, smart, has desires/ambitions, but most importantly is a person that can hold her own whether it be standing up to her blowhole boyfriend (Jess deserves someone better). I like that little drama with her character which made her sympathetic in my book, she has this dilemma and she chooses to deal with it a certain way but of course her boyfriend disagrees and is a complete dirtbag to her just spouting horsecrap to her. I'll admit at that moment I wanted to punch him and yell "Frak You" because I always believe a good significant other should always respect and understand the others feelings in certain matters no matter what. But most importantly hold her own physically against the killer.But what makes this film great and hold up is in it's suspense and creepy, moody atmosphere it invokes which I'll admit gave me the chills. The music is great I really like as the killer first enters there's some sort of eerie tone, as well as the end credit some of Silent Night which has a dark tone to it.I really like the plot it's a simple but it feels plausible, whose to say something like this can't happen; it also made me concerned as to how safe our secure our neighborhoods and homes are. Like in most suspense thriller has always been in being one step ahead of the protagonist. Throughout the film at the moments when nothing really happens yet, we always have that looming fact in our head that the killer in the house and up there, and he's about to do something any minute. In moments like that I'm always thinking "Don't go up to that attic." or "Cmon get the frak out of house, don't spend another night." We just constantly feel unsafe and hope the protagonist can find out this fact on time before it's too late.It's true we never really see what the killer looks like but this is a great think because this gives the killer the element of enigma, the crazed killer is simply who he is evil that's all we need to know. The cinematography is great I love the point of view shots which are great, where we are literally seeing the perspective of the killer. This really adds to the suspense because it adds to the step ahead element, from just some actions or even those noises he makes like in those creepy phone call scenes, it really gives you an idea how truly crazy and psychotic the antagonist is.And I like the feeling of isolation, from the fact most of this film takes place in the nighttime, the snow, the cold, and moments when a character or certain character is alone. Once again you feel unsafe because in times like that you know that the killer could possibly make his move and usually does. But it's also a time where all the chips are down for the protagonist and we hope he/she can successful fight back and survive.Black Christmas will make your skin crawl.Rating: 4 stars

reviews.review_title: A really underrated classic horror film
reviews.content: Black Christmas is awesome. Do NOT watch the remake. The original is the best. A sorority house is getting disturbing obscene phone calls around Christmas break. These calls are truly creepy. The caller's voice was so creepy.It's difficult to determine who is harassing the girls because they genuinely don't know who could be so disturbed toward them.As the evening progresses a local child goes missing and one of the sorority sisters has also gone missing.Black Christmas stars future Lois Lane Margot Kidder in an interesting role. Olivia Hussey, once upon a time Juliet in Romeo & Juliet plays an awesome strong, self sufficient and independent girl struggling with personal issues with her boyfriend and trying to find her missing friends.

Black Christmas is brilliantly simple: a stalker terrorizes a sorority house. That simplicity allows it to really dig into the disturbia more specifically and vividly. The intensely unnerving phone calls. The repeated imagery of the plastic-wrapped suffocation. The blur of Christmas lights punctuating the dark scenery. It's brutal '70s horror, but not without some nice splashes of levity to keep everything fresh (the dumb cop is classic).

Margot Kidder, Olivia Hussey and Keir Dullea must have needed work as I do not know how these three talented actors could possibly have read this script and agreed to appear in Black Christmas.Kidder slurs through her lines while mosrly drunk and Olivia Hussey argues with her boyfriend, played by Keir Dullea as a piano student with severe anger issues.The house mother is an overweight woman who is constantly uncovering hidden bottles of booze to keep her nerves calm.I recently read one of the many books on Ted Bundy, and in it, the author Kevin Sullivan claimed that Teddy misheard the name Chris Hayden while watching the film and used the name Chris Hagen while touring Florida on his last killing spree.I was bored to tears by this silly movie.

reviews.review_title: Something about this one always creeped me out!!
reviews.content: It is great to see that I am not the only one that was creeped out by this largely unseen film.  I have been a horror film fan since i was 6 and had seen all the classic horror/slasher/gore films long before ever seeing Black Christmas.  However, none of those films actually scared me like Black Christmas (or "Stranger in the House" as it was called in the U.S.).  I first saw Black Christmas when I was in my second year of college and even though I watched it surrounded by friends and others in a brightly lite dorm, the weird, dark atmosphere of the film and the extremely bizarre phone calls made me uncomfortable and still do when I think about it years later. The scenes of the killer wandering around the attic making strange noises and playing with the body of the first victim also rank as the most frightening moments in my own film experience. Some of the comments here compare it to John Carpenter's Halloween but in my opinion Black Christmas is a much more effective and scary film.  If you are looking for a disturbing and frightening film, you should seek out this forgotten classic and watch it alone late at night.  You won't regret it.

In the case of Bob Clark's 1974 cult-horror BLACK CHRISTMAS, Christmas comes before HALLOWEEN since John Carpenter's 1978 slasher took some inspiration from not only a killer stalking a group of pretty young ladies (college instead of high school) but the camera sporadically becomes his shaky, formidable perspective...But not for long enough as most of the would-be victims remain alive for too long: except poor Lynne Griffin's curiously foreboding shy girl, seeming perfect for the sole survivor... described by a loose, foul-mouthed Margot Kidder (more befitting a sex comedy than horror) as a professional virgin... but lovely-lithe Olivia Hussey's our final girl...And while meek, passive, she's anything but sexually-inexperienced with a melodramatic side-story involving brooding pianist beau Keir Dullea railing against an abortion -- his entire purpose is to provide a red-herring for the faceless killer...Making BLACK CHRISTMAS more an offbeat ensemble-thriller (including a lush house-mom; an affable boyfriend in Art Hindle; and token cop John Saxon) than body-count slasher, and, ultimately, the primary focus of the villain -- young girls in a sorority house -- isn't the primary focus of the movie itself.

One of my favorite scenes is when Jessica (The Gorgeous Olivia Hussey) finds some of her sorority sisters dead in a bed, and the killer's eye is peeping at her through the creak in the door. The whole chase scene down the steps afterward is edge of your seat material, some of the best I've ever experienced. Especially when you think Jessica is completely out of harms way, and the killers arm comes out of nowhere trying to grab her! I still freak at that scene! Enough could never be said at how amazingly eerie the phone calls are, even uneasy at times. The switching of voices sends chills down my back.Another great moment is Margot Kidder's death, while the Christmas caroling continues outside the house.There are a couple of plot holes that bugged me a bit...Okay, why on earth would Peter (Jessica's boyfriend) ever go looking for her in the basement of the sorority house at the end? You hear him yelling outside before he breaks out a window, but that doesn't make sense. Even if the doors were locked and he was yelling for Jessica, he already broke in once before (when Jessica and the others were at a search party for Clare), and it was never indicated that they weren't locked that time. Even so, it still makes no sense what so ever that he would look in the run down basement that looks like none of the girls have ever stepped a single foot in. I feel this entire scene was just made to make Peter look like the most ultimate Red Herring, but I think enough evidence was already pointing to him to totally steer the viewer away from the twist ending.Another thing that got to me was how they build John Saxon to act like a convincingly real cop, only to later make the whole police force to look like a bunch of backwoods Rosco P. Coltrane rejects. Early on Saxon is doing what a lot of cops do, asking questions that had already been answered. Like when he asked of the last time who and when someone had seen Clare, he said "Last time she was seen was this morning" when Jessica had already stated it was the night before. Subtle little bits like that won me over...What didn't was these cops knowing there is a second phone line in the house, and they didn't even think of that from the get go? Better yet, once they realized the calls WERE coming from the house, they never thought of checking the attic, or not even once looked for it? Come on! It was right above the girls rooms! Nevertheless, I did love the downbeat last five minutes of the movie. I guess many people felt cheated with the outcome, I kinda thought it was genius, I just didn't think the whole last ordeal with Peter and Jessica was needed at all for the ending to be so effective. Peter could've entered the house in a more believable way...

reviews.review_title: Ranks up there with some of the best horror mystery thrillers of all time
reviews.content: Amazing '70s horror cult classic. I've been missing out. I didn't watch it till quite recently and never realized it'd be incredibly creepy, very subdued at times but all the more effectively frightening, since it's what we don't see that heightens the frightening tone. The music, cinematography, and set design all help in creating a tense, ominous sorority house atmosphere. The scream queens, especially Margot Kidder, are all awesome, likable characters that we care about their fates in a horror mystery setting. The plot twist near the film's conclusion is sublimely used. A rewatchable horror film since it never looses the eerie, unsettling ambience with each viewing. We never see the face of the killer and his motives for killing sorority girls are unclear, along with an ambiguous ending. Did Jess end up being murdered or did she survive?Super recommended if you haven't seen it! Black Christmas is already on my top list of favorite horror films.

Pretty good antidote to the most cloying of all holidays this film offers mordant, "Twin Peaks like humor to get the viewer over the dead spots (no pun intended) between offings. Big downside for me is the general dearth of the great Margot Kidder at her foul mouthed, cheeky best...outraged that director Bob Clark saw fit to kill off his best character halfway through...and a plethora of the aggressively bland Olivia Hussey. Give it a B minus. PS...Great cinematography by Reginald Morris that captures the look and feel of a Canadian winter (i.e. look up "bleak" in the dictionary and there's...)

One of my very favourite films, I first watched it very late night on Channel 4 during Xmas and it scared the hell out of me The acting, direction etc are all top notch. Having worked in mental health, Billy's rage, hatred of women etc seems plausible (although exaggerated for dramatic reasons).It might seem slow paced with a lack of gore for some tastes, but I like my horror subtle and dark.My favourite DVD release of this is the critical mass special edition, although Dan Duffin's new release last year is well worth checking out, as is Australian release with the retro documentary (the name of that escapes me at the moment)Also check out www.itsmebilly.com

Supposedly this original version of 'Black Christmas' was a precursor to 'Halloween.' Some have even said that 'Halloween' ripped this movie off.Personally, I don't see the comparison. Yeah, he wears similar clothes and kind of breathes like Myers. I dunno. Not really.All I know is that the original 'Black Christmas' is far superior to that re-imagined garbage. I could only stomach about 20-minutes of that.I've seen this '74 version once on VHS a long time ago and wasn't impressed - it failed to scratch my itches so to say.The fact that this movie is freely available online means that it no longer generates any revenue for whatever "now defunct" distribution company it was conceived out of. (Movies of yesterday go away to die as well.) Sorry director fella, Bob Clark, but your little project is no longer a cash cow, or much sought after anymore. 'Black Christmas' is a nowhere movie today. What is sought after though is the elusive novelisation by Lee Hays. It's hard to obtain.Check out this guy with the fuzzy hair. He looks like something crossed between Ron Jeremy and Richard Masur.For some reason the curtains, carpet, and buildings, in this movie look British.And the Asian looking one, with the funny accent, sounds like the one who didn't want to be disturbed, unless it was Greco.'Black Christmas' was superseded by 'When a Stranger Calls' so I guess that movie was inspired by this one with the whole obscene phone call business? Well, it's blatantly obvious at the end when it's like, "Ma'am, the call is coming from inside of the house." Thieves.20-minutes in and I just find this whole affair bland and cloistered. The budget for this movie must have been no more than a grand? It's all filmed in the one spot.It's like it is set in gelatine and you just tread in treacle and get nowhere.Nothing appeals to me.Look at this Mr Peabody guy, who's he? Mr Harrison he is. He reminds me of classic British actors from the 70's & early 80's.And Mrs Mac also looks like any British sitcom actress. (Upon further research she's that one from 'Deranged' who gets shot in the pillow. There's a scene in that movie in her apartment with a photo of her dead husband who also looks British to me.)The prettiest girl out of all of them gets killed first - Clare.Okay, so Mrs Mac, and her drunken foul-mouthed tirade on the staircase, managed to get a chuckle out of me. (There's a lot of aggressive behavior by most cast members in this. It's a hard lined approach in their line deliverances by everyone bar the Asian looking one with the funny accent.)A constipated piano player on Valium plays the decoy killer in this = false lead.Droll judging panel observing him add to the dullness of this movie.College students who are way too old to be college students.This Barb chick looks, and acts, like the madam of the house.(And as if that fuzzy haired guy at the start would be allowed on campus at the ripe age of 50.)"Peter, I don't want to marry you! I'm in love with Greco."This whole movie's investigation hinges on one desk clerk officer.And it's crap watching this a month after Christmas as it's not Christmas anymore! (I hate anything Christmas related when it's not watched in December. Don't feel right.)So, to all you little carollers, harping your little lungs out at the door here, SHUT UP ALREADY!Wow, the Asian looking one, with the funny accent, handed them a few Canadian loons. Hey big spender.Don't tell me they killed off Phyl? She was so innocent and likeable.The problem with this movie is that the killer's uninspiring and has no backstory so why should I invest interest in his character if he's so generic and plain?He just came off the street, climbed up a dorm, settled in the attic, and harasses contributing members of society for no reason? His reason is non-existent.In this scene here the police gave the Asian looking one, with the funny accent, a direct order to walk out the front door and what does she do? Goes upstairs. Now, ain't we a clever cookie?And Thingo said he'd be there in 5-minutes! It's a long 5-minutes, guy.Turns out Greco's the killer and follows what's-her-name to England in that Stephen King movie the next day after the credits have rolled."I told you the first time I met him that he was a twit, Audra!"

It had a bit of a slow pacing and the plot was just decent. But i understand this was 1974 and for this to be one of the first slasher films it's actually pretty good. It has suspense and a bit of horror but not as scary as i thought it would be.

reviews.review_title: True horror is a mood...and nothing is moodier than this
reviews.content: Really good horror movies stay with you for life.Any idiot with a camera can pull you into a one-off scare with a ghoul's mask and a horrendously loud stab of music, but it takes real chops to pull off something as cumulatively horrific as Bob Clark's 1974 indie masterpiece. Watching it is like being at the center of a really macabre jigsaw puzzle that keep getting more forbidding and gruesome until you realize the last piece has your name on it.There are many exhaustive reviews (deservedly so) on this site that detail the plot, so I'm going to summarize the pieces of the puzzle that make it such a delight to return to time and again.1) The Sorority House - Just one look at this thing could send you running for the hills the way Clark, Art Director Karen Bromley, and DP Reg Morris have portrayed it. A look at the house in the daylight without the ominously warped lenses, dreary lighting, and blanketing snow reveals nothing remotely forbidding. But the thought of having to stay overnight there, as it's portrayed throughout the bulk of the film, with the majority of the occupants gone on winter break...chilling stuff. It's a character unto itself.2) Carl Zittrer's score - Quite possibly the most effective horror music soundtrack ever composed, it's a wonder for several reasons. It's economical. It uses what it needs to when it's needed. Zittrer tore up an old piano and raked the strings with a variety of odd objects, neatly echoing male lead Keir Dullea's avant garde mashing on the keys, when the character wasn't brooding ominously. Then there are the ghostly carols: "ooohs" and "aaahhhs" bent, slowed-down, sped-up, played backwards until they're ready to send you over the edge. Turn out the lights and turn up the volume on the newly remastered 5.1 soundtrack and watch your skin crawl.3) The Phone Calls - My god. Hey, there are a ton of menacing phone call movies, but nothing like this. The caller in "Black Christmas" doesn't just pant or moan or blare obscenities....he does all of this and more. "Could that possibly be ONE person?" Lynne Griffin's Claire asks the other girls early in the movie. It's a valid question, because the caller seemingly has a background soundtrack going while he's going out of his mind. Was he using a tape player? Probably, but who really cares? The point is this: the guy is obviously OUT OF HIS MIND. He's not trying to threaten, he's not trying to scare or pull a prank. He's merely letting the contents of his demented psyche loose in a torrent that's loaded with the organized chaos of a Jackson Pollack painting or John Zorn track on steroids. He laughs, screams, and sobs...many times all in the span of five seconds. The jarring vileness of these (many) calls was really toned down in the TV cut ("A Stranger In the House," which is how I first saw this --- and even hacked to pieces for late night TV it was disturbing - NBC would run it near the holidays in syndication after SNL, I remember).4. "Wrapped in Plastic" - Way before Twin Peaks, Black Christmas played with the idea of a killer "preserving" his kills with transparent casing. This is particularly morbid when they're stored in the attic of the house you happen to be occupying.5. The Totally Canadian Humor - With as much gloom and doom as BC has going for it, you'd think it would never make you crack a smile. But then again, it has two of the funniest, least self-conscious actresses playing supporting roles: Andrea Martin and Margot Kidder. And the late great Marian Waldman has the role of lifetime as a uniquely foul-mouthed, hard-drinking housemother who keeps bourbon in the toilet tank. And need I mention Doug McGrath's bumbling Sergeant Nash? His performance generates laughs and pathos simultaneously...he's a rube you can't help but pity, in a nice way.This film has an impressive fan base, and yes, it did fail when it was originally released. I hale from Peoria Illinois and it even hit our theaters a bit softly....but....the theater owners were shrewd enough to bring it back each Christmas for a limited late-night run. Why? because they knew it scared the crap out of the few who DID see it.It still does. And what better endorsement can you give a horror film?

reviews.review_title: It's won't make you jump but it still will creepy you out!
reviews.content: Black Christmas (1974) re-watch as one of the earliness slasher movies, even few years before big know slasher movie Halloween. I am little shocked that it did not get a sequel and I a, clad it didn't.If you are looking for slasher to make you Jump, this movie won't do it at all, there no real scare scenes to make you jump however, this movie dose not try to scare you at all in that way,Some may find this movie little out dated now and s tad boring if have already seen other slasher movies, like Friday and Halloween movies. However I found this to me very intense, they did, add some dark humour intothe mix, which was nice and didn't feel campy at all, worked really well with the rest of the movie. At Christmas, at the sorority house, girl are unaware that stranger, who making phone calls as broken into the house. We don't get to see who that person is at all, that makes little bit more creepy, as you have no idea who or why, his in this house for most of the movie, you do get to see parts of him in the movie. The deaths in this movie are not gory or anything but there are really good death scenes , which I think are way before there time. I love the final scenes of the movie, how is pans around the whole house and still mangers to keep tension until very last second of the movie. The acting was really good from everyone in whole cast, there maybe one or two that acted a bit over the top, it didn't bother to much. 9 out of 10

I saw this movie as part of a double feature with the Exorcist back in 1975, It has stayed with me ever since. It's low-budget, dark, Canadian feel, makes it that much more creepy. It's well acted with a great cast, especially Margot Kidder. I'm sure it seems a bit dated by today's big budget standards, but that adds to the appeal of this classic. Although I have not seen this movie in quite a while now, many of the terrifying scenes linger in my head. I still cannot sing "Bye Baby Bunting" to my kids!
The younger generation will not truly understand how horror movies of the seventies paved the way for some of today's classics. If you are a "true" horror fan, go rent the DVD! You won't be disappointed. Incredible ending!!

reviews.review_title: It'll change your mind about the "real" classics.
reviews.content: I thought John Carpenter's Halloween and Friday the 13th were the films that everyone else got their inspiration from in the horror biz. Then I heard that Halloween copied some movie called Black Christmas. I wondered how a film could be so good even Halloween lifted from it, and I would never hear about it or see it anywhere. Where's its reputation? Well, I watched it, and I can't explain why this film is not more widely known because Halloween is almost a carbon copy of this movie! And this came out years earlier! All the stuff used to scare in Halloween is done here first, and much better, too! It's set on a holiday, there's a killer on the loose, the police are searching for him, he kills young girls, etc. It even has an ending like Halloween. Whether intended or not, Carpenter is just a rip-off. This film is way scarier than Halloween, the acting is better, the direction is perfect, and the writing flawless. This is one of the first movies that uses the now-tired line "Jesus, you scared the hell out of me!" I laughed when I heard it because every movie says it now, but this actress actually said it believably. This movie will scare you. Near the end the officer working on the case discovers that the obscene phone calls the girls are getting are coming from inside the sorority house they are staying in. It reminded of the timeless urban legend, except that featured a babysitter. Watch this film. This is THE real classic, forget all the others that take credit for it. Look at the beginning with the POV shots with the killer. It is EXACTLY like Halloween's opening. It's a shame.

Watching this film gives me the chills! The story is about a killer who breaks into a sorority house and hides in the basement while killing the women in the house. You have Jess (the always beautiful and heartbreaking Olivia Hussey), a young woman facing an unexpected pregnancy and facing up to her high strung, emotional boyfriend, Peter (2001: A Space Odyssea's Keir Dullea). Then you have outspoken, drunk, Barb (Margot Kidder, who is excellent in her earlier role). The atmosphere is perfectly set: like the weather it is cold and chilling. It is a horrible nightmare of the idea that a homicidal nutjob is not only killing but hiding in the place where the murders are taking place. The film has a Hitchcock quality to it and more frightening is that we never see what the killer looks like and we see him killing through his point of view. It is such a shame and an embarrassment that they had to make a remake of this when certain filmmakers in Hollywood are not clever enough to come up with originals. Great thriller: intelligent, disturbing, and amazingly well acted by the cast.

Sorority sisters are terrorized by obscene phone calls in their sorority house at Christmas. Eventually, there is a murder. "Black Christmas" is a whodunit but with a twist ending that I find mildly dissatisfying.Much of the plot consists of routine chitchat and the comings and goings of the girls. So viewers will need to find one or more characters entertaining in some way to maintain interest in the plot. The elderly house mom who likes to sneak a drink from a cleverly hidden bottle provides comic relief. What these people don't know, but we viewers do, is that the killer is somewhere inside the large multistory house, watching and stalking them.Many scenes take place at night, and most are dimly lit, with spooky side lighting. The usual Christmas carols, peaceful and reassuring, are punctuated by the discordant sounds of piano strings that signal that the killer is nearby and/or active in some way. Adding to the tension and terror are sound effects, including the whistling of wind through the trees, footsteps of the killer, and his hesitant breathing. Several scenes are photographed from the killer's POV. Casting and acting are generally acceptable.The subplot about the outdoor search party seemed distracting and irrelevant to me; it could have been left out. Scenes at the police station also detract from the appropriately claustrophobic atmosphere of the sorority house.Despite an unsatisfying ending, the excellent color photography, music, and sound effects throughout the plot magnify suspense and mystery. Which renders "Black Christmas" a must-see for Horror genre viewers.
