And the film inaugurates a script formula that was so successful that it has been copied many times by other movies since this film first appeared some forty years ago, to render it a must-see for film historians.

So, I've just come back from a Re-Release of this & thought it was alright. I've seen it once before on DVD years ago back in 2015 if I remember rightly.The film sees a group of Sorority Girls being hassled with obscene phone calls by an unknown caller. It is then that when Bodies start to pile, that the they grow closer to finding out the person responsible.I found the film to be borderline average. While it's a classic film, I found it for the most part to be pretty slow boring & lacking. With a Body count of only 5, 1 of which was only slightly gruesome, it wasn't great as such. For 97 minutes (1 hour & 37 minutes), the film does an alright job in conveying a creepy atmosphere. The killer being kept out of sight was suspenseful as with the brooding feel felt in the house scenes.I much prefer the 2006 remake over this, it's gruesome, short to the point & improves on what this film lacks. I'm not saying this film is terrible, but too much time is spent on the talking scenes & characters & less on the horror, gore & scares.Overall, it's not a bad film. Hey, it's better than that abysmal 2019 remake by Blumhouse. While the dark, brooding mood & suspense is there in this film with some not bad kills, it does unfortunately lack in horror sadly & of course is a bit dated. But it's not a bad watch & has its good moments despite its flaws. I'd recommend this over the 2019 at least.5/10.

reviews.review_title: Good, but far from great horror thriller (SPOILERS HEREIN!!!)
reviews.content: Black Christmas was a good movie. In fact, it could have reached Hitchcockian greatness if not for two flaws: 1.) Why did the police decide Peter was the killer after Jess killed him? Hadn't it already been established that he had been in the room when one of the calls had been made? This is more than a nitpicky point -- it shakes the foundations of the whole story.2.) Now, this one is more subjective. I had trouble rooting for Jess because she was such a vicious ice queen. In all honesty, I felt sorry for Peter. First, his girlfriend tells him that she's pregnant, going to have an abortion, and there's no damn way she'll consider otherwise. As a result, a crucial recital goes down very badly. And on top of it all, the poor guy gets killed and he hadn't even killed anyone.Sure, the guy may have been a trifle high-strung, but Jess comes off as plain selfish. If she was planning to have an abortion and would consider no other option, why did she even bother to tell the guy, especially on the day of his recital? By the end of the movie, I was rooting for "Billy" to go psycho on her ass.Women with major moral flaws were often featured in Hitchcock's films. However, he worked it so we cheered for them in spite of their flaws. This movie expects us to cheer for the heroine because of them. Thirty-one years on, it doesn't wash.

reviews.review_title: Memorable Horror Film was ahead of its time before John Carpenter's Halloween was released.
reviews.content: During the Christmas Holidays season. Members of a sorority house for young woman receives, what they thought was a obscene phone call and the calls gets seriously disturbing each time. When one of the sorority girls is missing. They become scared and they wonder, what is going on not realizing that the deranged psychopath is in their house.Directed by Bob Clark (Porky 1 & 2, A Christmas Story, Murder by Decree) made a extremely bizarre but original horror film. The film was release a few years before John Carpenter's Halloween was release. Black Christmas and Halloween have some similarities in the storytelling.The latest DVD has an fine anamorphic Widescreen (1.78:1) transfer and an digitally remastered-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound.The new 2006 DVD re-release has new features like new interviews with the cast and crew. The film has a strong cast like Olivia Hussey (Franco Zeffifelli's Romeo and Juliet), Keir Dullea (2001:A Space Odyssey), John Saxon (Enter the Dragon) and Andrea Martin (Cannibal Girls). The film is well made, it's has the right atmosphere and it's quite frightening. One of the best horror films of that era, especially when it doesn't end with the easy way out. Although the real stealing performance is Margot Kidder (The Superman Films) as a Vulgar, Alcoholic Kid with Asthma. Screenplay by Roy Moore. Followed by a remake. (****/*****).

This an average horror film, with a good story line.  The story doesn't hold up throughout though.  It's kind of confusing.  Anyway, Olivia Hussey as our main star is super terrific.  Margot Kidder as the drunk sorority house sister gets what she deserves.  There are some suspenseful scenes which are well done.  John Saxon as the lead detective is wonderful as always.  The bumbling cop and one of the deceased girl's boyfriends are Porky's alumni, since this film is from the same director.  5/10 Average

The attic of a girl's sorority house during the holiday season becomes a nesting place for a grunting maniac, who scales the trellis one evening and begins to murder women amidst the snow and good cheer of Christmas carols. The madman uses the telephone to call the girls and taunts them with noises and deranged ramblings in a very unsettling manner. Olivia Hussey stars as the main innocent girl who is on the receiving end, with Margot Kidder as one of her no-nonsense loudmouth friends. The dependable John Saxon takes on the part of a police lieutenant who tries to help.The first thing I want to say about the film is that it's not unlike everything we've seen since in later slasher movies. Every cliché is present: the heavy-breathing psycho, the obscene phone calls; the terrified girl on the other end who is incredibly stupid; the grisly murder techniques; the killer's point of view shots... There is a sense of the familiar here, and I was almost prepared to give the movie a half-star less rating until I reminded myself .. this film came first, BEFORE all those other clones. Director Bob Clark has said that John Carpenter liked this film, and we can see some of its influence in Carpenter's HALLOWEEN, which often gets all the credit. But it's not the fault of the more rare BLACK Christmas that it spawned all the copycats which make it seem like one of them itself; I'd imagine this trend setter felt much more cutting edge in 1974, and that's why I gave it the extra boost it deserves. There is good and bad here ... I have yet to enjoy Margot Kidder in anything, and her drunken sleaze-mouth character here is annoying, as is the fat female den mom who's got a bottle of booze hidden everywhere in the house ... but not to worry. The killer, who's identity is a mystery, manages to be scary just through his eerie phone calls and creepy sounds. The idea of all this gruesome mayhem as a parallel to the joyous Christmas events happening on the side achieves the proper disturbing effect. The look of the large spooky house from the outside, complete with the image in the attic window, is haunting. The movie is not completely original, but it deserves extra credit for setting up so many now-patented and tried and true horror film clichés. *** out of ****

reviews.review_title: Black Christmas: A Frightening Holiday Slasher
reviews.content: After "Psycho," and "Peeping Tom," people wonder whether movies like "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" or "Halloween" invented the slew of slasher films that we get today. But hardly anyone gives credit to a 1974 film directed by Bob Clark that guarantees some serious chills. It's frightening, and weird, and yet, "Black Christmas" goes unnoticed. Perhaps the older genre fans have set aside a place in history for the film, but the more contemporary audiences hardly know it exists. This is where my review of "Black Christmas" begins.A figure approaches the Pi Kappa Sig sorority house. He climbs up the ladder to the highest window, and isolates himself in the attic. Below the attic door is a party. The sisters of the sorority (including Jess, Clare, Phyllis, and Barb) are enjoying themselves one last time before Christmas break. Many of them are leaving for the holidays while the rest stick around over the weekend to clean house with their house mother, Mrs. MacHenry(also known as Mrs. Mac). But as the obscene phone calls from an anonymous voice continue, and the girls quickly begin to disappear, the yuletide festivities are coming to a close and terror is setting in.Many movie buffs know Bob Clark for his classic comedies "A Christmas Story" and "Porky's," but don't let the fact that he directed "Black Christmas" fool you. The film is dark, and sincerely one of the scariest movies ever made.As I've stated before, the importance of the film lies within the fact that it was released four years before "Halloween." So, which film started the slasher saga? The argument has lasted forever. However, comparisons should not be drawn between the two. They are their own films with their own significance to the horror genre.The ingenious idea of inserting such a happy time of year into a time of fear and despair works extremely well. Since the film is set around Christmas time, the feeling of the holiday is evident throughout. There are decorations everywhere, as well as Christmas trees and snow. Throw the color of red onto snow, and the mood easily changes.Thanks to Roy Moore's script, not only does "Black Christmas" have a load of atmosphere, but it is also host to a series of some of the most profane, shocking, and outright creepy phone calls of all time. During the first call, the killer uses very foul language, and when Barb challenges him, his tone changes, and we hear a rather humanly voice simply say "I'm gonna kill you." From then forth, we are scared not just for ourselves, but for the sorority sisters also.You see, the characters of the film have such likability. Barb is the life of the party, but she means well. Poor Jess has a struggling relationship with her boyfriend Peter, who joyously accepts that she is pregnant but immediately becomes furious when he finds out that she's planning an abortion. These characters feel real, even when there's some comic relief from the house mother and the police department. You don't want to see them die.Telling from the phone calls, the killer keeps everything under wraps. We don't know who he is or what he plans to do, but he gives himself slight recognition of his identity by simply nicknaming himself 'Billy.' The rest of the time, we never truly see the face of the villain. In fact, we don't see much of him period. When we do feel his presence, it is in his perspective, from his point of view. While he's freaking out in the attic, we're freaking out in the attic. When he's killing somebody, we become him. It's an uncomfortable and horrifying notion, and that's why it works.In terms of acting, the cast is above average. Olivia Hussey (whose star quality was projected in "Romeo & Juliet") makes for a terrific Scream Queen as Jess. Also, the early Andrea Martin and Margot Kidder keep things going as Phyllis and Barb. The appearance of genre vet John Saxon as Lieutenant Fuller is also worth noting, as well as Keir Dullea ("2001: A Space Odyssey") as Peter.All in all, it's a shame that the subordinate remake of this fright-fest got minimal attention and the original film got no attention at all. Thankfully, a DVD release has fixed the problem, and more fans have found a place in their heart for the film. It's still not as popular as "Halloween" is, but "Black Christmas" is a horror classic. It will scare and shock you, and equally provide you with a healthy dose of entertainment. This one's a must-see!P.S. The "eye behind the door" scene still keeps me up at night!

All of the tropes were begun here including many that Halloween ripped off and got credit for. But this was the originator and still holds up, even if the technology in it doesn't. Very well done with genuine suspense.

Bob Clark, whose life was cut short earlier this year by a freak accident, will always be a genre hero; after all, this is the man who gave us the controversial Vietnam-horror allegory "Deathdream" (1974), the playful Romero homage "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things" (1972), and the celebrated holiday comedy, "A Christmas Story" (1983). "Black Christmas," a seasonal slasher that predated "Halloween" by 4 years, establishes the formula with grace, subtlety, and skill, threaded with Clark's strong sense of small-town Americana (shots are composed with the biographical artistry of a Norman Rockwell painting). An obscene phone-caller is harassing the girls of a sorority house; one of the girls and the housemother (an inspired comic performance by Marian Waldman) go missing; and our protagonist, Jess (Olivia Hussey) is looking to get an abortion, much to the objection of her boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea). Happy holidays, indeed! Roy Moore's screenplay takes a simple premise and lets the layers play out naturally--the collegiate and small-town humor still resonates today, and the characters are played with a minimum of exaggeration (as I said about the Clark-produced "Deranged," we feel like we KNOW these people); my only complaint is that not all of the characters are well-integrated, and some disappear for long stretches at a time. Otherwise, we have some iconic figures that clearly influenced Carpenter's babysitters: Hussey as the Final Girl, Margot Kidder as the hard-drinking joker, and Andrea Martin as the straight- yet-slightly-gawky good girl. The legendary John Saxon is his usual excellent self as the local police captain. And Clark/Cronenberg regular Les Carlson ("Deranged," "A Christmas Story," "Videodrome") has a small role that is the crux of most of the film's suspense (he's the phone-company employee tracking the source of the obscene calls through switchboards as high as the stacks at the Library of Congress). "Black Christmas" is one of the best slashers out there, and certainly one of the most influential (next to "Psycho")--raise some eyebrows at this year's holiday gathering by putting this on right after "A Christmas Story" (and vive la difference!).

reviews.review_title: Season's Griefings, The Gore the Merrier
reviews.content: Intelligent, frightful, part of the 1970s "Big 3", which includes "Halloween" (1978) and "When A Stranger Calls" (1979). Olivia Hussey is fine as a sorority sister who is terrorized by unnerving calls to the house by an obscene presence. Margot Kidder, as an asthmatic sister, is foul-mouthed, funny, and outstanding. Keir Dullea plays a possibly disturbed pianist, who is also Hussey's boyfriend. The setting at Christmas time with all the lights, snow, coldness, is well-presented. The sorority house is suitably creepy, atmospheric, and claustrophobic, even in the Christmas decor. An "eyeball" scene may freeze your blood, and the closing scenes are startling.

Margot kidder is excellent in this a great performance,
Her lines just crackle

They were receiving obscene phone calls at the sorority house. It seems that the definition of cool has changed a lot ever since as Barb was trying so hard to be cool and so do that angry sweaty pianist but they were so cringe. Claire was killed first at the party and she was put on a rocking chair wrapped in plastic. A children found in the park murdered and the sorority girls joined the search party with the father of Claire for Claire. reviews.review_title: Successful classic horror film that still chills today
reviews.content: Despite being over 30 years old, Bob Clark's "Black Christmas" has retained its ability to chill.From the original, expletive filled and truly disturbing 'phone call at the start of the film to its final scene, this movie is an uncompromising slasher film. The haunting image of the first victim will linger with the viewer long after the end credits have rolled.The cast are excellent and the director's groundbreaking POV shots for the killer are still effective, despite having been used in practically every serial killer film since.Atmospheric, mysterious and disturbing, "Black Christmas" remains a cracker of a film to watch during the festive season with the lights turned off.

Director Bob Clark is best known for his 1983 film A Christmas Story, the feel-good tale of a child who wants a Red Rider BB gun from Santa Claus. What a lot of people don't know, however, is that Mr. Clark has approached the holiday season from a much darker perspective. And his 1974 slasher, Black Christmas, is surprisingly effective.I'll be completely honest. I expected shoddy acting and lame scares to abound. Black Christmas does have its fair share of the preceding, but it also generates a somber, brooding atmosphere that's heightened by the frenzied piano stylings of a college student, named Peter, who appears to be on the verge of mental collapse. This guy is dating one of the sisters who lives in the sorority house where the bulk of the terror takes place—this comes in the form of harassing phone calls and some odd, funhouse-mirror-style first-person perspectives—and he's meant to be suspect number one. The elusive psycho's identity is never revealed, and it's clear that screenwriter Roy Moore wants us to believe that Peter is, in fact, the bad guy, but some last-second revelations result in the old switcheroo. This, along with a number of other strategies used in Black Christmas, seem frighteningly clichéd in this day and age, but I can only imagine that they were fairly groundbreaking during their own time (okay, so Psycho is really the movie that spawned the modern slasher, but let's at least give credit to a movie that's notably more tense than most of the horror to emerge from contemporary Hollywood).As previously disclosed, this isn't to say that Black Christmas doesn't have faults. Some of the acting—and corresponding character responses— to what's going on in and around said sorority house are completely unbelievable. The father of a missing sister, for example, calmly explores the campus when his daughter doesn't show-up for a rendezvous they had planned early one afternoon. Even after the police get involved and it's somewhat clear that foul play is afoot, this guy never exhibits any urgent sense of emotion to locate his daughter. There's also the presence of a pointless old woman who, for one inexplicable reason or another, lives in the sorority house. She curses and has liquor stashed in books and septic tanks throughout the home. I'm guessing she was meant to serve as some sort of comic foil, but she's more of an annoyance than anything else.That's Black Christmas in a nutshell. Would I recommend it as a cozy little holiday horror movie? Sure. It's certainly not bad, and it has its creepy moments, but don't expect the reinvention (or invention?) of the wheel.
No wonder this is so many peoples' favorite horror film. Tension and dread at their literal peak. Absolutely phenomenal.

Well, here's a picture full of Christmas cheer and the milk of human kindness and all that. It's time to bring up all that turkey you've tried so hard to keep down.Dear me, what have women done to Mr Moore to cause him to write such an impassioned love letter to the great God misogyny? He doesn't like them one bit in this picture and nor, it seems, does Bob Clark, the director. The stabbing scene is a little too long and lovingly composed, you know what I mean? Women are portrayed as drunks, promiscuous, baby killers, foul mouthed, amoral, men hating, jealous, covetous, venal and unprofessional. They are also seemingly deaf, unable to hear a man clambering up a drain pipe which would bring the rest of us outside like a shot. The only virtuous one is dispatched straight away. The rest are stupid. We are led to believe that after being told to leave the house immediately after being informed of the location of the obscene calls our heroine would march right up the stairs.Why is it that the calls always have to be coming from inside the house in these films? Why not surprise us by having them come from the bottom of a swimming pool or a zeppelin? How about the MIR space station? Seeing as it hadn't even been launched during the seventies it would have been quite a plot twist. But no, *yawn* THEY'RE COMING FROM INSIDE THE HOUSE! Dan-Dan. And why is the cop who guards the house always dead in the car? Didn't he notice the very obvious sight of someone jumping down from the side of the house and opening his car door? No, they are hired by the police department for their myopia and narcolepsy and complete lack of professionalism such as failing to search an entire house after they know a killer's been hiding in it. They must be desperate to go and get some turkey, providing they can keep it down, that is.And why do killers always have to have nasal problems? It seems to be a given that any one suffering from any sort of mental illness in films must also have bronchial pneumonia and the stumbling gate of a werewolf with a club foot. So they didn't get what they wanted for Christmas. Go and sulk in the corner of the sofa like the rest of us instead of running up someone else's phone bill and sculking around their house with one eye. The only stranger we want to see coming through the window at Christmas is Santa Clause and even then this guy would probably throttle his reindeer. Sheesh!The nastiness of this film has to be seen to be believed. A man we know has lost his daughter is treated with sadistic contempt by the writer (through a woman, of course.) It's a fascinating reminder of how the medium can be mis-used by those whose sole interest is making money.

reviews.review_title: Not sure what all the fuss is about?
reviews.content: I came across this movie in my local Blockbuster store. I had never heard of it but before renting it I checked out the reviews and it seemed like a great one to rent. Now that I've seen it, I don't understand why so many think this was so scary. The movie seemed very slow at times. Also, there really was not much blood, gore, or killings. I did think that the phone calls were very creepy. I hated the end of this movie. There was no explanation for anything that happened. I felt like I watched the movie and I'm still waiting for it to end. Just horrible. Probably the worst ending ever. I did enjoy a young John Saxon though. I guess this movie is worth a viewing but that's about it. I also don't understand why some are comparing this to Halloween? There are no similarities and Halloween is a million times better than this.

reviews.review_title: One of the first and finest slasher films
reviews.content:
A staple in horror history and an influence on the genre and start of the slasher era. One of my personal favorite horror films. I still do prefer John Carpenter's Halloween, but Black Christmas delivers a great combination of suspense and horror, along with an original and well written plot. You hardly ever see the killer yet this movie was horrifying for its time. Its mostly because the writing of the script, its suspensful, tactical, and realistic. You can relate to the situation, you can imagine yourself in this situation because it is much more realistic than a lot of horror movies. Not showing the killer till the end was an important aspect to this film, it slowly built up a plot, we got connected to some of the characters, once that connection happened, the horror starts. An underrated slasher forsure. Overall just a great horror film that any fan of the genre should see and own.
The 70's did horror best
If you're the type of persons into the horror flicks / Slasher And you will love black Christmas 1974.

reviews.review_title: It's a Lot Better than the Remake
reviews.content: This 98-minute film is a stark and stylish horror/thriller that turns everyone's favorite time of the year inside out. Olivia Hussey and Margot Kidder star among an ill-fated houseful of sorority sisters celebrating the holiday season. Festivities turn fatal when obscene phone calls break the serenity and it becomes clear that a psychopath is stalking the house.Instead of watching this movie first, I watched the remake of it, which was horrible. Watching this, I was surprised how many small body counts there are compared to the remake but I wasn't surprised it was less bloody, which is a good thing. The violence, which was the problem in the remake, does not turn you off.What I like about this movie is that it focuses more on the characters than the kills. I love the characters, including Marian Waldman and Margot Kidder, both who seem to have a good time giving us plenty of laughs. I also like Olivia Hussey's performance.Yeah, there are some clichés here but it was made in the past, okay? I didn't mind the generic ending, which is used in most horror movies these days. What I also like in here is the suspense. There are some scenes that really scares you.I'm sure this movie is underrated and should be better than it is today. It's a good horror movie if you want a fun and scary time. It's not a masterpiece in anyway but it's better than most horror movies, even the remake.

My favorite film is and always will be My Bloody Valentine (1981). However, I love slasher films in general and Black Christmas sadly was remade in 2006, leaving this nostalgic original thrill-ride behind in the dust. What people forget often is that this one is way better in terms of characters, plot and soundtrack. I will say that the phone call they got in the first few minutes was incredibly disgusting and seemed over-the-top even for a horror film, but aside from that, this is one slasher you won't want to pass up! Nothing says Merry Christmas like a crazy maniac making prank calls and killing girls in a sorority house!

Finally, a second viewing of a slasher classic, or at least a father to the slasher genre, though not the only one; 'Psycho' (1960), 'The girl who knew too much' (1963), 'Reazione a catena' (1971) and maybe even the elusive 'Delitto al luna park' (1952), if one is willing to interconnect the giallo with the slasher - they all amount to one big happy bloody (this one is relatively not so bloody, by the way) family to me. This one I remember as being particularly atmospheric and creepy, but I never rated it higher than 7 out of 10.After having seen it again just the other night, a theory entered my mind: the piano player did it after all! I have several observations to substantiate this, but first, a few things which director Bob Clarke has stated (if I may believe the - very interesting! - list of trivia here on IMDb): 1. 'Clark (-) insisted that the ending be ambiguous', which means Clark máy have had a certain explanation in mind. 2. 'Clark considered it to be more of a psychological horror film than a slasher film', which will fall exactly in line with my theory. 3. '...The ending of the film forces people to think independently' Again, not a debunking, nor a confirmation, so...So, Peter did it, I'm thinking now. Why? The ending (in the attic', which could be metaphorically observed as 'the mind', the 'top floor') is a way to mess with the viewer and offers an insight to the schizophrenic mind. Next, all the times and places when and where Peter could be at the times of the calls and the murders pan out. In other words, he has NO alibi(s)! Then there are the strange coincidences. Peter shows up behind Jess just after she received a call and the reason he wouldn't kill her right then and there, is because he may still hope for her to choose to have their baby. This 'baby' (/abortion) motif that haunts Peter is also is very important to my theory, as the caller's voices refer to it many times - 'baby Agnes'... When he is finally convinced Jess will not have the baby and she tries to escape, he makes his final move. Which brings us all to the basement (scene). How coincidental would it be that Peter would just show up there, let alone that he knows Jess is there?In terms of general logics it is very strange that the whole house wasn't searched when Clare went missing, when some even feared she might have hurt herself. I mean, it is just common sense then, to check the attic and the basement (if not by the police, then certainly by her roommates and friends) - another little sign? I'm really unsure about that part. All in all, my theory does agree with Clark's statement that this is a psychological horror; Peter is both the brilliant and savvy artist, ánd the demented and traumatized killer - a schizophrenic if I'm not mistaken.Perhaps the film should be considered a hermetic, atmospheric piece of modern art, disguised as a slasher (oops, that term wasn't even invented yet in 1974!) with comedic elements - I know(!); something dirty, ain't it?" Personally, I didn't know whether to love or hate those 'funny parts' (the silly cop, the drunk lady of the house), but there's always next time...In any case, it is a most artful thriller of the eeriest kind, I was way off with my first rating; 9 out of 10 this time around.

reviews.review_title: A little dated, but still better than 60% of horror films released lately.
reviews.content: Every time a remake is released (which is almost every week) these days I feel more compelled to seek out the source material to see why it needed remaking in the first place, as in 90% of cases the remake is worse or just as lousy as the original.I never saw the remake of Black Christmas, it looked altogether too teen-y for me and I'm not a big slasher flick fan anyway. But I did read something that said that it was a remake of perhaps the first slasher flick, which at least piqued my interest as it is always interesting to see where certain genres originated.After viewing what is immediately evident is that 35 odd years ago it was apparently unsettling enough to simply set up the kill and then have the killer do the rest. There are no intricate 7 minute "creeping through the halls" or red herring scares here, the victims decide to do something, enter the room in which they will do that thing, and the killer does the rest quickly and in straightforward fashion.Nowadays to achieve the same result the filmmakers have to build the tension or ramp up the gore, guess which one they normally go for ('eh Eli?).The supposed big twist (copied by Scream) is actually made evident in the very opening scene, as we are introduced to "Stalker-Cam" (TM) as someone cases a house from the outside, while a party seems to be going on inside. Said individual then climbs up and into the attic of the house.It turns out we are in what I think they call a frat-house in the US, a communal dorm for students, in this case all female with a middle aged, seemingly alcoholic dorm mother.The girls are having an end of term party before either heading home or settling in for the Christmas holidays. The party is interrupted by an obscene phone call, as the girls are all in their late teens / early 20s they put the phone on speaker and have a chuckle. Of course some are offended and others get into the swing of things and actually try to talk back to the caller, but ultimately no harm is done and they hang up, thinking that's that.Seeing as the film doesn't waste time in building tension or suspense, we get a fair bit of time spent getting to know the individual girls, there are no cardboard cut-outs here (I'm talking to you Friday the 13th remake!), there are drunken sluts, naive young women and other normal girls, same as every group of students. They are beset by the usual circumstances that occur to the age group, horny suitors, teenage pregnancy, busybody adults and the allure of alcohol and mischief.When quite suddenly (to them at least) a member of their number goes missing, they don't just shrug it off as so many crappy horror movies do today by saying "Oh, she must have gone to the shops" or "She'll show up", they treat the disappearance seriously, and as they care for their missing friend so too does the audience care more.The crank calls keep coming and they keep getting more and more disturbing, I would question why the girls keep listening but it is a movie after all. In between a small collection of bodies builds up, again this isn't a 73 dead slash fest as many are today and the remaining girls come across all sorts of roadblocks when trying to solve the issue, not the least of which is incompetent police work.When the ending comes it is in keeping with the rest of the flick, straightforward and basic, and there is no realllll surprise unless you have never ever seen a horror film in your life. What would concern though is the outrageously terrible police investigation that follows that wraps everything up so nicely whilst ignoring so many events and incidents.Again, this was the 70s, maybe they just didn't care too much back then about the details.Final Rating – 7 / 10. You aren't going to see anything new, but I'd rather watch this than most big budget horror remakes churned out these days.If you liked this review (or even if you didn't) check out oneguyrambling.com

I had to put the word 'very' four times in my summary because it was the only way to describe this chilling little film from 1974.The best horrors are the ones that imply horror rather than show it. This film is about a telephone killer who terrorizes a sorority house and kills several young ladies. It is a truly creepy film, a lot creepier than watching some guy with a hood on stalking a load of women with an axe. After all, what's more scary-a knife wielding maniac in front of you who you can at least fight or a mysterious anonymous psycho terrorizing you over the telephone?There are good performances throughout particularly from Margot Kidder and John Saxon and this is a horror I would urge anyone to check out.One more thing-the ending is frightening. The movie was scary throughout but after the film ended I felt a sense of unease. And that is what a good horror movie should be about-scaring the audience to death.If you suffer from a nervous disposition then do watch a little bit of this film but if you are the nervous sort, do not watch the ending. It will scare you.

This film came out when I was eleven years old and I remember sneaking into the local theatre to see it, as it was rated restricted at the time. I didn't sleep for days afterward! I now own the collectors edition of film and watch it at least once a year. My 19 year old son is somewhat of a film buff himself and I had him watch it with me a few years back for the first time. He was very impressed with it as well.Margot Kidder puts in a winning performance as Barb, the lonely attractive, abusive and constantly drunk sorority sister who flirts with anything in pants. Olivia Hussey is convincing as Jess, the lead female, who has to deal with a pregnancy, a highly strung piano playing boyfriend, and a weirdo who calls on the phone.One thing that really bothered me in this film - I wish Peter would have gotten rid of that coat. Fashion statement, NOT! ;o) I highly recommend this film.

Most of the time I was bored.The acting doesn't amount to much and the story drags. There is one stretch towards the end of the movie that is suspenseful, but it peters out.The way in which the movie is made is very good. The problem is there are no characters to give a hoot about and no real story within which to involve them.It's not unique; it's not engaging.It might have been a good drive-in movie to snuggle up to a date. But I wasn't in a car, and this didn't set any mood.A passable bit of time wasting.

reviews.review_title: Early Canadian/slasher flick is better than expected
reviews.content: Created when both Canadian cinema and slasher movies were in their infancy, Black Christmas is a film that effectively creates a creepy atmosphere with solid production values. It follows a familiar plot where a college sorority is receiving obscene phone calls, before each of the girls is murdered in the house. Eventually, the police trace the calls and they're finding they're coming from the house, too. I wondered if this movie started the cliché- I just looked it up and see the urban legend goes back to the '60s. It's not much of a surprise that the calls were coming from the house, even overlooking how well-known the cliché is now- for one thing, the killer is clearly in the house, and at another point, it's mentioned there's two lines.Some parts of this movie are well-done. Take the fact that one of the girls is killed while children are downstairs singing Christmas carols. That's juxtaposition reminiscent of the baptismal scene in The Godfather, though not as great. The movie is a little silly after the call is traced- Jess could have saved her skin instantly by taking three steps towards the door and going out to the police. Instead, she goes up the stairs. Reminds me of Tippi Hedren asking Hitchcock why she would go into the room at the end of The Birds (1963). Hitchcock's reply: "Because I told you to."I heard this movie described as a whodunit, but it's not much of a whodunit. The movie leads you to believe the protagonist Jess' boyfriend Peter is the killer even before the police identify him as a suspect. Then it's revealed it's not him... it's not entirely clear who it is. It could just be some random guy. That was kind of cheap, and the implication that he killed Jess, while cold and creepy, wouldn't have been as satisfying as the damsel-in-distress killing the bad guy. Oh well- Black Christmas works, and is a fine film for what it is.

Run of the mill slasher flick featuring the classic killer's P.O.V. which was used so effectively in Peeping Tom (1960) and imitated many times since. Boring, predictable and badly acted for the most part.  Even the murders suffer from a lack of a novel approach.  I did like the sicko's voice during the obscene phone calls and the scenes in the attic were creepy enough.  Had to watch the ending a few times cause I thought I'd missed something.  Turns out I didn't.  It's just bungled and falls rather flat. 
Perhaps this film was considered innovative at the time of its 1974 release, but it certainly hasn't aged well.  Worth checking out if you're a true fan of the genre, but there's nothing here you haven't seen before.  A far cry from what I consider Bob Clark's best horror film, Deathdream, a.k.a. Dead Of Night, a.k.a. The Night Andy Came Home.

Predating Halloween and it's countless clones in the stalk'n slash genre, I have to say this movie really serves up the goods. Sure, to today's audience it may seem a bit slow and dated but to the true fan, this is a masterpiece of the genre. A madman hides in the attic of a sorority house, telephones the girls from upstairs and eventually starts killing some of them.So many elements have been lifted from this film and utilized to great effect, think of When A Stranger Calls, Halloween, Scream and countless sorority slashers to name a few, this movie has to be termed as somewhat of a groundbreaker. Filmed with a low budget, director Clark relies solely on mood, lighting and atmosphere to give the film it's edge. He succeeds brilliantly. Apart from a rather tedious 10-15 minute segment involving the housekeeper of the sorority the film absolutely keeps it's tension filled grip on the viewer and doesn't let go at all. I even found myself shouting at the tube, telling the girl "don't do this, don't go there", and I can't remember ever doing this before or after. Watching it alone (plus, it was at Christmas time) the film totally freaked me out. Acting is way above average for a slasher flick. Olivia Hussey, besides being a total knockout, is very good in the lead role. Margot "Lois Lane" Kidder is a delight as the foul mouthed drunk, Keir Dullea fairly creepy as Hussey's not-so-sane boyfriend and genre favourite John Saxon is good as always. For the most part, the humour goes down well also. One particularly funny scene involving a not so bright cop, but that seems to be a regular in Clark's films. If you're a fan of horror films, it doesn't get much better than this. Highly recommended.

This one is a slasher classic. It will always be a 10/10 on my affective memory. After rewatching, I remembered I don't appreciate the Christmas aesthetic that much and that the script wastes much time telling a story that runs through days. I think that's why the 2006' remake works better for me. But I can't deny this movie's pretty much atmospheric and tense, especially on the 3d act.

BLACK CHRISTMAS is one of the best of the horror genre and HALLOWEEN, although a great film itself, borrows much from this film - John Carpenter was friends with Bob Clark and even had asked Clark if he was going to do a sequel. Bob Clark, director of the excellent CHILDREN SHOULDN'T PLAY WITH DEAD THINGS and DEATHDREAM, told Carpenter that he was not going to do a sequel, but, if he was, it would be called HALLOWEEN. Carpenter's opening is very similar in style to Clark's opening, as if the killer POV camera work and the killer lurking out of the frame. Olivia Hussey is not the virginal heroine (her character is pregnant and determined to abort the baby) and a lot of film books and reviews incorrectly identify Keir Dullea as the killer when he is obviously not. I have heard complaints regarding the ending and the unknown identity of the killer because most viewers have been conditioned to have everything explained to them & tied up in a neat little package, a la the ending of PSYCHO, but that only makes the film more unique. It was one of the first and the acting is superb for this type of effort. In a fair world it would be every bit as popular as HALLOWEEN, but given the amount of posts for this film, it shows that BLACK CHRISTMAS is very much appreciated by horror fans. I read an interview with Bob Clark on FANGORIA'S web site that a remake of BLACK CHRISTMAS is in the works, as well as a remake of DEATHDREAM and either a remake or sequel to CHILDREN SHOULDN'T PLAY WITH DEAD THINGS. Another great Bob Clark film worth checking out is MURDER BY DECREE, in which Sherlock Holmes takes on the Jack the Ripper slayings. It's a shame that Clark turned his back on the horror genre after BLACK CHRISTMAS and directed crap like the PORKY'S movies and LOOSE CANNONS. If he would have kept his hand at horror, I predict that he would have been one of the biggest names in the field today.

it has a lot of elements that have been used since a million times over...the caller in the same house.widelens action of a madman...i do also think that this has gotten a little old this movie.and another thing i don't get, that i've read quite a bit of psychology, and i know from fact that most murderers are sexual freaks...i mean almost all movies have just people doing murders, while in reality it's almost always connected with rape or sexual perversions... the murderer was a pervert on the phone, but his actions were not like that.i think it's the American hypocrisy in this movie also. sex is evil while violence is OK.we'll you could watch this from a old movie channel, but i wouldn't even rent =/

This is one of those popular horror movies released the same decade as Carrie movie, or John Carpenter's Halloween or George Romero's Dawn of the Dead. Sometimes I get bored of old-fashioned movies.The cast in this movie consist of deceased Margot Kidder, Olivia Hussey and even deceased John Saxon (a decade before he's Nancy's dad in Wes Craven's original Nightmare on Elm Street movie). Indeed, this movie has it's high feel of suspense and terror even with camera shots like this unidentified stalker is watching the sorority sisters inside the house and is hiding in the attic. I hate when he's screaming and trashing the place like pissed off for no reason. Also, there was a low number of kills even some are completely or partially off-screen.Like in many horror movies, the police in this are completely incompetent and not very helpful. I somewhat don't like how the movie ends without giving the viewers any idea as to who the prank caller and killer is, more details as to why he's harassing the sorority sisters and whether the bodies of Clare and Mrs Mac will be discovered in the attic, and if Peter was truly innocent before Jess killed him.Overall, I haven't decided whether I really don't much prefer this movie more than the 2006 remake - the one with Katie Cassidy and Mary Elizabeth Winstead.

This movie has been promoted as the inspiration for "Halloween", and there are some similarities, but to tell you the truth, "Black Christmas" has always been so little known that I would be surprised if it influenced "Halloween". I think it's probably more a case of great minds thinking alike.After all, there are only so many ways to do the whole "psycho stalker" thing. That said...It's a pretty good movie. Not as good as "Halloween", but still admirable. On the plus side, it has beautiful cinematography, an eerie score, a palpably creepy atmosphere, freaking scary obscene phone calls, and good acting. On the minus side, the plot rarely makes much sense, the characters are so poorly developed that the wonderful acting was the only reason I cared about them, and the scares are too obligatory, even if they're so stylistically accomplished that they manage to be tense anyway. I also have to say that I don't think the film had as much emotional resonance as it could have.Basicly, this is a movie that could easily have been a bonafide classic, if only more attention had been paid to the script before shooting started. As it is, it's a near-miss, but still more than worth watching.

My understanding is that BLACK Christmas is considered to be a cult classic because it is one of the first slasher movies; it laid the foundations for those that came later. Although pretty well done overall, it does have some problems. The film is lightly based on an urban legend - it concerns a Christmas holiday murderer who primarily targets those living in a sorority house. The killer may or may not be involved in some other murders around town, but the focus here is on the people living in the house.The acting is fairly well done by all of the cast, however, some of the characters are very one dimensional. We only see one side of their personality - the conservative virgin, the vulgar party girl and the inept policeman are perfect examples. There are others who are a little more fleshed out and have more depth to them, but the movie does suffer from that shallowness as many horror movies do.Unlike the slashers that came later, BLACK Christmas is very tame in it's graphic violence. Many of the murders take place off screen although the aftermath is generally seen. Although very little blood is filmed, the movie does have a fair amount of bad language so be warned if you don't like profanity or sexual references. It's definitely not suitable for kids.The film is really genuinely creepy in parts, especially in the interactions between the killer and the girls living in the sorority house. The ending is quite creepy as well.Parts of the movie don't make a lot of sense though. I don't want to get into any spoilers here, but lets just say that certain things should easily be heard when things are quiet. And of course, you have the character who stays and puts herself in danger when she's knows that things are quite amiss - one of my biggest pet peeves with horror movies. The film is pretty well paced overall which made it enjoyable to watch. Although some reviewers disagree, I actually did like it's final scenes but I wouldn't want to live in a town where the police don't think things through to a logical conclusion.If you like your horror tame, this one would be a pretty good choice if you can handle the vulgarity. There are other "entry level" horror films that are better, but this one is okay. I don't know that a seasoned horror buff who likes their movies bloody and violent would like it though.

This is a good movie but still is not nearly as good as Halloween.  Most of the scenes that are shared in this and Halloween are coincidental.  Black Christmas has a very creepy atmosphere but Halloween does it better.  At least I cared about whether or not Laurie died, wherehas I could care less about the main female in this.  This is a damn good horror movie, but Halloween is much better.

For you fans of "Black Christmas", take note of a bit of trivia that might have gone unnoticed.In the scene where the park is being searched, dogs are brought in to assist. What may not be so obvious is that the filmmakers apparently couldn't find any suitable Bloodhounds in the Toronto area, so they somehow found their way to my friend's father, who used to raise Black & Tan Coonhounds.Because the dogs actually get a fair bit of screen time in that scene, you can see they're not actually Bloodhounds doing the search. They're my friend's Black & Tan Coonhounds.Just a quirky detail.

Black Christmas is first of it's kind. This movie started the trend of slasher horror in hollywood. This movie inspired John Carpenter to make classic Halloween.Movie was good and enjoyable at some points but most of the time you will feel bored. Movie had some problems with pace and setting of story. Till the end of the movie, you don't know killer's intentions and most, importantly his identity. Hiding the identity is good for suspense but by the end nothing was cleared. Everything should have been shown step by step just like Halloween which helped audience to feel what's happening with the main lead but that was not the case with this one.Overall, by reading what I wrote above don't think that the movie is bad. For 1974, it is ahead of it's time and gave birth to slasher genre. It was just that after watching so many slasher movies, this one felt short.

reviews.review_title: It's actually as good, if not better than all the reviews that made me see it
reviews.content: I am a huge movie fanatic and horror is one of my favorite genres. Horror films from the 70s to the present are my favorite, but it's usually quite difficult to find the good ones amongst all the junk. I had gotten to the point to where I thought I had seen all of the great horror pictures of this time period...including...THE CHANGELING, AN American WEREWOLF IN London, THE DEAD ZONE, SHAUN OF THE DEAD, EVIL DEAD 2, THE THING (1982), HALLOWEEN, THE SHINING, SUSPIRIA, THE DESCENT, DEAD-ALIVE(aka BRAINDEAD), THE EXORCIST and THE BROOD...to name a few, so obviously I was skeptical that this film BLACK Christmas that had passed me by for almost my whole life could actually be as good as all my fellow IMDb reviewers were stating. But being a huge fan of Bob Clark's A Christmas STORY, I took a chance and purchased this DVD right out and to my surprise all of the hype didn't even begin to do this film justice. It's been compared to HALLOWEEN and John Carpenter's film is certainly one of the best of the genre but BLACK Christmas...dare I say it...is actually better..scarier and more original. First of all I was impressed by how good the film looked for its age. BLACK Christmas is a class act, with pretty fine actors, a great script and an excellent crew behind the camera. It's hard for a film to scare me after all the films I've seen but my wife and I were often creeped out by BLACK Christmas. There is very little gore and you don't see much of the killer which proves sometimes less is more...WAY MORE in this case. BLACK Christmas is now in my top five of all time horror flicks. See it if you like a good scare. BOO!

reviews.review_title: A terrifying masterpiece of the macabre!
reviews.content: It's Christmas break at a sorority house, the girls (Margot Kidder, Olivia Hussey and Andrea Martin) are planning things for Christmas vacation. Until a mysterious stranger makes weird phone calls as he torments the girls then sneaks into the attic of the house as he starts to kill some of the girls one by one. The police are concerned by strange murders going on especially the discovery of a dead 13 year old girl in a park but can the cops find this psychopath or will he have his bloody hands on the entire household? Suspenseful and masterful psychological horror slasher flick from Canada and writer-director Bob Clark who would later give us "Porky's" and "A Christmas Story". It's a true masterpiece of the slasher genre in the 70's with "Texas Chainsaw Massacre", "Halloween", "Torso" and Mario Bay's "Twitch of The Death Nerve" (a.k.a. Bay of Blood) but this was before "Halloween" hit the screen 4 years later. The film also stars John Saxon who is one of cult cinema's best actors, it's a scary and chilling skin-crawler that will keep you guessing till the very end. Unlike most slasher movies which uses gore, this one uses characterizations and tension rather then just brainless blood-buckets. This is a true underrated horror masterpiece that every horror fan should seek and paved the way for other slasher flicks like "Halloween", "A Nightmare on Elm Street", "Friday The 13th", "Maniac", "Sleepaway Camp", "The Burning", "Scream" etc. as it ranks up with "Psycho".

Black christmas was sometimes scary,but wasn't as scary as I thought it would be. I can name countless horror movies that are scarier than this. Like the first halloween,the first 3 friday the 13th movies,clownhouse,prom night,the first 2 nightmare on elm street movies. The list goes on,and on, but black christmas is still scary at times. Watching this movie at night with the lights out,still really isn't as scary as watching halloween or the first 3 friday the 13th movies in the day time. I give black christmas **1/2 out of ****

This weeks entry is something special. For starters it is directed by none other than the genius behind one of the most beloved Christmas classics in the history of Christmas classics, A Christmas Story (1983). Yes, the man himself, Mr. Bob Clark. I bet you're thinking to yourself, "Self, I bet the movie this week is going to be a sweet, fun filled romp that will transport me back to when Christmas was chock full of magic and wonder." Well, you'd be wrong. Instead, The Mock Films Blog is proud to present the one, the only (unless you include the lack luster remake from 2006) Black Christmas (1974).Why, you may ask, did I choose a horror film for this joyous holiday season? Well, honestly, if we can call Die Hard (1988) a Christmas movie then we can do the same for this one. (Merry Christmas. On with the blog.) The film revolves around a group of happy-go-drinky sorority sisters getting ready for Christmas break. Little do the naive ladies know, someone other than Santa will be paying them a visit this year.What makes this film so great is that it's as funny as it is scary. Clark puts his signature subtle humor that we saw in A Christmas Story and applies it to this much earlier work. Margot Kidder as the loose cannon is really amusing, along with the booze hound house mother played by Marian Waldman. But for all of its goofiness, the scares are just as strong. From the creepy POV of the killer wandering through the house unnoticed, the disturbingly graphic prank calls made to the sisters, to the solid gore effects,this is a nasty little jump scare flick. Although, it might be a rough watch for those who are bummed out easily during the holidays (go watch A Christmas Story marathon. Bob Clark thought of you too).—

reviews.review_title: One of the BEST horror films
reviews.content: Black Christmas is a very underrated and un-recognised Canadian horror film from director Bob Clarke (probably most known for the raunchy comedy Porkys). This came before Halloween, Friday the 13th, When A Stranger Calls or A Nightmare on Elm Street. This is what started the slasher genre. This created the killer's POV shots, the creepy scores and the obscene phone calls.There really isn't a huge plot here, it is basically about a group of girls in a sorority house are being terrorised by obscene phone calls. No one has any idea who it is calling them. Slowly, each one goes missing and everyone becomes more aware of what is going on.Despite the minimal plot, this is THE slasher film. It has an extremely creepy score that will have the hairs on your neck standing, very effective cinematography (the house is perfect), a great group of younger, great camera work and older actresses/actors and it packs a walloping twist at the end. The lack of gore or violence suits the movie PERFECTLY. If they had shown the killings in full detail, it would not have been as good. One murder (involving a glass unicorn) is the stand-out, being one of the most recognised murder scenes in horror movie history.Many people consider Halloween the original slasher, that is not the case. BLACK Christmas is the ORIGINAL slasher. But it is much more than that. Instead of a cast of complete asses, we have a group of smarter people. They die not because of idiocy, but because of accident or just the wrong place in the wrong time. There is also some great humour tied in. Margot Kidder being the funniest of them all.The movie gives me the chills, especially the ending, which is the greatest in my opinion, of any horror movie. I urge anyone who considers themselves a horror fan to see this.5/5.

reviews.review_title: The slasher before the slasher era.
reviews.content: This is kind of a incredible film for 1974. It's a well wrapped movie with some all round decent performances. The plot is simple yet very effective and I don't think I've been scared of a killer in a genre like this for a while. The acting, mostly voice acting for the killer is chilling. It's really emits the sense of insanity above anything else. After watching so many horror movies, I can't believe I thought the things that I did. Especially the later sections of the movie really grab onto you.Now as for the beginning, the movie starts off pretty much right away and is very engaging at the start. Then it does get a bit tedious and drawn out around the beginning-mid section which is probably my least favorite of the movie because nothing really happens.Regarding gore this film has a very light amount. But stil enough disturbing images, especially the ''second'' kill Clare is done very effectively. So for its age, it still did a great job at being somewhat scary. Also what really helps this movie is that its pretty barebones, no special fx, no crazy plot. It's very grounded and real. One of the only caveats is the amount of plotholes and characters that ''need to be alone''. Though it wasn't that annoying. I guess the main offender in this would be Phyl.Barb was one of my favorites throughout this film and seemed to be the lead in the first part of it, Jess gradually took over and became the lead girl which was an interesting shift. That said, Barb was one of the only ones that had some comedic relief in her dialog, though I still think this movie lacks in that department. Most of it is very dry and serious.As with many slashers, the killer is important, but not here. You're not gonna know, its completely kept to your imagination. Which in this case definilty works in favor.The cinematography and directing is honestly really good as well, filled with moments where as a viewer you get real claustrophobic with slow zooms, and long ended shots. One of my favorites is of course the final scene with Jess in bed.That said this movie suffers mostly from some annoying plotholes and ''convenient'' events.All in all this is a must watch for slasher fans, and will still be pretty thrilling if you aren't one. 6.5/10.

reviews.review_title: A sorority house is terrorized by obscene phone calls, while one by one the girls are stalked from within the house.
reviews.content: It's the night before Christmas Eve at a campus sorority house when the phone rings. The muffled breaths of the caller can be heard on the other end. Soon, heavy breathing turns into lascivious outbursts, cries that egg on Barb (Margot Kidder) while unsettling the rest. Soon, nobody can find Clare (Lynne Griffin), which leads her father (James Edmond) to contact the police, lead by Lt. Fuller (John Saxon). With the disturbing calls continuing into Christmas Eve, and Jess' (Olivia Hussey) boyfriend upset, it soon becomes evident that there's more to the night than just carol's and Christmas lights.When an unsuspecting world received Black Christmas, the term and sub-genre slasher wouldn't insert itself into the mainstream canon for another 4 years. Pre-dating John Carpenter's Halloween, the aforementioned cannonball to the eyes of American cinema, our film aptly embraces the first person perspective alarmingly introduced with such films as Peeping Tom and Psycho. While the former, Michael Powell's compellingly voyeuristic tale, ultimately ushered in the perspective that would end up widely used in the genre, it wasn't until Bob Clark's holiday slasher that we would see its use popularized in film.What Black Christmas does exceptionally well is assert an uncomfortable gaze over its viewer, one that helps peel backs its grainy, exploitative layer with a razor sharp masculine fixation on the female body. We witness the sorority house from afar, only getting closer as our peeping tom does. Even when we're invited in before he climbs through an upstairs window, it's always through the perceived eyes of our voyeur. The masculine gaze controls much of our perception as he slowly preys on the sorority sisters, a light cascading across a peering eye. When Claire is strangled, her body is propped up by a window with her eyes peering out and mouth agape, echoing the sexually deranged moans of our caller.It's these perverse and sexually driven calls that push our film forward, filling every frame with tension on what we already know. Bob Clark frames the horror with staircases, doorframes and windows, utilizing these as the eyes of our killer. While we don't know who it is, we know where he is; yet this understanding only adds increased value to the terror that presses down on us. It's a pressure that weighs so heavy it rests in our stomach, a feeling Jess carries with her as she tells her boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea) of her pregnancy and impending abortion. When he tells her what she can and cannot do with her own pregnancy, he stares at her with the same fixation as our killer.Writer Roy Moore plays between the killings and a male-dominated state of mind with a juxtaposition that reverberates even more so today. Peter tells Jess that she can't kill the baby, while she never implies that it's a baby nor uses the word kills. We then shift back to the sorority house, a home that is devoid of male governance, save for the looming eyes of our intruder. The dominating male gaze echoes the dominating male voice that pushes Jess away, further into our place of murder. These transitions spur on the ominous dread that hangs in the air as each kill unfolds, our now final girl clinging to a hope we know doesn't exist.The world that Bob Clark and Roy Moore bring to life is reminiscent of its time, yet mirrors those that we live in today. Its morally strong lead, and similarly dueling views, both literally and symbolically, helped usher in the sub-genre that films like Silent Night, Deadly Night and Night of the Demons would inevitably destroy in the years to come. Black Christmas works as a powerfully affecting, unsettling piece of pre-slasher filmmaking that establishes itself as an important piece in horror cinema.

This has got to be one of the most genuinely terrifying movies I have ever seen! There are many terrifying aspects of this film. The soundtrack is horrifying with it's various screams, vocals, and the constant Twang of the piano. The atmosphere is haunting with the various camera angles showing you the killer's point of view and the consistent image of the first victim in the rocking chair with the plastic bag still wrapped around her head flashing across the screen at various moments and then there's the telephone calls. The terrifying screams, moans, and various voices that the killer uses during these calls will make the hair stand up on the back of your neck. The most terrifying aspect of this film though is the fact that you never find out who the killer really is. The viewer is lead down a particular path and falsely believes that they know the identity of the killer but then the film betrays the viewer. This is sheer cinematic genius and one of the essential elements for true terror. This film set the benchmark for future films such as "Halloween" "Friday the 13th" and "Nightmare on Elm Street"...ESSENTIAL VIEWING!

reviews.review_title: One of the creepiest films ever made - A great slasher
reviews.content: Over Christmas break, a sorority house is terrorized by a mysterious obscene caller. Eventually, the terror increases as the sorority sisters are, one by one, viciously murdered by a psychopathic killer.Let me just say: With the proper viewing atmosphere, Black Christmas can, easily, be one of the creepiest and frightening films around. Stick yourself in a dark room with no light but the Christmas tree, make sure it's nice and snowy outside, and empty the house. Have all of those, and prepare to be scared out of your wits. Unfortunately for me this time around, all I had was the dark room and empty house. No tree, no snow. But, that didn't stop the film from being nearly as chilling. In addition to the chills the film delivers, it also succeeds in its technical aspects. Moore's script is very good, with a nice even flow throughout. It manages to flesh out the 'important' characters and make them seem more complete, even though some of the other characters are pretty much forgotten. Also, though some don't, I very much liked the lack of resolution. The late Bob Clark's direction, of course, was also damn fine. It worked well and took full advantage of the beautiful sorority house. The acting, on occasion, failed. Olivia Hussey, whom I never found to be a GREAT actress, was for the most part good, but still seemed a bit over-the-top on occasion. It wasn't enough to distract from the quality however, and can easily be overlooked. In the end, Black Christmas (1974) is a success of chilling slasher cinema that fans of such films as Halloween should truly love.Obligatory Christmas-Horror Elements:Subgenre: SlasherChristmas Carols: The soundtrack is primarily made up of holiday tunes.Snow: That there is.Person in a Santa suit: Yes, we see a Santa-clad person a few times.Violence/Gore: It's not as 'bad' as the remake, but there is a bit. The deaths are certainly better here.Sex/Nudity: None, although the phone calls are pretty graphic.Scares/Suspense: Endless. This is one of the creepiest films I've ever seen and it definitely stirs deep.Mystery: Absolutely. This is one of those rare films where the mystery lasts long after the credits roll - -Final verdict: 7.5/10. See it! -AP3-

I watched Black Christmas tonight finally, after years & years of being a horror movie fan. I've heard so much about it. A lot of good things. I'm also one of the biggest fans of John Carpenters Halloween. It's not only my favourite horror movie of all-time, but my favourite movie of all-time period.I respect this film. It was neat. A lot of scenes I noticed were done in Halloween. It was well made. However, it wasn't scary. It didn't have major fear factors in there. One of the biggest things a slasher/horror movie needs is the killer to be intimidating or creepy.Also, a great score would've been fantastic. Unfortunately, it was missing good music as well in my opinion.This movie isn't frightening in the least bit. I got a few chills in the last 30 seconds of the film, but that's it. I don't know what all the hype is about. I respect what it has done for slasher movies, but if you can't go back, watch the film and truly be creeped out after decades, then its not a classic.This movie isn't a classic. Rather a stepping stone for art work such as John Carpenters Halloween. I would never compare Halloween to this movie. Never has a slasher/horror movie been done so well as Carpenter & Hill created Michael Myers in 1978.I could honestly say Tobe Hoopers Texas Chainsaw Massacre scares the living hell out of me until this day. Same goes for Exorcist. Halloween, not so much anymore considering i've lived with it since I was a child.6/10 Overall - See it for a history lesson on how American slasher films came to be.

Mostly well done chiller with elements later re-used in the better-known Halloween (1978) and When a Stranger Calls (1979).Olivia Hussey, Keir Dullea, Margot Kidder, John Saxon do some good acting. The locations are well used and the suspense builds well. The tense final segment is effective.Bob Clark later did teen sex comedy Porky's (1981), and there's much Porky's style comedy here. However it weighs the film down and dampens the suspense. The gags of Mrs Mac having booze hidden everywhere, Barb (Margot Kidder)'s jokes about turtles having sex and the fellatio telephone exchange, and the antics of the character credited (appropriately) as 'Laughing Detective' seem try-hard and drag on too long.Also weakening the film are the unbelievably dumb cops. The detectives openly mock dim Sergeant Nash (Doug McGrath) yet the detectives also screw up so badly it becomes distracting. The most obvious blunder is never properly searching the house even though Clare is still missing. There are big logic lapses. After threatening calls and a local murder, characters go back to joking like there's no danger. Even if Mrs Mac really would leave while a student is missing, no one reports her not arriving at her destination or tries to inform her of the murders in the house. Near the end the boyfriend (Art Hindle) of the still-missing Clare, and Clare's father, sit casually chatting beside the catatonic Jess (Hussey). Shouldn't they be searching for Clare who is still missing?

Black Christmas is one of the creepiest slasher movies I've seen in a while, for starters this film did make my skin crawl especially with Billy's phone calls. The atmosphere of the house and attic was also creepy, Bob Clark did a good job creating the suspense with the camera shots for the killers POV just like John Carpenter's Halloween, the acting is good from all the cast.The scenes with Billy are intense when he phones the girls because he's reacting his childhood while also saying other things, this slowly lets us understand the character and why he's killing people. I couldn't wait to hear the next phone call from Billy to see what he said next to them because they really are creepy.This film is a real classic 70's horror movie that really sends a chill down your spine. 10/10

Black Christmas is about a deranged killer on the loose in a college town. He takes up residence in the attic of a sorority and picks off the girls one by one. One of the first killer in the attic films, it was scary for the early 70s and is one of my favorites. Many well known actors had their first roles in this film. There are continuity errors and some obvious scene remakes, but overall a good film for the time period. Some masterful camera angles. The dialog was ripe for the time period, but quaint these days. This is one of the few scary PG rated films (except for language) that can get you going. One of the best parts of the film is the calls from the killer and the demented dialog. Very creepy.

Black Christmas is a dark, chilling film set in Canada. Its Christmas time and a mysterious evil person starts making spooky phone calls to a girls sorrority house and one by one the pours souls are put away, resulting in a brand new obscene phone call for each murder. This stars Olivia Hussey (Juliet from the 60's remake of Romeo and Juliet), Margot Kidder (Clark Kents best gal). Andrea Martin (SCTV) and John Saxson as, who else, a police detective. This was ten years before Saxson appeared in his most familiar role as Nancy's dad in A Nightmare on Elm Street.  The sub-plot deals with Hussey's character, who is pregnant. She wants an abortion, but her boyfriend, Peter, objects to this. This subplot ties in to the obscene calls and keeps you guessing to the very end.  The highlight is the Italian-style, dark and gloomy atmosphere and tone that Bob Clark has established. This amps up the spook factor and makes up for the lack of gore. This movie certainly paved the way for "Halloween" and "Scream" among   many other horror films. Theres also a nice mix of humor, largely due to Margot Kidder and the dopey police sergeant, the same one from Porky's. Black Christmas combines many of the right elements in a good Horror movie with good scares, chilling music, and humor. If theres any downfall it would be that it is quite dated and this shows during a pivotal point in the movie where the Police put a tap on the obscene calls, but are only able to get a read by having Hussey's character keep the caller on the line for an extended length of time, but this does help build the drama and horror, however.  Theres also a lot of profanity, for 1974, very strong language, but this adds to the realism of life in college sorrority.  Highly Recommended for any horror film buff.

3 years before "Halloween" forever changed the horror film genre, "Black Christmas" was the original slasher film...and what a weird-ass film it is! There is a killer hiding in the attic of a posh sorority house, a killer whose face we never see and whose motives are never revealed. The film begins almost immediately with the sickest, most obscene phone call ever put on film. It's not so much what the caller has to say (although, for 1974, it's pretty graphic, sickening stuff!) but how he says it; his (or her?) voice changes with every sentence, sometimes two or three voices overlapping each other. It is indeed a chilling thing to hear, reminding me very strongly of Reagan MacNeils Legion of voices in "The Exorcist." The call ends with the mans voice, now speaking in a normal (but no less frightening) baritone, informing Margot Kidder that he is going to kill her. The spree begins almost as soon as the call ends.All of the characters are rather offbeat, and all of them suspect. Olivia Hussey is the surprisingly non-virginal and newly pregnant heroine. Keir Dullea is her moody and slightly obsessive piano playing boyfriend who refuses to allow her to get an abortion. Margot Kidder is the drunk, rude sorority sister with a mouth only slightly less foul than that of the obscene caller, who continues to phone and torment our confused and increasingly frightened Miss Hussey. The girls continue to disappear, but no bodies are ever discovered and no one has any reason to climb up to the attic, where a display of horror awaits. There are some ingenious killings here: a plastic bag, a hook on a rope, the glass horn of a unicorn, all very wince-inducing. The climax obviously went on to inspire "When A Stranger Calls" and can be appreciated anew here.It's not a flawless film, however. I personally hate ambiguous endings. I want to know who did it and why, and although it really is not necessary (real life killings oftentimes have no motive and the killer no history with his victim, after all) it still left me feeling irritated. I also had a serious problem suspending my belief when, at films end, the cops simply leave our heroine alone in the house to sleep her drugged sleep. True enough, they think they have caught the killer...but the girl is in shock, she's just committed a murder of her own (albeit, one of supposed self defense), and I'm supposed to accept it when they turn off the lights and just leave her there? What the hell? Okay, reshoot the last ten minutes or so, and I'll stop griping about the fact that we never find out who the killer is.I'm not sorry I watched it, if that's any consolation to you hopeful horror fans looking for some lost oldies but goodies. It's a good film. It could have been really great, but just fell a few inches short, that's all.

Black Christmas is ultimately one of the most under-appreciated horror films in the horror genre and really a pioneer movie for the slasher genre. The beginning of the film is terrific since it really takes its time setting up characters and the unseen psycho, inside the sorority house, almost like a chess match. Bob Clark did a fantastic job with the casting and character development. Oliva Hussey and Margot Kidder was what steered this film forward with their fine performance and natural attractiveness. John Saxon, who most know from A Nightmare on Elm Street, had a major role and was also top-notch. Perhaps my favorite part of the movies though is the psycho phone calls that the sisters get. Many films have tried to duplicate the phone calls, but none have been able to match the insanity and effectiveness that Black Christmas achieved. I could rave forever about Black Christmas, even the ending, which many people may not have liked; I thought it was definitely a good way to end an incredible horror film.

reviews.review_title: A Horror Classic That Helped Shape the Slasher Genre
reviews.content: I don't know why I've waited so long to see this film because I hear about its greatness all the time, but I saw it for the first time earlier this afternoon. I was pretty blown away at how good it was. I was expecting it to be good but I was also expecting a good amount of cheese because it's so little known. However, it wasn't cheesy at all and it is still terrifying to this very day.I thought the story was incredible. It's really simple but it accomplishes so much and instilled a lot of fear in me. I've heard a lot of people say how Halloween ripped this movie off and I don't see that. I definitely see how Halloween was influenced by this film but that doesn't mean it isn't its own film and a great one at that. I would call them equal films. Both have great stories.The acting was very good and the characters were portrayed very well. The atmosphere is probably the creepiest part about the film, it was executed so well. This is definitely one of my new favorite movies and I am bummed that I waited so long to see it.Every horror fan owes it to themselves to see this movie immediately. It is essential not only to see, but to own as well. And remember, if this movie doesn't make your skin crawl, it's on too tight!

reviews.review_title: My vote for the scariest movie ever.
reviews.content: I saw this movie 25 years ago, and it was the scariest movie I had ever seen then. It's been replayed on cable TV lately, and it still gives me the creeps. If you love horror movies, and haven't seen this one, CHECK IT OUT!

reviews.review_title: The tempo, the rhythm and the speed of the movie makes it boring
reviews.content: First of all, I respect the movie, it's history and how it affected other slashers but I skipped it when I was watching. There is no active action for a spectator. I can not even replace myself anyone of the characters. The way its shooting is not effective at all. No thrill, no mystery. At least, through the ending, the tempo and the rhythm of the movie should be accelerated. There are a lof things going on in the movie but the conscious selection of the speed blocking the events. I don't know, there is a huge problem with this movie and, in my opinion, it is because the tempo, the rhytm and the speed that choosen by the maker. Purely boring slasher.

reviews.review_title: Groundbreaking and original, awesome early slasher.
reviews.content: As a holiday tradition, I make a point to view this at least once every December to get myself in the Christmas spirit.
