This year was no different and I have decided to review this old favorite once and for all.The ambiance is genuinely creepy and the Christmas theme being used in a horror movie is upsetting to see. I would not recommend this one to kids. "Black Christmas" is one of the first true slasher movies. A killer is on the loose and stalking members of a sorority house. We are not sure who it is and the ending is shocking. The killings are brutal. It's crazy to think that the guy who directed this went on to do such hits as "Baby Genuises..." He should have stuck to horror! Highly recommended classick that will sit with you for awhile after viewing. And avoid at all costs the Michael Bay remake for that is absolute garbage and just a sorry attempt to cash in on an awesome movie that DID NOT NEED TO BE REMADE.9 out of 10, kids.

I'm starting to think I saw a totally different movie than almost everyone else who has posted a comment here. I keep reading "best horror movie of all time, and scared the hell out of me". While this movie had it's moments, most of them humorous ones, it will never be on my Top 10 list of scary movies. I'm sure that when Black Christmas first came out it was terrifying, but there are much scarier horror films out there now. The scariest moment in this fairly slow movie was the creepy eye of the killer peering out from the crack of the door. I'll admit that gave me the willies! The gore factor was at zero, and there where some great chances for some good body part shots! The "creepy" psycho voice on the phone only made me giggle like a sorority girl. The scariest thing about Black Christmas was that good actors and performances where wasted on this movie.

reviews.review_title: Have yourself a deadly little Christmas!
reviews.content: This horror film came out in 1974 and is well known as a scary delight for the Holiday season! Black Christmas follows a group of sorority sisters in their sorority house. Little do they know over Christmas break, they are being stalked by a killer living upstairs in their attic.When one of the sisters (Claire) goes missing and a dead girl in a park is found in town, they are scared.The house keeps getting scary phone calls from a stranger... now other murders begin, and just who will survive this holiday season? So pop this in and have yourself a Merry Little BLACK CHRITMAS!

Small *SPOILERS* ahead.  This is the Grandaddy of "Put down the phone and walk out of the house, now" films.  If you really want a good scare then this is the one for you.  Made in Canada, it pre-dates all those "phone call from a mad killer" movies and sets the standard which those films that followed really never matched. (The one exception being "Halloween"). The setting is a sorority house on a college campus at Christmas holidays. The terror and murder that is visited on those girls that are still left in the house is unrelenting.  The story is basically a simple one.....horrible phone calls which result in horrible deaths.  That voice on the phone will totally unnerve you...it lingers with you long after you have seen the film. Margot Kidder is perfect as a hard drinking, hard edged student and Olivia Hussey is truly beautiful as the gentle girl in love with Keir Dullea. In fact the whole cast, some of whom are unknown to American viewers, is quite good.  Look for Andrea Martin from "Second City" as one of the sorority girls.  The downbeat ending will leave you weak, as will the scenes with Hussey and Dullea when she rushes to the basement to escape.  Why do people always go to the basement instead of leaving the house? If you like films that scare the bejeesus out of you, then don't miss this one.  It is available on tape but don't watch it alone, and for God's sake, don't answer the phone!!!

I watched this film last Saturday evening. I thought that i was far better a movie than the remake of Black Xmas(2006). The actors were way better than in the remake. The film seemed to have a much more creepier feel to it. i really liked how the camera work was done which made it feel that you were being followed through the house. I think that it is best to be watched late at night with the lights out for full effect. I thought that there was good amount of gore in the film. as well as having a a good psychological feel to it so that you are on the edge of your seat waiting for something to happen. The killings were done well especially one one with the girl having been suffocated with a plastic bag.I recommend this film for fans of all the 80's slasher films. such as Halloween (1978), Friday the 13th (1980. You should feel quite afraid after watching this film (Enjoy!!)

Being a horror film afficiando, I headed off to one of my local videostores to catch up on horror films that I ought to have seen for one reason or another. One of the films I picked up was this one, having read that it was probably the first slasher flick, which qualified it to my list. After watching it, I thought that it was very unsettling, but was it REALLY scary? And was it any good? Well, sort of. The problem with the film is that one, I couldn't care less about the characters, and when they go about acting like total idiots I even caught myself mumbling: "if he/she/it gets killed now he/she/it's got him/her/itself to blame". This keeps the film from really being scary, plus that, and this probably wasn't the case for the audience when it was released, the ending is so unbelievably predictable that it's plain silly.WARNING! SPOILER!I mean, if you have a long cameraroll that drifts from he bed where the heroine lies across the hall, doesn't that give it all away? And they basically signal that it's coming, I mean, why else would everybody leave the room? I called it right when the scene started!END OF SPOILERNow, don't get me wrong, it is a pretty good film. Now it's time to compare it to the other film of this kind, John Carpenter's "Halloween". There are similarities, but there is one significant difference. In "Halloween", we know who the killer is a couple of minutes in, in "Black Christmas" we don't. And that makes a bigger difference than one might think. One film which is a big ripoff of "Black Christmas" though is "Friday the 13th", which is built up in a similiar fashion, but is indeed a MUCH MUCH worse film. But back to "Black Christmas" vs "Halloween", the question now is, which one do I prefer? The answer is easy, I'll pick "Halloween" any day of the week. Why? Easy, Carpenter is a much more skilled director than Bob Clark and it shows in a major way. Clark manages to build an effective mood, but the mood Carpenter builds is more menacing than Clark could build in his dreams. SPOILER!Second of all, in "Halloween", the characters act more human. When they are given a chance to escape they take it, they don't go out to investigate.END OF SPOILERNext is the camerawork. It is similiar, but it's far more slick in "Halloween". The same goes for just about everything else in the film. But back to just "Black Christmas", the film is definitely worth the price of rental, since it is after all a sort-of classic. I personally don't think it's good enough to be classic in terms of quality, but does belong on the cult classic list since it helped spawn the genre that "Psycho" laid the building blocks for. But it's definitely not a masterpiece. According to me, anyway.

reviews.review_title: This is classic, don't miss it
reviews.content: You may never have heard of this neglected 1974 gem, but you've probably seen one of its many imitators. Olivia Hussey and Margot Kidder (also look for Andrea Martin of SCTV fame) star as two residents of a sorority house that is emptying out as Christmas approaches. The atmosphere is jolly and carefree, except for an ongoing series of menacing telephone calls, and, oh yes, we've just seen someone climb into the attic with apparent ill intent. Kidder does some scene-stealing as the bad girl, Hussey illustrates one of the downsides to having beautiful long '70s hair, and Keir Dullea does a nice turn as the creepy boyfriend. Director Robert Clark knows that the unseen is far scarier than what can be seen and he ratchets up the tension beautifully, making good use of ominous shadows, and putting in nice touches like replacing the sound of a distraught woman's scream with the piercing ring of yet another ominous phone call. This is a terrific, well-made little movie that is genuinely sleep-with-the-lights-on scary. Don't miss it.

my husband and i hired this movie tonight and we both enjoyed it very much ,i thought everything about it was creepy, the phone calls, the way the camera takes things at angles, music , house and you are guessing who it could be .... This is one i am going to get for my collection, keen horror fan, i love When An Stranger Calls and this movie was before that now we know where they got there ideas from... If you like an good scare, something creepy , hairs on back of neck then watch this movie... Who i thought might be killer i was wrong, and i like the ending even at the end you don't know who he or she is? If the main character survives the night, and who else will he/she kill, before they are caught or killed? Richard

reviews.review_title: You should try sleeping in the house!
reviews.content: Hi everyone....i had no idea Black Christmas was so popular! My grandmother owned that house until 1994. As you see i wasn't even alive when the movie was filmed, my mom was and the stories are pretty funny. The film crew left this huge Black Christmas promotion in one of the rooms. Fast forward some years and now i'm in the picture. I would stay at my grandmother's house a couple nights a week in the room where the girl gets suffocated and stuffed in the closet. I hadn't seen the movie yet 'cuz i was still young so it didn't bother me. But one day my cousins (who lived in the house) rented it and i happened to see it. Holy S***! Sleeping in that room was never the same! Jesus, being in that house when i was seven years old used to scare the hell outta me! Anyways, i just thought i'd share my lone story of Black Christmas. I was stoked to see so many people liked it.Cheers

Wow Margot Kidder and the woman from that TV show, with Tutti and Blair and George Clooney starred for a brief minute. Anyway it all goes down very creepily on this college campus, in a girl's dorm at Christmas, circa 1974 horror film style. Many other subsequent horror films stole the ideas herein.No disappointments and no telling what's going to happened next - as there are many red herrings.I love the girls at the college that don't wear bras and it's very apparent(! i.e. tits showing). Those were the days. That and smoking grass and getting obliviously loaded everyday at school.Plus tackling a very real issue, pregnancy and abortion.It's all very believable and very scary. I love the ending.Watch it and you'll see..........

reviews.review_title: Other movies have borrowed heavily from this holiday horror film, but there's a reason for that
reviews.content: It's ironic in a way. "Black Christmas" predates pretty much every single slasher horror film (including the one I consider the first in the genre, "Halloween") but you can see so many elements in this film that have been borrowed or distilled into familiar horror tropes that at first, it will seem kind of routine. For this reason, you might be wondering what the big deal is about if you're just a casual movie viewer. There's a lot more to it than just an ancient ancestor of your "Friday the 13th" and your "Prom Night" though. It goes without saying that if you're a true fan of horror cinema, this is a must-see. The plot, as you might expect happens on Christmas Eve/Day. It follows a group of sorority sisters who are stalked and murdered by an unknown killer hiding in the attic of their sorority house. Sounds basic? In a way it is, but it's the details that make this movie stand out.As a fan of horror movies, I have a great deal of admiration for this film. I enjoy seeing the beginnings of the horror genre. The cast of characters gradually being reduced in numbers as the movie comes along, the building tension, "the final girl", the various kills and the escalating terror as the sorority sisters slowly realize that there is something very wrong happening. It's like looking at the skeleton of an ancestor to Tyrannosaurus Rex and looking at what bones are going to gradually turn into which ones and what traits were deemed unnecessary so they were dropped until the creature in front of you became this legendary killing machine. From a fan of horror films, this historical aspect ranks about 3rd on my list of "favourite things about Black Christmas". I'll get to #1 in a bit, but my #2 isn't the familiar aspects. It's the sort of precursors to some of the familiar tropes in slasher films that are quite different in their primeval state. For example, the main character in the film isn't very clear at first. Are we going to be following the killer? Is it going to be Margot Kidder's character, the sarcastic, drunken girl who appears to kick-start the plot? Usually the protagonist of the film is "the virgin", so maybe it will be Claire (Lynne Griffin), who leaves the party early when she is offended by Barb's lewd remarks? Maybe it's Jess (Olivia Hussey), the recipient of the obscene phone call that is our first clue as to who the killer might be? Just as there are some points in the film where your familiarity with slasher films will help you deduce some developments, the fact that this movie doesn't adhere to many of the clichés (because it predates them) makes it often unpredictable and unconventional as far as films of the genre go. You'll be surprised to learn, for example, that the killer in this film does not have a signature weapon, that we don't really learn a lot about who he is and that there's really not much blood in the film. Just when you think you've got this movie figured out, it throws you for a loop, and I like not knowing where a plot is going to go.You're probably wondering what the main appeal, my favourite thing about this movie is. Well, it's the fact that the film is genuinely frightening. There's a very naturalistic look about the film that brings home the terror. The movie doesn't begin with a fresh face going to college for the first time and being introduced to a slew of characters, some of which act funny from the start to indicate they might be the killer later. It starts at Christmas time. All of these characters know each other, they're all busy doing their own thing, and it's like you're coming in uninvited to peep in on the action (in a way that's similar to the killer). When we hear the phone ring and learn that it's a strange man making lewd phone calls, and that he's been doing this for a while, it's not really a grandiose shock to the characters, they've heard it before and yeah, it's creepy, but it's not a big deal. It really feels like these people have a life outside of the events of this movie. We hear several off-hand remarks of other crimes that have happened around the campus, and we have no way of knowing if they're connected to this plot at all. This helps make the identity of the killer even more mysterious. Has he been murdering people for a long time and he's just now coming into contact with these sorority sisters? Is this the first night and the other events are just coincidences in the same way that you have coincidences all the time in real life? A lot of it can only be guessed because like the characters in the movie, you don't really get big bits of exposition explaining the who, the what and the why of this plot. This lingering uncertainty as to what exactly is happening, and why, makes the conclusion of the film incredibly intense and unsettling. There are images of the killer that spook me every time I see them."Black Christmas" is a movie that does suffer because it has been imitated so much, but there's a reason it hasn't been forgotten. It has some really genuinely frightening scenes, a lot of tension and also several humorous scenes to throw you off. I really like the comedic moments because just like in real life, when you get genuinely scared you do manage to find little nuggets of humour to try and steel yourself. You have probably heard some things about this film and wondered what the big deal was about, but watch it again, really watch it and I think you'll agree that it really is something special. (On Blu-ray, December 5, 2014)

reviews.review_title: A Christmas As Red As Blood
reviews.content: *Black SPOILERS* Christmas Break; most of the Pi Kappa Sig Sorority girls have already gone back home for the holidays, but a few are still in the house, and begin to receive chilling phone calls by an unknown person, and after Barb (Margot Kidder), a drunkard Sorority Sister, disses him, he says calmly 'I'm going to kill you' and hangs up.One of the girls, Clare (Lynne Griffin) is scared, and mocked by Barb, she decides to go pack, since she's leaving the next day for home with her father, but she is lured by the caller in her closet and suffocated with plastic wrapping, and her corpse is put in the attic (where the killer hides) on a rocking chair, with a doll in her lap.Her father obviously doesn't meet her, and worried (but somehow worried more at the decor his daughter used in her room) he calls the police.And as the Pi Kappa Sig's housemother, the alcoholic Mrs. Mac (Marion Waldman) 'goes missing' also, and the calls become increasingly frightening, the sorority sisters, which include Barb, the pregnant (and planning an abortion) Jess (Olivia Hussey) and the geeky Phyllis (Andrea Martin) begin to realize the danger in which they are in, but is it too late? Not many know of this movie (yet), especially where I live (Italy), where it's rare to find (until Dec. 5, when the DVD is going to come out... I hope), but it's a real treat for horror movie lovers, and it takes you back to a time where Final Girls were still believable, the horror movies were thought out and original (heard that, Michael Bay?), and suspense, not gore, was a priority.The obvious inspirer of 'HalloweeN' (along with Italian thrillers 'Profondo Rosso' (1975) and 'L'Uccello Dalle Piume Di Cristallo', (1970) which also use the technique of the killer's POV), 'BC' conserves intact the power to scare you silly with a very simple storyline and almost no blood.The actors (which other than the above mentioned include Keir Dullea, Art Hindle and John Saxon) are also really great, and there is a subtle sense of humor throughout (just a quote: 'These broads could hump the Leaning Tower of Pisa if they could get to the top of it!'), and let's admit it, Christmas has always been a little *too* cheery, hasn't it? Black Christmas: 9/10.

I watched this movie 30 years ago. We rented it for our Co-Ed Dorm and watched it together, just before Christmas break. It scared us all.Now, some 30 years later, my 16 year old daughter likes and wants to rent scary movies for Halloween with her friends. She asked me if I knew of any really good scary movies. This movie instantly came to mind. It was the only movie I could think of. It obviously left an impression.This is a good movie that can really scare you without using lots of special effects and gore. Sometimes, the simple, possible, and every day things can be the scariest.

It's hard to believe the same man directed both the self-deprecatingly nostalgic A Christmas Story and Black Christmas, a twisted little shocker (based loosely on an urban legend) about an anonymous killer who infiltrates a sparsely inhabited sorority house at Yuletide. The two films could hardly be farther apart on the Christmas-spirit spectrum. But then Bob Clark was a dedicated craftsman who preferred to adapt his style to the subject matter at hand.

reviews.review_title: EXCELLENT PERIOD PIECE not just for the month of December!
reviews.content: Andrea Martin! * * Margot Kidder * * John Saxon! * * Some old guy you see on TV all the time who plays the old geeky guy all the time!! * * Listen I'm sorry, I wouldn't say that the performances are good...at all at all atoll!!! They are pathetic, in fact! All the way down the line!! Do you hear me?!?! PATHETIC! Indeed though, sure 'twas that it was the case that these gals and guys without exception "didn't have much to work with". In fact I think looking back that aside from Andrea Martin perhaps, all the characters single and in to-to reminded me viscerally of those dimwitted folk who try the patience of detectives Joe Friday and Bill Gannon on "Dragnet" starring Jack Webb forcing the fuzz to raise their eyes to heav'n on numerous occasions so provoked by the half witted dimwitted of LA are they as they go about their "beat" investigating crimes. Not just the good citizens, look you, of this campus town but the peace officers themselves are equally unintelligent leaving it to the audience - you and me - to roll its eyes a la Joe And Bill in this Canadian production entitled, "Black Christmas" but when I saw it in the theater when it originally played I believe it was called "Silent Night, Evil Night". Only with R rating: brace yourself to hear profanity aplenty in this motion picture! Ms. Kidder also does some lewd tongue things. In fact the least nasty of the bunch is probably the heinous killer who has some story to tell about Agnes and Billy which as many other reviewers have indicated, comes off less as an attempt to terrorize than as some little kids intending an attempt to entertain (however feebly!) or kids making "prank" calls and struggling not to laugh as an accompaniment or kids dead set on simply sending "everything but the kitchen sink coming down the line" as one reviewer comprehensively put it.On to accentuating the positive: The color is very richly saturated and the set design and lighting are nothing short of lushhhh, like Barb (Margot Kidder)! As a result, while you'd probably be making a mistake to date any of these sorority sisters, you'll make no mistake dating this picture: this is 1974 all right in all it's glory, with fashion palette ranging from mod to retro and in fact what makes this film really juicy is the heady flavors of '74. Why you can almost hold the aroma in your hand which emanates from the chicks of patchouli, rose oil and from the dudes English Leather, Brut and the like with which you'll be juggling the stench of blood, egg nor, the house mother's "B for Booze" which - charming if hardcore woman that she is, this broad drinks from out the toilet without any kind of rinsing of the bottle I guess she figures if it's a battle to the death between e coli and her saliva she's nothing to worry about with the egg nor, Xmas tree, various other fixings, etc. and the booze the other girls are drinking too, cause the house mother is by no means the only one drawing refreshment from the "tis" punch bowl! Kier Dullea is an evil conservatory composer/pianist whose blatant atonality and extended techniques while one would hope could convey a sense of menace yet even sweating and squirming on the piano which is practically smashing literally to bits during his performance he puts the jury assigned to hear his recital to sleep. Philistines! This movie is so funny cause of its 1974 vintage with all the young women being so potty mouthed, each wanting to be more outrageous and provocative than the last. well at least two or three of them would give any woman a run for her money in a contest for which of them is the sauciest lady of them all, verbally/orally that is. Visually though you may find yourself musing, "I wonder who put up the poster that is the "peace" sign made of the pelvis and legs of a man and woman - the woman's are spread as the man appears to penetrate her from above, his legs tightly clamed together. By today's admittedly different standards it is the female of the species, aside from the "bespectacled" (as the reviewer who spoke of the kitchen sink called her one - i.e. Andrea Martin) one and maybe a couple of the others who bent over more in the direction of soft spoken, who would be charged with sexual harassment in this day and age! Is this a sorority house or a museum of erotic art? The place is, as a rule choka block with knick knacks - carousels, a collection of glass swans, etc. Ah the good old days! Were they so good?!?!?! "Black Christmas" raises this question without doubt.Well for one I was disappointed not even to see a composer credit in the credits for the spicy piano music. The IMDb indicates that the composer recommended sexy John Saxon for the roll of the top cop. Wouldn't it be funny if this composer actually in this instance proved to be the first cause of Mr. Saxon doing the many and various copious cop rolls he was eventually fated to you might say specialize in - let's call it of course a sub-specialty of cop in horror rolls! The last 2 shots were kinda cool. I didn't "get" who it was outside, I guess another ineffectual cop and why he didn't react to the phone ringing!! I'll give it a 10 for being an outstanding "time capsule" cause it really is more interesting in this way than many another bad movie or even good! :)

A psychopath stalks young girls at a sorority house during the holiday season in "Black Christmas". This Canadian made horror movie is by far the best of it's kind I've ever seen. It falls under the categories of "killer is in the house" and "holiday horror", therefore is compared to such classics as 'When a Stranger Calls' and 'Halloween'. The thing is that Black Christmas was made before both of those, yet never got recognition over the years. The plot is pretty simple. A group of sorority sisters get obscene phone calls around Christmastime. It all seems fairly harmless until we see one of the girls murdered and then stored in the attic by the killer. The rest of the characters go to the police to report her missing. After receiving more disturbing phone calls, the cops tap the phone to find out what location the calls are coming from. As the movie moves along, we see a few more people murdered leading to the shocking scene in which the lead character jess is told that "the calls are coming from inside the house".The plot sounds simple and has been done to death in eighties slashers, but Black Christmas TRULY does it best. So many things about this movie are done so right. The caller is not your average deep voiced creeper. His ramblings range from high pitched squeals about "Billy and Agnes", and get even more twisted towards the end. The sounds the killer makes when he's alone with the dead bodies is so unnerving, I've never watched anything like it. The suspect list is short and really only includes the boyfriend Peter. We see throughout the film that he is a very troubled guy and you really start to believe that he is the caller/killer.Despite this being a creepy horror flick, there are a lot of laughs especially from the character of Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) and Barb (Margot Kidder). Mrs. Mac is the house mother who loves her booze and loves her cat Claude. She has to be one of my favourite horror characters of all time. The acting is top notch from Waldman and Kidder, but also from our leads Olivia Hussey/Andrea Martin/John Saxon/Keir Dullea. Black Christmas is one of the most frightening and terrifying horror films of all time. It's got the premise of a slasher flick, with out the blood and gore. It uses shadows, creepy phone calls and a mystery in the story that leaves us in fear and with many unanswered questions. This film by the brilliant Bob Clark should be seen by all!10/10

As a shocker it is 100% original, it pre dates both Halloween and Friday the 13th yet hardly anyone seems to have heard of it and even fewer people seem to be aware the effects it had on its far more illustrious and in my opinion slightly inferior shocker relatives. The cast are excellent John "B movie king" Saxon, Margot Kidder and Olivia Hussey are all standouts. Black Christmas will make you laugh, shudder and jump in equal measures. If you are a fan of ground breaking, CGI free original and pure horror this is the perfect film for you. After being at the upper end pricewise it has come down significantly in price. So buy now to avoid disappointment but only if you enjoy being scared.

Black Christmas, also known as Silent Night, is a Psychological Slasher Horror movie and considered to be one of the earliest Slasher films in general. It's based on a urban legend about a teenage girl babysitting children who receives telephone calls from a man who continually asks her to "check the children". If that doesn't sound like the perfect Christmas flick for the entire family, then I don't know. The actresses are both gorgeous and talented, but what I loved most about this movie is that unsettling voice that you keep hearing through the phone. It's genuinely disturbing and I didn't even understand everything he mumbled. The contrast between the Christmas/ holiday spirit with the dark atmosphere works perfectly. The movie isn't really that graphic but again, that voice will possibly haunt you for a while. Another interesting element is that we look through the killers perspective, which allowed to killer to keep his identity secret from the audience. The Slasher genre may have become a bit repetitive but don't let that stop you from watching this classic. Now I'd love to write some more but I have some calls to make.

reviews.review_title: Very creepy movie..... don't watch it alone
reviews.content: This movie was very creepy and it reminded me of Fulci's movie "New York Ripper" in the way that the pycotic caller would call up after he would kill his victims with all kinds of wierd strange noises that sent shivers up your spine.  This movie was about a sorority house that becomes victimized during Christmas after an obnoxious prank caller would call up each time he would kill his prey.  The only problem with this movie that I have is it does not release the identity of the killer.  The boyfriend of one of the tenants had me fooled for awhile but at the end it left me guessing again.  And who is Billy?  Otherwise... I would highly recomend this one to anybody that likes a good scare, but don't watch it alone, this kind of crazy stuff is something that could happen anywhere.

Bob Clark's Black Christmas is a criminally underrated film, not just in the horror genre but also in film and art. The film is so real, sometimes you will think it's based on a true story. With a tight, sold script, laser focus direction and great performance from the cast giving grounded, real characters, coming together to make Bob Clark's Black Christmas a instant classic.
The script plays with the audience expectation by the characters actions and a faceless mysterious antagonist in putting us on edge of wondering and guessing what going to happen next and the film will deliberately will leave us with unanswered questions.
On a side not, the film overall message is the most pro choice message I ever saw in cinemas in my life without being a pro choice film that just preaching without any creativity.

reviews.review_title: Don't watch it with the lights off!
reviews.content: I first saw this movie on television, at night, alone, when I was about 12, and it was one of the scariest experiences I ever had watching a movie. Catching up with it again now as an adult, it still sends shivers through me - even if I know what to expect.Before Bob Clark began wasting his time with low-brow comedies he fashioned several low budget horror films, of which this is the best and most adult. His skill in putting the screws to the audience's nerves is aided & abetted by a soundtrack that itself promotes unease, rich photography, and a solid cast.  While the story of a sorority house plagued by an unseen killer has been done to death (no pun intended), Clark did it years before the stalker film cycle of the late 70's / early 80's, and with much more talent than 99% of them.  The final 15 minutes are out-and-out terrifying, and the final scene, while open to debate - still haunts as a macabre joke.The story? It's Christmas, of course.  A sorority house is tormented by bizarre, schizophrenic obscene calls.  Soon, people begin to disappear. Who is responsible? Watch it. Just keep the lights on.

reviews.review_title: Not a slasher film, but the one that started it all!
reviews.content: I watched this movie after much searching through Mom & Pop video stores and found a pristine copy. It scared my pants off! BLACK CHRISTMAS is one of those movies that is an unsung classic and is most appreciated by horror buffs. I tried to get my friends to watch it, but they are all into gory, graphic horror opuses like SCREAM and URBAN LEGEND. Unfortunately, those movies have very few scares and are just cheap rip-offs posing as tributes to great films like this one. There really isn't anything to complain about for this movie unless you don't like movies that rely on suspense and hinted-at violence.One reviewer said this movie wasn't a slasher movie because BLACK CHRISTMAS wasn't gory enough. The gore in slasher movies is what ruined the entire horror genre. BLACK CHRISTMAS, HALLOWEEN, TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE, the older films rely on suspense, mind-numbing suspense and require your imagination. People are spoiled by the gore effects in films now, sometimes the effects are gratuitous and don't move the story along at all! BLACK CHRISTMAS' story moves along briskly, dragging the viewer into it, making the movie seem so real! Horror buffs should appreciate the fact that BLACK CHRISTMAS attempts to "befriend" its audience instead of "ripping its guts out"!

Here's the one I watched on Halloween but couldn't understand due to all the ruckus going on at the party. And now that I have sat down and watched it properly, I see exactly what makes this one such a classic.Black Christmas is one of those old school horror movies that knows what it's doing, unlike mostly every horror movie that comes out these days. The build-up is long and it sets a tangible mood - this is not a movie trying to rush itself into the blood and gore, which is not really one of the focal points of this movie anyway. Yes, there are stock characters, and there is some thin human conflict going on between them, but you actually care about these characters, and you don't really want to see them die. What a novel concept, right? This makes it all the more disturbing as the stalker's phone calls escalate in insanity and as the bodies begin to pile up. The acting is really good for these kinds of movies, too, with great performances from all of the characters.And goddammit, those phone calls get really, really creepy! I mean, I know what you're thinking; "oh, wow, a phone call, how can that be scary," but no, it is scary. I won't spoil the reasons why for those who haven't seen this gem yet, but the atmosphere of the whole thing is blackened, haunting, claustrophobic and memorable as Hell. This is all very believable, leaving no room for anyone to laugh and pan this movie off as unrealistic or silly. This could happen to anyone! And that, in a similar manner to Halloween, is perhaps the scariest thing about this movie.From before a time when horror equated to ridiculous special effects, gory amputated limbs and torture chambers, Black Christmas hits you hard no matter where or when you watch it, with a ferociously creepy mood, a calculating, dark atmosphere and just enough pizazz to have you looking under your bed this Christmas eve to make sure that there aren't any bogeymen coming to get you. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: One of the top ten horror films of all time.
reviews.content: I personally feel that this film is heads and shoulders more frightening than either Halloween/ Friday the 13th. This is a must rent if you can find it! I own the DVD and have lent it out uncountable times and have always met with a favorable response upon it's return. Knowing that this film predates Halloween, Friday the 13th and When a Stranger Calls you will see that it laid a great foundation upon which great horror films are still built upon today. The scariest aspect of this film is that there is no closure at the end.

This was great fun. Highly recommended for any movie fan, even if you aren't a horror nut. Still scary after all these years, and I'm glad I tracked this one down to finally see it.But...all this talk on here about how this influenced Halloween - I don't buy it. Hasn't anyone seen any of Argento's stuff? Geez. Much of the POV stuff had been done by him, including in Bird With the Crystal Plumage - which was done in 1970. Even Argento probably wasn't the first...almost everything new draws on something from the past. Don't get me wrong, Black Christmas and Halloween are both excellent movies, but even Carpenter said that Halloween was his Argento film, or somesuch.I guess what was new here (maybe?) was that no explanation was given for the killer's motivation, and that adds to the creepiness. This is something that Halloween took and ran with - so much so that Michael Myers has NO lines...I saw Halloween on TV in the early eighties when I was in elementary school - and I remember that part above all disturbing me: WHY did he kill? Why would anyone DO that? And why doesn't he TALK? :) I think when horror movies are wrapped up neatly it deflates any sort of hold they might have had otherwise ("if it wasn't for those darned kids"). And Black Christmas gives the viewer none of that sort of comfort.

I saw Black Christmas this month I was honestly scared after I had watched it. It was really scary. You didn't know if the killer was Billy or the boyfriend.The film starts of quickly as an unseen, stalking psychopath returns to his home house on Christmas which is now a sorority house which is owned by girls who celebrate Christmas together every year. The killer sneaks into the attic of the house. Soon after, the girls start to get creepy, insane phone calls. They don't realize it's from the attic. In their own HOME! Soon after all of them are murdered.I loved this film and it honestly kept me tuned in to watch the rest. It's like your watching Halloween (1978) all over again. Word of warning though that this is a very slow & long film that goes on forever though for a film like this, slow is good.I suggest you ignore the remake and watch the original. 9.5/10

reviews.review_title: Good, solid film. Well worth it to see!
reviews.content: Excellent film which combines good acting and an interesting plot, which it seems is very unusual in the horror genre. It's Christmas and as the girls prepare to leave their sorority house they are plagued by harassing phone calls. Soon the calls lead to murder as an intruder breaks into the house and starts killing off the girls who have not yet left. Now its a quest to find the killer before everyone is dead. Margot Kidder gives a wonderful, hilarious performance as the perpetually drunken sorority member. And Olivia Hussey is worth seeing as well for her solid performance. One major thing that should be noted is that this movie preceded Halloween by a good four years, and it seems obvious now how that movie was influenced by this one. Further, unlike later horror movies, the heroine isn't a near saint, rather she is just as imperfect as the other characters. Overall this movie works on many different levels and should definitely be seen by fans of the genre.

This movie is SOOOO scary! I absolutely loved it because it's something so different than what you would see about the season (Christmas), and yet so totally believable.I mean, this could actually happen; not just to someone else, but to you OR me! It definitely made me think about answering the phone.I actually cannot watch this flick in the dark; I did that the 1st time I saw it; even knowing that it's " only a movie" doesn't change it at all.Scary movies are my all time faves, and it certainly didn't disappoint. I would recommend it to anyone (except young children), especially if you want something to think about later, after dark, when you're alone in your bed, in the dark.

reviews.review_title: God love Bob Clark for making great Christmas movies, whether there's death or not!
reviews.content: With the typically silly state of slasher movies today, considering that most of any of the popular ones are sit-'n-slash (Hostel, Wolf Creek, Turistas, you get the idea), it's nice to take a travel back in time when slashers were about mystery and the chase, not some hapless victim tied down to a chair with a chainsaw blade being fed into his or her rectum. Hell, Cube & Saw kind of got the ball rolling on that, but at least those people had SOME kind of chance of living. Thanks a lot, Eli Roth. But I digress.Ah, the 70's slasher film. Is there anything more pure? Before the 80's came in and Friday the 13th perverted the original depth into mindless splatterfests, the slasher film moved on mood and atmosphere (Texas Chainsaw Massacre excluded, that movie is just f***in awesome). Bob Clark's Black Christmas takes the horror to not only a supposedly harmless environment such as the sorority house, but also to a holiday more harmless than baby holding a puppy that's licking a bunny. This harmless environment, in turn, gives the film and even more terrifying feeling, as if it was invading a world that God never intended it to cross into.All slasher villains have to have a gimmick, and have needed one ever since Michael Myers donned his stylish emotionless white mask. And although Myers will always be my favorite, Billy by far is the most intimidating one I've ever seen... er, "seen." Why? Because all he is is a voice, an eye, and a shadow. That's it. When's the last time you watched a horror movie and didn't see the monster? Billy has no gimmick, and he doesn't need one, because he is f***in creepy all on his lonesome. He doesn't even have a standard weapon! Don't worry, I won't tell Agnes what we did.As far as the acting is concerned, stellar performances all around. John Saxon was way on in the movie, more than he was in A Nightmare on Elm Street (easily). Margot Kidder was a great drunk (I'm sure she's experienced). To the main point: I was concerned for the safety of EVERY character, a MAJOR rarity in the slasher film. There's usually at least one or two meat puppets you're couldn't care less about, but not a single one in Black Christmas. If you can find one, tell me who it is! Black Christmas is everything that I wish slasher films today would be. Moody, dangerous, dreadful, and with more depth than just a knife into the chest, Black Christmas easily presents what the slasher movie needs to recapture. Please, untie that guy from the chair and give him a chance. You'll still get him, just make it at least SEEM like you're not!

This movie is a true classic. It was made in 1974, and most people think John Carpenters Halloween started the whole slasher craze with Michael Myers, Jason, Freddy...But this is the one that inspired Halloween.I must say I really enjoyed this. Good acting, and original scared. I really liked the prank phone calls throughout the film, they were disturbing for a film that was made in 1974. So go out and see this movie because its a classic! The sexy Olivia Hussey, and Margot Kidder star in this masterpiece and they really carry this film as the two sorority babes. John Saxon plays the Police Officer and is dead on. The camera work is wonderful in this movie, and you can tell that John Carpenter clearly was inspired by this movie. This is one of my favorite horror movies of all time, and every genre fan should check this out!

First off, Black Christmas is not in my mind a "great horror classic", as some other people have said. Why? Because it's all violence and a non-exsistent story.The story (warning, spoilers): The film opens at night with a small party occurring in a sorority house for a private school. We are introduced to all of the girls in the sorority house, the main ones being Jess, the heroine of the film, Barb, a drunken loud mouth, and Phyllis, Jess' friend and the peace keeper of the group. The girls have been receiving mysterious phonecalls from someone they call "The Moaner". The calls start out sexual in nature, but they gradually grow more macabre, with the man on the other end saying strange things in different voices. The shyest sorority girl, Claire, goes upstairs to pack, and when she goes into the closet, the killer dives out and wraps a plastic bag around her head. He then drags her into the attic, and puts her in a rocking chair. The next day, Claire's father comes to pick her up, but nobody knows where she is. It becomes a mystery as the police search for the missing Claire. Meanwhile, Mrs. Mac, the house mother, stumbles upon the killer and gets a crane hook in the face. Meanwhile, Jess admits to her boyfriend Peter that she is pregnant, but she's having an abortion. He begins to act strange, and shows off some anger problems. As Barb and Phyl are murdered by the killer, Jess gets another call. The police trace the call and realize that the calls are coming from in the house. Instead of going out, Jess goes upstairs and is attacked by the killer. She manages to escape and heads to the basement. There she runs into Peter, who she now falsely believes is the killer. He approaches her to talk, but Jess hits him over the head and kills him. The police feel the case is closed, and leave the house, leaving Jess alone to sleep off the excitement. As the credits begin to roll, we hear the phone ring once again.Now, this film has major plot spoilers, such as(warning, more spoilers): Police arrive at the home but make no effort to search it, despite two bodies having been undiscovered. (Also noteworthy is that an officer notes "The local morgue cannot handle this many bodies.") The deranged killer is able to repeat lines of dialogue from other characters on the phone, though it seems almost impossible he could have heard them despite being in the house. Despite the parent of one victim being around for the entire movie, no one suggests searching for his daughter when the mystery appears to be solved and she has not been found. Police leave the final potential victim alone in the house sleeping. (Sploliers end now)Basiclyy, this film is all blood and no story. Even though Halloween, (1978) is a rip-off of it, (in my opinion), it's all far better movie.

The movie is an outstanding work of art that started it all. Black Christmas spawned Halloween, Friday the thirteenth, Nightmare on elm street, and many more. It has some comedy in it to lighten the load a little bit, and then there are LOTS of dark moments in this film. Overall a dark/comedic masterpiece that should be a landmark in cinema history forever.

Didn't know what to expect going in to this film, i haven't actually ever heard about this movie before so i decided to watch it, and boy did it surprise me in a good way.Suspense, unnerving, creepy and simple ( that's why it's good).Fine work with the camera, music in this movie is eerie and set's the tone. The ending was something you don't see alot in horror slasher films.For a 70's slasher horror film, this is superior in filmmaking and suspense then other modern slashers! And holds up today i will say.If you like it suspensful and eerie, this is the movie for you!

This is perhaps the scariest film I've seen. It practically set up the rules for the slash-horror genre. Unlike Scream and kin, (which I love, don't get me wrong) this is just a straight horror, and all the better for it. Incredibly atmospheric, with great performances all round, and a chilling ending.

reviews.review_title: Before "Scream" ... before "Friday the 13th" ... before "Halloween" ... before "When a Stranger Calls" - there was this!
reviews.content: Before "Scream" ... before "Friday the 13th" ... before "Halloween" ... before "When a Stranger Calls" - there was this!A uniquely creepy (the scene where one victim is stabbed with a glass unicorn is particularly harrowing) movie that seems to be one of the earlier slashers, though in many ways though it has slasher hallmarks, it really is not a slasher; the death scenes are not gruesome and hardly seen, the bodycount is low...A refreshing movie featuring relatively intelligent characters, all the more surprising considering they're sorority sisters, and don't prance around half-naked!! Wow!!Also, some fine moments of serious drama, and a great cast, particularly Olivia Hussey and John Saxon (from horror "A Nightmare on Elm Street" fame).Unfortunately overlooked and underrated, this is a great film.

Black Christmas is the story of a group of girls in a sorority house being stalked and picked off by a psycho.  Sounds familiar.  Well Black Christmas came out long before all the those others and laid the foundation for them. This is the first flick to offer those cool killer POV shots.  This slasher also likes to use the phone, his phone calls give me chills just thinking about them.  This guy is insane!  The slashings are cool and it has a great twist.  Oh yea and this flick is actually creepy.  Bob Clark does a great job creating a bleak atmosphere just right for some slashings.  Bleak, creepy, and really cool.  What more do you want from a slasher? A must for all genre fans.  Go find it!  An underground masterpiece!

reviews.review_title: I liked it better than Halloween
reviews.content: If Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho is the grandfather of the slasher genre, then Bob Clark's Black Christmas is the father, spawning/Inspiring John Carpenter's Halloween.While Halloween became a mainstream success, Black Christmas was destined for cult stardom only. Which is a shame because I enjoyed Black Christmas more, and I believe it's a better film.Firstly, all the characters have personalities and little quirks that help keep you more engaged. Theres next to no "spelled out" backstory for the slasher villan, most of it is hinted at through the phone calls the girls receive, but he's still intimidating and scary. Also this movie is suprisingly funny. It knows not to take itself too seriously, which helps the horror scenes feel serious and frightning.If you haven't already, I highly recommend seeing this excellent film

reviews.review_title: Several sorority babes are terrorized by an obscene phone-caller, whose childish pranks turn into stranger and deadlier games as the evening goes on.
reviews.content: A must!!!!! This film is a classic of the early '70's slasher movie genre. Olivia Hussey(of ROMEO AND JULIET fame) is excellent as the tormented young woman who fears that the killer maybe her violent-tempered boyfriend(Keir Dullea) who doesn't want her to abort their baby. Margot Kidder is a standout as a drunken, consistently trashed sorority sister with asthma. Directed by Bob Clark(A CHRISTMAS STORY), the film is surprisingly bloodless and concentrates instead on creepy, ominous atmosphere, and genuine suspense. This was several years before HALLOWEEN or FRIDAY THE 13th, and in my opinion, much better!!!!!

For a slasher film (this is more like a predecessor to the genre)the film is pretty boring, and the kills are for the most part bloodless and uncreative. The killer, makes prank phones calls to a sorority then kills them off one by one. John Saxon is in there as a cop for some reason but the cops don't seem to exist for any other reason than to pad out the more than ample run time. The end is the slasher genre equivalent to "it was all just a dream". Basically, YOU NEVER KNOW WHO IS DOING THE KILLING AND WHY! WTF!? HOW UNSATISFYING CAN YOU GET? Most, at least the entertaining, slasher films have a twist, or a reason, an impetus for the killer's motivations, that's 90% of the story, and why you want to watch. the production values were pretty decent, and the actors all did their parts decently, but with no central thread holding what they're trying to pass off as a story this is a big pass, and only for those who are horror film buff completeists. The viewer has no idea what is motivating the killings, and the characters are so thin, you don't care.When the credits rolled I caught myself thinking, "BOOOOOOOO!, BOOOOOOO!"

reviews.review_title: Maybe the most underrated "slasher" movie of all time...?
reviews.content: (****1/2 out of *****) This early mad-killer-in-the-house flick predates "Halloween" (as well as the similar, but much-inferior "When A Stranger Calls"), and it is seriously one of the scariest movies I have ever seen.  A group of girls (including hotties Olivia Hussey and Margot Kidder and former "SCTV" regular Andrea Martin) staying in their sorority house over the Christmas break are plagued by bizarre, obscene phone calls from a schizophrenic maniac hiding up in the attic who begins knocking them off, one by one.  Clark, famous mainly for directing "Porky's" and the much-beloved (and much more family-oriented) holiday movie "A Christmas Story", started his career directing horror movies (he also directed the psychedelic zombie flick "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things"), and he knows how to create an unbearably creepy atmosphere.  He builds up so much tension and suspense towards the end of this one that it practically overwhelms you.  The freaky phone calls and the disturbing open ending are enough to stay with you for days afterward. Clark and writer Roy Moore also manage to inject some much-needed humor into the oppressively gloomy script, provided mostly by Kidder's profane, heavy-drinking character, Barb.  Art Hindle, Keir Dullea (`Dave?' from "2001") and horror movie veteran John Saxon also star in this sorely underrated thriller.HIGHLIGHT:  The chilling moment of discovery when the heroine finds out that `the calls are coming from inside the house!'  A highly influential horror-movie scene, oft-repeated, never bettered.

reviews.review_title: Bob Clark's "Black Christmas" is a horror movie masterpiece.
reviews.content: I had heard about Black Christmas and read reviews proclaiming how great Bob Clark's 1974 horror movie was. The movie truly did live up to the hype. Clark creates a creepy atmosphere with Christmas carols and POV shots. Simply put, everything in this movie works: the killer's phone calls are downright chilling; great character development; a few funny moments; shocking ending. There are some images and scenes in this movie that are so well done they will stick with you. The ending is shocking and is the perfect end to this movie. Bob Clark created a masterpiece with Black Christmas, and it is obvious so many "slasher" films took elements from this movie.l If you think Halloween is the greatest "slasher" movie of all time, seeing this lost gem might change your mind.

I still don't know who it is! I thought that when I saw that the focus was around sorority girls I thought it was going to be iffy. It hooked me from the beginning. You wonder who is doing it and where are the call coming from. Once you think you know who might be doing it, it is unclear. The voices on the phone are creepy! Wonderful movie to watch for Halloween.

reviews.review_title: Scary, creepy, old movie, don't answer the phone
reviews.content: This movie reminds me of that tale everybody has heard by now. But instead of it being a baby-sitter, it takes place in a co-ed dorm. Somebody who sneaked into the attic by climbing a rose vine (or something like that) and makes obscene phone calls to the kids. one by one the kids get killed off. The people who are alive just think the kids are missing. Why somebody would stay in a dorm all Christmas holiday instead of going home is beyond me. This is a good movie considering it was made in 1974. One year older than me. After reading all these comments want me to watch the movie again.(considering i didn't know who Kidder was back then). The only problem is that it's very hard to find these days.

reviews.review_title: A great slasher film - Sadly underrated
reviews.content: Horror films have a bad reputation for being completely senseless and lacking a sense of artistic integrity. I'm not going to lie, some of them do fall into that category. However, there are moments in cinema history when you get a film that defines the genre. Something that is so good that it transcends the usual trappings that hold films of its kind down. A Nightmare on Elm Street, Halloween, The Exorcist, Alien, and The Texas Chainsaw Massacre are just a few of the horror gems that are well made and also very scary.The story is quite simple. At a sorority house, the girls are getting ready to go home for Christmas but begin receiving phone calls from a strange caller who won't give his name. The next day, many girls leave, but one who should have met her father doesn't turn up, which causes great concern for her safety. When another girl goes missing, the police begin searching the area and find a body nearby. Meanwhile, with only three students left in the sorority house, the phone calls continue, getting more and more menacing each time, but unknown to the remaining members of the house, the caller, and perhaps the killer, is closer to them than their nightmares could ever imagine.Keep in the mind that the killer calling his victims before he strikes them practically began here. Some might tell you it started with the original When A Stranger Calls, which was actually released a few years later, and it certainly took place before Scream, which was released in 1996. Black Christmas was the first to effectively use this technique and I must say this film uses it the best. While, menacing phone calls can get tiresome in some thrillers, the calls in this film generate fear and tension with each one that is made. They gradually become more violent and disturbing, to the point that they're almost unbearable. This isn't someone merely playing a game, this is someone with deep emotional and mental problems. The phone actually becomes a character itself because for most of the film it's our only link to the killer. We learn very little about him but what we do learn about him is through his acting out on the phone. I guess you can say the phone is an extension of his character.I also liked that this film believe less is more. There is very little blood and most of the violence is implied. Sometimes a visceral approach to horror can work but I think horror is most effective when they leave a lot of it up to the imagination. Your mind certainly creates a more disturbing image then they might've even shown.Speaking of the killer, he's probably one of the better ones to appear in a film of this nature. The most fascinating thing about him is you don't know anything about him throughout the film. The fact that he has randomly chosen to strike these girls makes him all the more frightening because it proves that sometimes crime is unexplained and completely unprovoked. You never really get a clear look at him, since he's merely a voice on the phone or cleverly shrouded in darkness but he's still a very powerful presence. The fact that he's seen rarely makes his few big "appearances" all the more terrifying. I'll provide two pictures of his most frightening exposures in the film and i guarantee when you see it, even after seeing these, those images will still stay with you long after the film is over.Halloween is commonly known for its effective opening scene which a steadycam shot that is supposed to be the perspective of the killer coming upon the house. That technique was made popular in that film but it was used first here and it's actually used often to great effect. The camera is constantly giving you the sense that danger is approaching and it's a very simple but effective technique. A lot of the film is seen from his perspective so it becomes very interesting to view a film through the killer's eyes.No good horror film can work without engaging leads and Black Christmas certainly has a pretty good cast. Olivia Hussy, who at this time was very popular due to her turn as Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, is a very likable heroine. She differs from most because she's definitely flawed and is nowhere near perfect but it also makes her all the more human. She's able to carry the film and while she's not the strongest actress around, she certainly handles the task at hand very well. The rest of the sorority girl cast consist of mostly unknowns but Margot Kidder, who would go on to play Lois Lane, is featured as one and quite funny as the booze hound of the house. John Saxon, of A Nightmare on Elm Street fame, appears here as a detective and is always a welcomed presence in anything he's in.Black Christmas is pretty hard to find in stores. I had to get mine on amazon but if you can try to catch this film. It's simple, effective and very scary. It should be given more credit for its role in shaping the slasher genre and maybe with the release of the remake this year, the original will get its much deserved mainstream attention. Check out Black Christmas this Halloween season, you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Mind numbing chiller that stays with you long after....
reviews.content: I remember first seeing this film in the early eighties, i was about six or seven, and horror films have a stronger affect on a child than they do an adult, this film proves it. I was utterly terrified to go to sleep in the dark after Black Christmas, the film's bogeyman is the film's mentality, the audience sees his point of view as he stalks the sorority house where the students are staying and the music is chilling and uncanny, its almost like the killer is an entity rather than a human being, and when he terrorises the girls with obscene phone calls the camera slowly pans over their reactions creating a chilling atmosphere, like the killer's voice is searing into their minds. It's a frightening and scary picture.In January this year though, i bought the film on DVD as a creepy childhood reminder, it has lost none of it's power but now that I'm in my late twenties the effect isn't the same. but i will watch it at least twice every December. A Classic.

Alfred Hitchcocks Psycho was the starting point of slasher films, Black Christmas was the main point of slashers for the 70s because lots of 70s horror slashers used some of the ideas from this like Halloween for instance where you see the vision of the killer himself like on Black Christmas. But no sequels though only a crappy remake in 2006 and even that was 33 years after the 1974 classic.The 2006 remake sucks, it tries to hard to be gory and violent when it doesn't look real, so DON'T WATCH IT (unless you want a good laugh at how rubbish it is) 10/10

reviews.review_title: This is where it all began
reviews.content: The 70's were without a doubt the golden era of horror films. Many brilliant classics have been produced in that time and "Black Christmas" is one of them. This is the godfather of all slasher films and rarely surpassed - "Halloween" would be on the same level as this one. Some argue that the first ever slasher made was Mario Bava's "A Bay Of Blood" which came out three years earlier from "Black Christmas". If you are a fan of the genre I would definitely recommend it since it does contain heavy elements common to the genre but nevertheless "Black Christmas" has a look that is considered modern even today. It has all the ingredients that make a great horror film: creepy atmosphere, tension that never lets go, nice camera work, eerie soundtrack and a nice mystery. There is even some dark humour thrown in. You will not be bored for even a second. The characters are interesting as well; they are not all your cliche college students which became very common in future slashers. Highly recommended to every true fan of classic horror.

Black Christmas has been the scariest psycho horror film I have ever seen!This is like an old version of Scream and Urban Legend because the killer is inside the house when he makes these creepy, crude calls.The story begins at a girl's sorority house on Christamas eve when an outsider decided to climb up to a window on the next story and then sneaked into the attic. And then, the creepy, crude calls began.The creepiest moments were when a girl named Claire Harrison decided to pack her stuff and leave the sorority house and suddenly, she could hear someone was in the closet and when she approached it, she was suffocated with plastic and the killer dragged her body through the trap door of the attic. And when morning came, the girls went outside to go look for her, and sitting in the rocking chair next to the camera [ close to the window of the attic] was little Claire with a plastic bag over her head!!! The second one was when Mrs. Quate went throughthe trap door of the attic and before she could do anything else, a hook went through her head! And another was when Barbera ( Jess's friend) was murdered by the killer when he came into her room and got hold of the horn of one of the glass unicorn figures!! And the last one was when Jess thought the killer was arrested and gone, he still lurked in the attic with Mrs. Quate with a hook in her head the cat and strangled Claire Harrison. And then, the telephone rang again.THE COPS NEVER FOUND HIM AND THE OTHER TWO BODIES!!!!!!!!! And Jess and the cops thought that it was her boyfriend Peter who was doing all the murders! To make things sound scary, the killer never shows himself in this motion picture. The only thing we get to see are his light green eyes. And to make things worse, Jess receives calls that came from the upstairs when she doesn't know it. DARN IT! You can hear the victims being strangled, suffocated and murdered!!! You want to know something? Once you watch this movie, you will never want to answer the phone when you have your friends around ever again! IT WILL MAKE YOU LIVE YOUR LIFE IN FEAR!!!

I realize that characters generally have to make incredibly stupid decisions in order for a horror movie to work, but this one, while genuinely creepy, just left me thinking that EVERYONE in it, except for the killer, was an absolute moron.

This film practically invented the "slasher" genre, and it is better than most films that fit that category.  It can make you laugh one minute (the sorority housemother is a riot!), then send chills down your spine (that voice on the phone is just plain creepy), the next.  Often copied, but almost never duplicated.  It is an original, and anyone who enjoys horror films must see it.  Be warned, even after all these years, the first telephone call from the mysterious stranger, is a shocker! Director Bob Clark (Porky's, A Christmas Story), serves up a first class chiller.

reviews.review_title: granddaddy of slasher flicks better than most
reviews.content: An unseen psychotic killer stalks the residents of a sorority house. Horror film that rises above most of its brethren has decent script, creepy atmosphere, reasonable acting and some evidence of character development. (Rating: B+)

SPOILERS AHEAD!!!After two competent attempts at horror (Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things, 1972, and Deathdream, 1973), Bob Clarke made Black Christmas, one of the first American Slasher films that mixes the Italian giallo genre and the psychoon-the-lose cycle initiated by Hitchcock's Psycho (1960). The results were original at the time, but even today, aware of all the clichés attributed to Slasher cinema, the film is still quite chilling.Set in an old dark sorority house during the festive season, a group of girls are brutally murdered by the raving lunatic that resides within the attic (Margot Kidder among them, who also starred in De Palma's Sisters, 1972, then found success as Lois Lane in Superman, 1978). The film even manages to mix horror and humour involving a buffoon excuse for a cop, Margot Kidder and John Saxon's detective character. The red herrings are characterised very well leading you to wonder whether it's Olivia Hussey's eccentric boyfriend (Keir Dullea of 2001: A Space Odyssey, 1968) or the escaped mental patient' that kidnapped and killed a young girl remains a mystery right up to the tense finale. During the film mechanics are used effectively, especially the now familiar caller is inside the house' routine. These are where the scares really lay. The foul-mouthed killer screams abuse at the girls down the telephone, occasionally snorting like a pig and mumbling something incoherent about a boy and girl called Angus and Billy'. The film ends with the fact that it is neither, but a deranged maniac who can only presumed to be Billy.The ending was intentionally left ambiguous for a planned sequel. It is even suggested that Bob Clarke, who then chose to do comedy, allowed John Carpenter to pick it up where he left it. As we all know what finally materialised wasn't Black Christmas 2, but the Daddy of the Slasher, Halloween (1978). This is one of the best Slashers, but definitely gets the award for the best psycho killer at Christmas, leading the way ahead of Silent Night, Deadly Night or Don't Open Until Christmas (1984).

reviews.review_title: Are we all talking about the same film?
reviews.content: After hearing lots of good things about this film I decided to rent it and see for my self.Not only did I find it boring and predictable but I also thought the story was flat and some of the acting was severely primitive.I've seen some pretty bad horror films in my time and nearly all of them would blow this film clean out of the water. To all the people who though it was scary, what exactly did you find scary and why?(This is just my opinion, feel free to disagree as much as you like)

reviews.review_title: One of the most frightening slasher movies EVER!!!
reviews.content: I stumbled across this at a local video store, and read the tagline, "If this movie doesn't make your skin crawl, then it's on too tight!". It looked frightening, so I picked it up and rented it. Went home, turned off all the lights (I was alone in the house too) and watched this film. I'll tell you honestly, I couldn't sleep after I finished watching this movie. I was so incredibly scared by this film. Sometimes, it even scared me more than "Halloween" did. Plus, there is a good mystery to this film because we don't really know who the killer is. It starts out with introducing to us several girls living in a sorority house during their Christmas Break. We are also aware that a psycho killer is lurking outside the house, and makes his way in through a window in the attic. Soon, he begins his reign of terror which includes threatening phone calls (oh god, I was freaking out during those scenes!)...and murderous attacks on the girls. There isn't a lot of blood or nudity, but this film is so incredibly frightening and scary and pumped with atmosphere, every horror fan should love it. Let's not forget that creepy piano score and the lovely girls, Olivia Hussey as beautiful heroine Jess (man, that girl can scream!!!), Margot Kidder (who does a hilarious job as Barb, an alcoholic chain smoker), and there is also Lynne Griffin (who was in "Curtains") and Andrea Martin ("Cannibal Girls"). This is an absolutely awesome movie! Rent it! Buy it! Cherish it!

reviews.review_title: A really good feminist suspense thriller from the 70s!
reviews.content: This movie is really well paced and uncharacteristically strong women for a movie from the 70s.The editing, filming, and setting are very well done and the story carries it along well.You really get a sense of fear and confusion from the villain of the film and his weird and obscene phone calls. Something I'm amazed my millennial jaded mind thought capable of a 70s movie.There are elements of this movie that were brought up decades later in the #metoo movement in how women's safety when it comes to domestic cases, is almost always very poorly understood and resolved.It also happens to be on Christmas! Yay! Add this to your xmas watching list!

This movie is f****ng scary as hell. Great performancs abound (although Miss Mack's character is annoying) and those phone calls are terrifying. The winter setting and the Christmas overtones make for an even creepier atmosphere, and Margot Kidder is great as a bad-mouth, alcoholic asthma victim. Indeed a classic horror.

reviews.review_title: one of the SCARIEST movies ever made
reviews.content: This film was released years before HALLOWEEN or FRIDAY THE 13TH, and it is much scarier than either. Even seasoned horror buffs will love this one. If you are a REAL horror movie freak, you should have already seen it!
To keep it short this movie is so overrated and boring. Good chunk of the film is the lead talking on the phone, there's barely any slashing, just very overrated what do people see in this?

The film opens with a creepy POV cam shot of a person spying through windows and proceeds to scale up the lattice to an open attic window.Four girls Jess, party animal Barb, Phyllis, Clare, and Claude the cat are harassed by a obscene caller they dub "The Moaner" alone in a sorority house under the care of a drinker house mother named Mrs Mac. The calls have begun a day before Christmas Eve. When everybody is getting ready to spend the holiday weekend with family or friends or boyfriends.This same day Phyllis has promised to go skiing with Barb and her parents, Clare plans are to be picked up by her father, and Jess wants to meet her boyfriend Peter before his piano recital whose stressed he hasn't slept for three days.But that night when our home invader kills Clare before she can say goodbyes to her sorority sisters and her boyfriend Chris and hides her body in the attic, and her father comes to meet her at the appointed time at the university, well, it puts a damper on everyone's holiday weekend plans because Clare will soon be officially a missing persons report on Christmas Eve.Between harassing obscene phone calls Mrs Mac, Barb, and Phyllis are forced to delay plans and reluctantly play host to Mr Harrison taking turns even. Jess goes to the conservatory to drop the big bomb on poor Peter before his recital no less, she is pregnant and wants an abortion. Peter disagrees and believes it is a choice they both need to make but his argument doesn't make much head way and Jess makes him promise to stop by the sorority house after the recital to discuss their future plans in greater detail. Hey, there is a pattern here stay tuned.Christmas Eve, Claude the cat found Clare and is kind enough to lead Mrs Mac to it. Clare is officially reported missing to Lt Fuller (John Saxon). Lt Fuller organizes a large search party of volunteers and police to comb a local park and the surrounding neighborhoods with the assistance of Jess, Barb, Phyllis, Chris, and Mr Harrison. They find a dead body of a girl but no Clare. Peter bombs his recital. Returning back to the sorority house it is evident to our trio of girls that Mrs Mac has left the building. Barb who is nearly obscene as "The Moaner" finally crashes from two straight days of hard drinking. Jess receives another bad call and reports the phone stalker to the police when in steps in Peter who had been waiting upstairs. They argue Jess isn't going to give her planned future but Peter wants to give up his doesn't want to be a concert hall pianist anymore and neither wants to work at the conservatory anymore he wants to get married.Lt Fuller arrives to set up the tap passing a departing Peter, learning that the sorority house has two lines, one in the living room and hall and the other in Mrs Mac's room. He also stations a patrol car outside. Two fails to track the phone stalker but the killer drops a quote of a statement Peter made that same evening. Uh-oh. Jess and Lt Fuller are coming to the same conclusions. Lt Fuller follows this lead to a destroyed piano in the conservatory and Jess's greatest fears are allayed by Phyllis who reminds her that Peter was visiting them when the phone stalker dialed them up making him the suspect impossible.This films suffers a lot of errors in continuity and gaping plot holes. If the phone lines are only in living room, the hall, and Mrs Mac's room how is the killer moving around undetected? There isn't a phone jack in the attic. And how come the girl's failed to hear him yelling from Mrs Mac's room? And how did he leave the house, kill patrolman Jennings, and get back inside the house undetected by the sorority sisters nor the search party outside? Yeah, he could of went back down the lattice from the attic window and again back up? Still... I ain't buying it. Unless our killer is a flipping ninja yeah that is what he is. *Gives self-induced facepalm* D'oh.This is a classic slasher maybe deserves a better rating but I didn't find it all that scary, but rather silly, I didn't appreciate how forcibly determined the film chose to misdirect me. Actually, it would have been an improvement to this film if Peter did indeed suffer a mental breakdown leading to a homicidal psychosis. Keir Dullea fit the role like a hand-in-glove.

I always recommend "Black Christmas" when acquaintances and I are sitting around talking about the scariest movies. Like everyone said (I knew it before reading other reviews) this came out first and the later "Halloweenish" flicks copied ideas and atmosphere.My dad and two sisters were watching this on TV when we were kids and I remember my dad would try to scare the hell out of us by staging a fake horrified jump and a cry of fear from his prone position, which sent us all jumping! It was called "When a Stranger Calls" (for TV) and they must have cut some of Margot Kidder's lines like "You f***ing CREEP!!!" which she says into the phone with such power and conviction that it makes me crack up whenever I hear it. Yeah, I kinda made a sound bite from of it.I still had to grab a blanket, cover myself and put my feet up on the couch when I saw the video release a few years ago. Of course I only make it worse while watching it in the dark. The only other movie that even comes close in creeping me out is "Omen" when Mrs. Baylock's face appears as she goes after the mother. A 7 out of 10, this movie ranks in my top 5 of the most frightening ever.

reviews.review_title: Sorority girls shouldn't play with mad killers
reviews.content: Best known for directing "Porky's", Bob Clark also directed "Porky's II", "Baby Geniuses" and "Baby Geniuses 2". To be fair, he's also the director of a decent zombie film with an excellent title: "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things". And of course of "Black Christmas", a film that has all good films should have: an inspired screenplay, good actors and excellent camera work.Olivia Hussey is the star of the film. She was mainly cast and admired because of her leading role in Zeffirelli's version of "Romeo And Juliet". "Black Christmas" isn't the weirdest film Hussey is in: you can also spot her in Metzger's "The Cat And The Canary", Kinji Fukasaku's "Fukkatsu no hi" (a.k.a. "Virus") and "Turkey Shoot" (a.k.a. "Blood Camp Thatcher"). You'd almost be more surprised she recently played Mother Teresa. Olivia Hussey is excellent in "Black Christmas" as Jessica (Jess) Bradford, the pregnant and terrorized girl in the sorority house. Don't be put off by the fact that "Black Christmas" takes place in a sorority house: this isn't the sort of film where scantily-clad bimbos are chased by a maniac with a set of knives. The film actually bothered about something called 'plot' and most characters have (at least a little) depth. A welcome change.Also noteworthy is the camera work.
